headline: Software Engineer
pros: Open and exciting. Engineering oriented. Good peers. Good tools. Good benefits.Open and exciting. Engineering oriented. Good peers. Good tools. Good benefits.
cons: You need to be very social. Different teams are very different. Your manager decides your performance.
advice_to_mgmt: Some people are really hard to work with. It is really hard to survive at Facebook if your manager does not like you much.

headline: I didn't expect that
pros: Not very political compare to other advertising company. Paid is very good, easy to reach quota, growing business in greater china, amazing benefits and great CEO. Great outlook to the business, but need to carefully select team and focus market.
cons:
Hong Kong office culture, and team culture. Over controlling of employees actions... surprisingly, no one speaks English at office because 65% of employees are from China, and 30% Hong Kong. Hard to perform and compete with mainland colleagues because they are good at sucking up and aggressive. At meetings, always need to compete to share things that are meaningless to everyone, and raise your hands as much as possible. 
Hard to trust anyone at work, even managers and management and HR.
advice_to_mgmt: Improve culture and provide care to ethic minority at office. Be open and honest, and do not only listen to managers. You know our culture is bad, and many people are unhappy at work. Too many people needs use time and energy to act happy. Waste of time, not efficient.

headline: the best company in the world
pros: high income, good work and life balance
cons: lack of promotion opportunities and time

headline: China and local culture
pros: Meals benefits and insurance is offered to employee. Standard is higher than what the market is offering in China. They also hired a lot of smart peopple.
cons: Very political environment. Promotion favours people that is close with management, a lot of pleasing work needs to be done everyday. Hong kong employee get revenged after sharing real feedbacks at employee surveys. Also, CSM works much harder than CP, no one dare to complain, because afraid get revenged .
advice_to_mgmt: Allow employee share more feedbacks

headline: People Focused
pros: Facebook deeply cares about its employees and has built a compelling culture around support and growth. Career growth opportunities are plentiful. If you don't like the team you're on or don't get the support you want from your manger, Facebook empowers you to find new teams or projects. Facebook wants its employees to be invested in their work and to feel connected to its larger mission. If large scale opportunities and growth are important to you, Facebook is a fantastic place to work.
cons: Facebook's culture is demanding and fast paced. The greatest aspect of working at Facebook is that everyone is very motivated and very smart. The problem with this is that they all expect the very same of you. Holding a very high bar for excellence can certainly be demanding so it's important to make sure you're always carefully paying attention to your own personal work/life balance.
response: Thank you for this thoughtful feedback. Building a career at Facebook is about using your unique strengths, doing meaningful work that matters to you and making Facebook better. We're glad you're here on this journey with us.

headline: Smartest people, impactful opportunities, work that matters.
pros:
- Working with the smartest people I've met.
- Visible, present leadership.
- Incredible salary, benefits, culture. 
- Opportunity to do work that matters in the world. 
- If you get an offer from Facebook, you have to take it. Just trust me!
cons: - You are in the drivers seat of your career at Facebook, and there's no set growth plan or defined career ladder. This is challenging for some but those who are ambitious will thrive!
advice_to_mgmt: Thankful to work here because of how leadership values employees above all. Keep it up.

1. Company culture. Openness is mind blowing. 
2. Structure to support employees to grow.
3. Excellent compensation.
4. Place with lots of awesome, smart and most important good people. 
5. Opportunities to be part of project that can create positive impact to Facebook products, users or internet ecosystem in general.
cons: Nothing much, experiences may vary slightly team to team or manager to manager; but lots of safety net in place to ensure core values are intact and employees are well taken care of.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work.
response: Thank you for this feedback. We're glad you're on this journey with us. Being open is one of our core values and taking care of our employees is paramount. Thank you for choosing to grow your career here.

headline: Fast Growth, Tough Work
pros: Great Benefits, Pay, and relatively fast career growth for a large company
cons:
PSC/performance process is brutal; extreme focus on individual performance -- people are more driven to achieve here than on company success in general or other goals

Bad documentation/bad organization/poor processes

increasingly bureaucratic

leadership still has no idea how to counter public controversies
advice_to_mgmt:
Get a grip; find a cogent way to deal with public controversies and stop the incessant pandering to people who will never be supportive of the company. 

Never run a "We're sorry" campaign every again and fire everyone who proposed and supported that

headline: Overall good company, steer clear of research ops
pros: Facebook in general is a great company to work for. All the amazing perks you read about in all the other reviews, leadership does give off the impression that they care about their employees. Everyone is very smart and in most cases people are enthusiastic about collaborating and conversing about new ideas. You will learn a lot very quickly and often be inspired by the ideas and leadership of others.
cons:
Outside of Facebook probably being responsible for destroying the moral fabric of society, Your experience at Facebook is highly dependent on your manager and team. 

That said, stay away from Research Operations. I have never seen such poor, uninspiring, thoughtless leadership in my career. Multiple ICs have had to take extended leave because they could not take the abuse from management and were broken down to the point where they felt they had no value. Managers are reported to HR repeatedly, without any action taken. Leadership on that team would rather defend managers to the death than support an IC. There are at least two similar reviews on Glassdoor about this team.
advice_to_mgmt: Dissolve the research ops team and outsource that work to contractors. The pulse scores are consistently in the tank even pre-Covid. Most people would welcome the severance check and the freedom.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Fast moving, fun, humble people
pros:
There’s no where like Facebook. I’m surrounded by talented yet friendly and humble people. The culture is strong, we have a clear mission and values. 
- Allow you to lean into your strengths and this makes work enjoyable. 
- I can make impact quickly. 
- My manger is supportive and open.
- Growth oriented, always options to learn including L&D and mentors.
- Travel was amazing when we could! 
- Incredible benefits including generous holidays, bonuses, equipment, health, parental leave.
- Best in Class review system- it’s peer led and official reviews happen twice per year.
- Inclusive culture. Lots of ERGs.

This company looked after me better than I could of dreamed during Covid. Received many supports including money and flexible working.
cons: Negative press cycles, Facebook is in the eye of the media and much of the good for the world work isn’t covered.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the company flat and allow us to move fast.

headline: Still a great place to work
pros: Work hard at keeping remote working people connected. Generous support for remote workers. Great support for flexible hours focus on work delivery. Try hard for "fairness" in bi-annual assessments. Pretty independent salary setting method means you are not completely at the whim of your relationship with your boss although your bosses support in presenting your performance twice a year is a major contributor to your grading. This in turn drives your pay rise, chance of upgrading your level, and, the percentage bonus your granted. There is also a formula based calculation that determines what stock value you may receive as a top-up refresher to your stocks granted when joining. This too is linked to performance. Employees who drive hard and perform well all the time supporting their peers tend to get well rewarded (as they should be!)
cons: As with many rapidly expanding businesses, some people can find themselves with a different manager each year. Difficult for relationship building and targets agreement. Drive to target performance review scores can get in the way of common sense sometimes. Some policy implementations can come across as harsh. There are structures imposed on how you can make promotion steps that work against job retention.
advice_to_mgmt: Try to limit management turnover where you can. Review inter-regional movement policy in relation to stock grant changes.

headline: Review

headline: Good pay and opportunities met with exhaustive list of challenges
pros:
Pay
Benefits
WFH bonuses
Resources
Brands / Clients you work with or on
Big Tech / Market Leader
cons:
Internal leveling isn't often met with expectations requested for a role. You could potentially accept an offer at Facebook at a level that would limit transfer opportunities until you reach next level, even if you have the externally facing requirements and experience. 
Neverending negative news cycle.
Marketing here has become very technical and tactical... The work is neverending and not very fulfilling (unless you have great partners, and even then it can be challenging). 
So much information overload.
So many resources that it causes paralysis and a feeling that growth feels stagnant and done by a checklist of expectations and navigating politics.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire a technical team with the bandwidth to help with those type of issues. Stop relying on partner and account managers to fix all issues and help with all technical/tactical and strategy guidance. You really just end up losing on the strategy side- quantatively and qualitatively.

headline: not bad
pros: many food choice, cheap price
cons: less free time, stressed out

headline: Facebook cares about me as a person
pros: I have been very pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoy working at Facebook. It took a friend many months to convince to apply, but I am so glad I finally listened. I finally found a company that treats me like a valued asset, pays well, takes care of my benefits, my health (physical and mental), and provides a supportive team environment with opportunity to grow. I have autonomy, flexibility, and lots of responsibility given to me. I feel like my teammates and managers care about me as a person. As someone passionate about sustainability and the environment, I am also very pleased with Facebook's commitment to sustainability (ie: powering all offices and data centers with renewables).
cons: There is overall a lack of process and procedure at FB. It surprises me how much the company still runs likes a start up. It's easy to get lost in all the tools, wiki's, information repositories, etc. You have to be willing to dig in and fix problems, propose solutions, and get your hands dirty, if you want to see anything change. Sometimes managers are not clued in how best to support their people (many young/new managers), so you have to be comfortable asking for what you need.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to support, teach, train managers on how to support their teams, especially in the new remote environment. Help provide career tracks for those interested in people management.

headline: Smart people, great culture, strong comp and benefits

headline: Very driven by PSC
pros: Benefits, salary, work from home flexibility
cons: The culture is very driven by the PSC reviews which happen every six months. This causes people to want to hold on to high visibility projects or projects that have “impact” so that they can get a better rating which then leads to higher pay/bonus. It really boils down to what team you land on and your manager. Some are lucky enough to get promoted in less than a year and others can take up to three to five years to get a promotion. The company is large and has become very bureaucratic like any other large organization. I also think that there is a culture of “conform or else” even though they promote authenticity, it’s not 100% accurate. Conform to the FB way of thinking or be treated like an outsider. Diversity is a sham and there are a lot of cliques, either you’re in or you’re out.

headline: Great career opportunity
pros:
Facebook is Facebook and you get yourself amazing branding stamp in the CV.

Huge range of projects and opportunities.

cons:
Low compensation compared to competitors.
Long working hours - it can be difficult to balance work-life. 
Constant pressure.
Not everyone is hard working and if you end up with lazy, non responsive people on the project you won't have a great time.
advice_to_mgmt: Levels are not assigned consistently throughout organization. E.g. people with 5-10 years of experience who just join the company might get IC3, where someone who has 3 years of experience (joined facebook just after graduating) within the company will be at the same level.

headline: Overrated, unstructured, chaotic
pros:
Competitive salary in the location, good perks.
Good internal tools.
Good Learning opportunities.
Smart people working.
Good facilities, while the offices were open.
cons:
Can't agree with some of the company values.
Also, what they advertise as company values, they don't actually adhere to.
Censorship, and toxic culture in general. You can't be open unless you support a particular side. People have been driven out by the toxic culture for having wrong opinions, unless they are able to suppress themselves. 
As engineers you will have to constantly look for what to work on, this adds extra responsibilities. There are very less product managers, program managers, etc., so all those responsibilities have to be taken by engineers.
Too fast paced, sometimes just for the sake of pace or 'impact'.
Unstructured environment, teams will continue recruiting more and more without having much clarity on what to work on.

headline: Great place to work for certain people
pros: High bar for talent (you learn by your peers), makes/keeps you sharp, rational/data-driven culture, VERY people oriented, great total comp and benefits. Have more respect for Zuck since having worked here; seems candid and earnest in bettering the company's outlook. Lots of interesting product development happening consistently.
cons: Productivity suite is chaotic / not standardized across teams (takes a lot of time managing personal comms), sometimes it can feel TOO people oriented (very surprising what can be said to managers and Zuck himself that is honestly flat out disrespectful but tolerated...also, lots of entitlement - particularly at lower levels that can make managing teams/talent tiresome). For mid-career professionals (L5-L6 in particular), advancement is tougher as the company gets bigger/evolves; seems like there are more growth opportunities for junior levels (in terms of promo: L2/L3) and senior levels (in terms of new areas of learning/expansion: L8/D1+). For SOME people, the high ambiguity, fast pace, and 99% self-determination of one's career will not fit their personal preferences. For me personally, it works well. But I have friends at the company who are quite frustrated/unhappy due to the lack of tops-down order and seemingly chaotic shifting of priorities and strategies. (Note: I work in Facebook Reality Labs, which is definitely more nascent and a bit different in flavor than the 'core apps' teams.)
advice_to_mgmt: Have a backbone: Just standardize some of the productivity/comms tools across the full company and don't let managers be disrespected for sake of "culture" (which can only be fostered for so long as a company gets gigantic).

headline: Make sure your morals and values aligns with company values before choosing this place as a future employer
pros: Compensation is amongst the best within the industry.
cons: Diversity, equal pay for equal work, micor-aggression against minority employees, not a respectful workplace, bullying and retaliation practices
advice_to_mgmt: Facebook should consider revamping its standard hiring and HR practices and give some regards to leadership upward feedback. Skip level interactions are detrimental to the overall success of the team and quite frankly, with Facebook's loose hiring practices, some individuals are not qualified to lead teams. Mid-level management should endure intense diversity training and the current managing a respectful workplace and bias training should be more indepth. Managers are not held accountable when accusations of mistreatment are presented and Facebook legal team spends more time looking for ways to cover up infractions to distance themselves rather than holding those responsible accountable. This is why the minority work force is departing at record numbers.

headline: BIPOC Beware
pros:
- when the offices were open, the amenities 
- healthcare is one of the best I have seen 
- majority of the people I worked with were amazing and fun to be around
cons:
- FB knows they are on the line to create a diverse workforce and have been struggling for a while with it. With all the "effort" going into mass hiring of BIPOC, there is little to no consideration for how to retain. There is constant censorship on the intra-Workplace conversations, discrimination during PSC, and worst the silent exiting of employees that frame BIPOCs to be resigning. All the hush money they offer exiting employees help keep up the facade
- With such rapid growth, inept individual contributors were forced into management positions and now they spend all their time trying to keep their friends at the top and everyone else in desperation to advance. This also means there are far too many bad managers 
- HR is a hot mess of incompetence whether it was related to PSC, career growth, everyday issues
- The Kool-Aid FB forces through their infrastructure keeps many brilliant employees blinded from their true potential of getting competitive pay elsewhere.

headline: Former employee 2011*
pros: Facebook marketing team... B2B sales. When I learned what my job would be I felt a little intimidated, however, the management and training staff were excellent. It is very difficult to get selected for this job, so this is one of my most memorable accomplishments. You're not really in until you've trained and passed a mock call. Definitely not an easy mock call. Not alot of my training class went on to continue working there. The work environment was relaxed, business casual dresscode required, but it just felt easygoing on the floor, not all high stress, high powered call floor where everyone is yelling sales stats and talking crazy to a potential client to get the sale. They continued on the job trainings as necessary. There were many opportunities for lateral moves, and promotions. Sadly, the reason I had to leave was because of a family emergency, that became an ongoing issue.
cons:
What was offered to potential clients may have been a bit too costly. Most businesses contacted were small brick and mortar, mom and pop shops who just couldn't afford to pay what the programs cost.

headline: Terrible WLB, Constant reorgs; Low growth; Leveling and reviews are a total mystery
pros:
- Decent peers
- Metrics driven culture
- Global impact
- Lots of teams to choose from
cons:
- Terrible WLB: This depends on the team but generally FB hires less people per product compared to peers, so the amount of work is always high for PMs. Privacy, compliance, integrity, policy and similar regulatory stuff, albeit much needed, has added a ton of work, but the expectation of shipping fast is still there. Which means no WLB. Many 15+ hour days in a month are common.
- Low growth: Hard to become a people manager in this company unless you’re really lucky.
- Leveling is a total mystery. People who advance are usually those whose managers are willing to give them a great review at any cost.
- Middle management is filled with old timers who've never worked anywhere else, or some people who probably got in because they knew someone. Decision making is horrible leading to a lot of teams with tons of churn and low morale.
- No patience to build lasting products. Projects that need nurturing are shelved and the only ones that continue are those that Zuck personally cares about. You have 6 months to show massive progress, or else your product is done. 
- Reorgs are as common as oxygen at FB. This causes a ton of headache to have to re-start every so often.
- Business has serious headwinds due to things like signal loss caused by privacy climate and anti-trust legislation.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Do an audit of middle management and let go of people with terrible reviews.
- Find ways to grow product managers
- Focus on WLB of your PMs by hiring more, being more realistic on timelines.
- Invest more in long-term bets and stop re-orging every 6 months.
- Your 5 values say nothing about being supportive to one another, creating a workplace that people love working at and that shows in the way your culture has evolved.

You have to use Atlas which is kind of internal Facebook for organisations, in this Atlas you have to publish posts about the projects you work on. 
The amount of likes, shares and comments your internal post gets impact your evaluation and your rating. 
You have to conduct self-assessment every 6 months (which is fine per-se) however you must provide 5 colleagues at least that will fill their opinion over your performances. The craziest thing is that you don't get to see their feedback and learn about it only from your manager.

The HR in the Tel Aviv office is very problematic, they have difficulties understanding what Program Managers do and it's quite daunting working with them.

headline: Fast paced company with high expectations, but incredibly fair. You won't a place that cares more about it's people.
pros:
- Incredible benefits 
- Excellent compensation that rewards strong performance 
- Lots of autonomy 
- Tons of room for growth
- Very transparent from the top down
- Strong leadership
- Intelligent and caring colleagues
- The most fair and well thought out review process you will find everywhere 
- Exciting work
cons:
- If you don't learn to make the work life balance work for you, it can be exhausting. But you'll also be given lots of support with this if you ask for it. 
- It doesn't matter how good you are at your job, chances are you're going to be surrounded by a ton of other people who are just as good if not better. Imposter syndrome is real, but if you got an offer, you probably belong here too.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing, keep an eye on employee burnout, keep supporting your people and keep pushing them, and the rest of the world, forward.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations

headline: Amazing Place to Work
pros: Great benefits, the company really takes care of you
cons: A lot of pressure and many hours of work
response: Thank you for your feedback and your contribution in growing Facebook as a vendor program manager in Dublin. I appreciate the call out on benefits, and the fact that the company really takes a care of its employees. We think a lot about how we can improve the employee experience to ensure we are creating and fostering and inclusive environment where everyone can be heard and feel a sense of belonging. We also try to provide a competitive remuneration package including benefits, so thank you for the shout out there. We know that work-life balance is a challenge for a lot of workers in the tech sector, I know I certainly feel it juggling parenting as well as work responsibilities. Facebook continues to focus on this area: whether it is providing internal tools to understand how we work, providing resources to learn more on resilience, mental health and work-life balance. Or training managers to be more responsive to employees experiencing burn out or stress. We'll keep continuing our focus to do even more here.

headline: Bottom-up engineering culture
pros: For those that appreciate a bottom-up engineering culture, this place is great. People throw together ("hack") prototypes, and the most successful ones win. Everything is about the results. Things like documentation and reliability, which some engineers bristle against, are secondary. Bureaucracy is nonexistent.
cons:
Engineers who prefer a more "design first" style will find it infuriating. The "don't talk to me unless you've got a prototype in hand" culture can feel like it's stifling ideas (even though it's a very reasonable reaction against pie-in-the-sky proposals). Proper architecture and code quality can be big problems.

There's a strong emphasis on social networking as a means of getting things done. For introverts this can be unduly difficult, and even for extroverts it can come across as a triumph of personality and schmoozing over sound engineering principles. There is a strong emphasis on trying to fabricate relationships in order to have impact, which can feel extremely deceitful.

headline: Good benefits but poor management

response: Thank you for your feedback and your contribution to Facebook's development as an engineer in Dublin. Thank your for acknowledging the work we do with our employee experience and the benefits we offer in our gym and food offerings. I'm sorry to hear that we didn't meet your expectations when it came to management and communication. We'll continue to keep working on how we improve our communication playbooks and how we invest in our management's development and leadership skills. Best of luck in the next chapter of your career and once again, thanks for the feedback. I appreciate the time you took to share it.

headline: Amazing people, supersonic pace, hard work, impact from Day One
pros:
I've never worked with a more incredible group of people at a place that drives a culture of belonging and inclusion. I came from another large tech company, and there is no comparison in terms of the way employees are able to bring their authentic selves to work.

Make no mistake, however, working at Facebook is not easy, and it's not for everyone. In my mind, these things are still pros, but definitely need to be called out - super fast-paced, high bar for excellence, a ton of autonomy and freedom, and huge opportunity for impact. The opportunity is there to do amazing things at Facebook, you just have to grab it.
cons: Although we are a very large tech company, sometimes we still think we are a start-up. There are processes that one would think should be in place by now that are not. Ways of working can be complex with lots of gray areas that can sometimes slow work down. And of course, FB is polarizing, just in and of itself. Disagreement with leadership decisions is common, but civil discourse is encouraged.
advice_to_mgmt: Moving fast is great, but sometimes we need to slow down to speed up.

headline: Pays well but unprofessional and no career development
pros: Salary, bonus, and stock grants are generous and the benefits offered are fantastic. The company does care about its employees and made welcome changes during the pandemic to support us.
cons:
The biannual review cycle and the focus on "impact" makes an endless treadmill of overworking to make sure you get a good review. The company is very unprofessional in its working style where there is little teamwork and many people who try to dump the hard work on you while they chase revenue gains for the review cycle. There is no real career progression and management will do musical chairs and swap your role. I only got to do what I thought I was hired for 18 months. 
The senior management are very disingenuous when it comes to being neutral in politics and supporting BLM. They keep leaning to support Trump but then acting shocked when the company gets caled out for it.

headline: Lack of Diversity
pros: Good Benefits and flexible work arrangment
cons: I have enjoyed working at Facebook but as a POC, I do feel that the lack of diversity has affected the quality of work we do, and diluted the creative culture at Fb. Creative teams across the company are very white, and mostly male. While I'm excited to see more roles open up in Facebook for creatives, I worry that it affords teams and management opportunities to hire more white people. Instead of bringing in someone with a different experience that is talented and deserving of an opportunity. Sadly, I've seen BIPOC candidates get shortlisted, only to not make the cut for arbitrary reasons. 'Not a good fit' is a poor reason for someone who spent the time interviewing with us with a stella portfolio. I worry that teams are only bringing in certain candidates to meet some sort of quota or to appear "exhaustive" in their search, just so that they can hire another white person. I'm tried of observing these performative acts of diversity from creative leaders across teams and hope that this changes. We can do better, we should do better.
advice_to_mgmt: Introduce more ways to hold teams and creative leaders accountable so that we are continuously assessing the health of the culture here at Fb. Hire more diverse talent! We are so white and boring as it!

headline: Impact Work Internally and Externally
pros:
In no particular order, here are some pros that come to mind:

1. Surrounded by very smart, experienced people, who are top in their field

2. A lot of non-tech opportunities, esp. for those who are not SWEs such as folks in HR, Operations, Research, Recruiting, Branding, etc.

3. Supportive employee resource groups such as Black@ and BlackWomen@ which I found has helped me a lot as a black woman living in the Bay

4. Global cross-functional teams collaboration, and worldly impact of the work I do. I'm non-tech, and I still get to work with engineers and other orgs on projects and even get to hack with them in Hackathons!

5. Candid and tough conversations are carried out within the company among employees using Workplace, which have led to overall updates to policies, and also in the products and services we provide to people globally. It's not always pretty or easy to do (sometimes it can get bumpy); but the fact that we can have these discussions in our teams and from Zuck as a company means a lot to me, especially coming from my experience in the past where my leaders didn't even acknowledge current events and the plight of others.

6. Benefits and Perks! There are so many amazing benefits that have truly saved me-- medical insurance, mental health support through Lyra (for you and family members) have helped so much especially during Covid times. 

7. So many other things other than Facebook, Instagram and Oculus to work on! The company has grown and work that we do esp. in AR/VR keeps me excited to work here, as well as research that we're doing.
cons:
1. Sometimes moving so fast can caused projects (non-tech) to experience multiple iterations when a longer time line may have yielded a "one-and-done" result

2. Would love more diversity and people of color in higher leadership positions. 

3. With the increase in company size over a short span of time, I've notice that there are folks that are hired on that do not align with our mission and values. This can cause tension within the teams, and some managers do not address these head on.

4. On some occasions work week can be quite long, from my experience. When dealing with a global project with multiple stakeholders, hours of work can be a pain esp. when you're in late night meetings or early morning (i.e 1AM PST when with APAC for example.). I find this more of a given depending on your role however.
advice_to_mgmt: Let's go back to being leaders in tech and policies! When it comes to racism and systemic racism amongst people of color in the U.S., and groups, politicians that post false information to instigate, I don't think it should take us so long to action (i.e. Twitter banning /fact checking politician posts that are false... before FB did).

headline: Dangerous Cult DNA
pros: Most skillful engineers in the country
cons: In my position I had a lot of influence in hiring and terminating employees. I have being exposed to dubious decisions in that area by upper management, actions taken without good-heart and with conflicts of interest. This behavior could only thrive in our Cult-like company where truly speaking out your mind could hurt your career. Quite ironically, the values of giving constant feedback are encouraged in Facebook, but in reality, employees are afraid of giving negative feedback as they know the potential devastating consequences of doing so. Negative feedback will be given about technical decisions and ideas but not about managerial decisions or the human resource department from fear of upsetting the wrong people.
advice_to_mgmt: Get more involved in what is actually happening in your offices. Teaching a certain set of company values in Facebook bootcamp is step one, but it must be followed through with understanding why those values aren't implemented in the day to day life in the office.

headline: Working for Facebook has exceeded my expectations!
pros:
-Opportunity to make immediate impact in your role on day 1. You are not limited based on seniority to work on big, high visibility impactful initiatives
-Compensation is excellent! Bonus program and additional financial support doing COVID has been amazing
-Flexibility and support of remote work. Leaders encouraging employees to focus on mental health, family before work has been appreciated.
-Incredible smart people and teams
-Wide variety of employee resource groups - there is truly something for EVERYBODY! And if there isn't something that meets your specific needs, you can create it! 
-Strong leadership top down
-Tons of great professional development programs and special events for everyone.
cons:
-The work never stops and is intense!! Having healthy work life balance is critical for maintaining sanity. 
- Lack of ethnic diversity across the board, particularly in leadership positions.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your IC's more to understand the challenges and opportunities to make this company stronger.

headline: Strong, supportive company culture where I feel valued
pros: From the long list of benefits that my family and I can take advantage of, to the inclusive, supportive, hard-working company culture, I couldn't be happier working at FB. You're surrounded by really smart people who care just as much as you do about the work and impact you can make here. Giving and receiving feedback is highly valued. You have the opportunity to grow and develop the skill sets that you want to - you don't necessarily feel like a cog, even though the company is huge and growing.
cons: Company is growing so quickly - potentially faster than the company is able to keep up with in a sustainable way.
advice_to_mgmt: Be more transparent with the public about all of the various initiatives that we're working on to combat misinformation, etc. We're doing a lot to try to make things better for everyone, but all of the work that we are doing isn't always shared.

headline: Great Company, great intensions, and still evolving...
pros:
Tons of flexibility to bring your best skills to the game
Empowerment
Authenticity - Bring your Best Self
Passionate, smart coworkers
Great pay and benefits
cons:
Ambiguity - Can be daunting if you aren't very self-motivated and driven
Collaboration - Collaboration is something I view as a positive typically, but too much reliance on the consensus can slow things down. This can be a problem in a company where few things are mandated top-down.
Recognition - Recognition for Impact is top of mind. Recognition for making others great is still a work in progress.
advice_to_mgmt: I love my job at FB. My advice to management is to hold your leadership teams accountable for really understanding the world they manage to truly see the hard, smart work being performed to make our company even better than it is today. Today it feels like a big gap between leadership and rank and file workers, including the middle management level. Until we evolve our performance model, work will be focused on 6-month chunks and limit our ability to collaborate with cross-functional teams.

headline: Extensive Support and Brilliant Coworkers
pros: One of the biggest perks is working with some of the most intelligent, thoughtful and honest coworkers anywhere in the world. No matter how big of a fish you have been in previous ponds, you will be a small fish here and have incredible space to grow. There is incredible freedom to pursue the projects you want in the way that you want as long as you can defend why they are important to the company. While less than it was in the past, there is incredible transparency and accountability from leadership internally. Your manager will support and promote you in a way that is unprecedented at most other companies. Most importantly, the work you do affects millions or billions of people - even seemingly tiny tasks like making the app update 1 second faster or tweaking a model to deliver 1% more interesting content can have a large positive impact on the world. While it doesn't always succeed, the company takes diversity and social justice seriously and it shows in project initiatives and hiring.
cons: It's a big company with entrenched (if sometimes informal) power structures. As much as people try to be transparent, there are backdoor politics that affect your role and career that you might not learn about until much later, if ever. There will be constant pressure to specialize - many of the new skills I've developed here would transfer well to other big tech companies, but be wasted at a startup. Work life balance can go sideways quickly unless you protect yourself zealously. Even in the "move fast (and we no longer say 'break things')" culture there is a lot of pressure to not mess up in ways that affect the public negatively - even small mistakes in privacy or integrity have terrible negative effects on potentially millions of people.
advice_to_mgmt: Get way ahead of privacy and integrity trends - we're usually reactive to anything that affects the top line, we should do a lot more speculative research on ways to protect free speech, squash misinformation, and protect user identity - all at the same time, even though those things often trade off poorly.

headline: Frenetic, extreme stress, and disorganized with good pay
pros: High comp, excellent benefits, smart people
cons: This company works you so hard that you can't ever see the bigger picture. I think this is on purpose so you never notice your complicity in the bad things the company enables. They also compensate you well so it's hard to leave for a lower paying job. They also lied about the hours during my interview. First year expectations are for you to work extremely hard for 10-12 hours/day with little to no support. This is worse for people who come in at more senior levels. If you have a good job now, do not leave it to go to FB because of higher pay. I wish I hadn't.
advice_to_mgmt:
The company pays a lot of lip service to employee wellness, but mid-level managers are always trying to justify their jobs by demanding new reports, plans, and strategies. This is made worse by the high turnover at various levels of management, meaning that every time a new manager comes in, they need to be brought up to speed. These operational tasks are so frequent with relatively no lead-time that long-term product work suffers enormously. 

The company would benefit from managers taking a longer view and giving their teams enough uninterrupted time to execute on the management's strategy.

headline: Great Company

FAANG pros in general.

* Prestige
* Engineering Excellence

cons: You become more and more a FB engineer over time and tools do not translate to other companies in the industry.

headline: The people are nice, but that's about it
pros: - The people are nice
cons:
- Not Invented Here is pervasive and basic tools are often rewritten for little, if any, gain
- Open source is not valued. Open Source is only done when the company sees a direct benefit like sharing code with vendors or when an advocate is willing to fight through all the red tape
- The company advocates a work/life balance, but expextations are not reasonable for a 40 hour week
- Code quality is extremely low. There is little empasis on quality so long as it works
- Developer and process tooling is all custom and buggy resulting in a lot of externa workarounds
- Internal training is low quality and external training is the same budget as swag. There is no tuition reimbursement
- The company says to be your authentic self, but if you don't drink the Kool-aid you're going to have a bad time
- The company is driven by semi-annual performance reviews that create perverse incentives which emphasize impact over quality and short term over long term goals.
- There are too many meetings and most are run inefficiently
- The company uses Workplace (Facebook for work) for internal communications which, like Facebook, has a low signal to noise ratio unless you ignore most things
- The company is process heavy in many areas but the only way things get done is when people ignore the processes
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to employee concerns. Embrace a more mature culture.

headline: Great place to start a career

* Tons of mentorship opportunities

cons: Work life balance is a bit rough

headline: Community oriented, challenging and a place for voicing ideas and having impact
pros: Facebook is a company where you can own your career, grow professionally and personally, be challenged and help shape the future of technology for billions of global consumers no matter what role you're in. You can find community, have a voice and use your time to make real impact. There are endless teams to work on including some that aren't even in existence today, so your career has the opportunity to evolve as you do as an individual. I've enjoyed being able to network with people from different backgrounds, industries, etc. who help me think more broadly and strategically to source and engage diverse talent for open roles.
cons: As the company grows, there are a lot of moving parts/team and things pivot quickly. So, it's important to remember to not just move fast, but to take the time to always think thoughtfully about the overall goal and the right people to bring along from the onset to be efficient and strategic.

headline: TOXIC - Avoid the SOE Infrastructure organization
pros: Perks and Pay are decent
cons: Lack of career mobility - managers in the SOE (Sourcing Operations and Engineering) in Infrastructure department take it personally if you want to leave their team and explore other opportunities. This department is filled with cliques and politics and god forbid if youre manager does not like you, you will personally be set up to fail. Gaslighting and abuse is rampant in this department evidenced by the rapid turnover and mismatched culture compared to the rest of Facebook. Managers are bullies and not inclusive especially if you do not fit the white, frat boy stereotype. If you do not drink the "kool aid" or atleast pretend to drink it, you will be ostracized. PSC is an ultimate circus and you will be stack ranked with other based on popularity, and leadership's perceptions of you rather than concrete performance measures. You cannot be your authentic self at work. Not my circus not my monkeys
advice_to_mgmt: This is not HP or Cisco, this is Facebook. If you want to hire the best talent and keep them for the long run, you need to 1) allow career mobility and development and not take it personally if people want to leave your team 2) not play favorites and pit team members against each other 3) Set your underlings to fail by not providing enough resources for them to complete their projects.

headline: Great opportunity for ownership and impact
pros:
Facebook is a great place where you can have ownership of your projects and actual impact in the company. At other tech companies, you're a cog in the wheel. At Facebook, you really do have the opportunity to build out the next wave of ideas, strategy, and product.

Facebook has plenty of growth opportunities as the company is still growing, despite the pandemic. New products are being launches every day and each day is a new adventure.
cons: Sometimes leadership makes controversial decisions that the company may not agree with, however they host weekly Q&As with full transparency around their thought process behind the decision, and are open to criticism and feedback. You don't get that at every company and I really respect that leadership is so thoughtful in that way.

headline: Great Experience So Far
pros:
Workload isn't too bad- coming from an MSP, my workload doesn't seem as heavy.
People you are helping are all very nice and friendly. 
Salary, benefits, and perks are incredibly generous. Facebook employees will complain about things that most employees elsewhere couldn't dream of getting.
cons:
Work can sometimes be monotonous, a lot of people have the same issues.

In addition to your work helping others, you are given projects each half to work on- which sometimes feels like you have two jobs (Support Techs are hourly and while overtime is allowed, you sometimes feel you don't have enough time)

Watch the episode of the Simpsons where Homer goes to work for Hank Scorpio. Sometimes it feels a bit like that- would you be comfortable working there?

(Working remotely, you also miss out on the social elements of working in an office... this is not Facebook's fault but due to COVID-19)
advice_to_mgmt: I think some of the values we have as a company need to be extended to the platform. I think it's an issue all social media and large tech faces in this day and age.

headline: Conclusion & Remarks & Qns
pros: ore than ever, our work depends on tools and methods that allow us to share and develop information across the enterprise, with external partners, and the public. Our experience shows us that new uses of interactive technologies have the capacity to expand and strengthen relationships. We continue to make progress engaging the expanding population that lives online, through social media and the increased use of mobile audio and video conferencing technologies. Today’s collaborative tools deliver tailored content and messaging that is available and accessible to Department employees, and shareable to members of the public and foreign audiences.
cons: he Department produces and stores vast amounts of knowledge and data every day. Managing these elements requires centralized knowledge repositories and standard data elements to reduce duplication, facilitate sharing, improve accessibility, and automate workflows among bureaus and offices. Not only will these repositories serve as a portal to shared knowledge, they will expedite our ability to reduce the number of paper-based processes and records. Improving knowledge management will increase our capacity to enable faster retrieval and more accurate results.

headline: Great company to work for and feel pround to be part of
pros: The company really takes good care of the employees. People are constantly looking out for each other and making sure no one feels left along. The company has a very open culture and the management will explain the motivation of a policy and decision in deepth, so that everyone is on the same page and for better buy in. The perks are fantastic -- it surely is the best I have received and I think it might be the best in the local market too.
cons: It is still a very clearly US-central company. For all meetings and townhalls, it is all held in US timing. I have colleagues who is not willing to have meetings after their office hours so they propose timing during Asia sleeping time...
advice_to_mgmt: Be more focus outside US for employees and markets. After all, 90+% of the users are outside of US and Asia is the fastest growing market for the company.

headline: Data Engineer experience at Facebook
pros:
1. Strong infrastructure, similar workflow and data flow among every orgs. Easy to communicate, debug and share experience with other DEs in FB.

2. Top pay for DE among the world and top promotion speed.

3. Good company culture. Very open and free inside the company. Managers are nice. They are helping you and your career, not manipulating you.
cons: Strong infrastructure and data tools solved most tech problems for you. You only need to perform business logic at most time in SQL. Writing too mcuh SQL everyday will let you feel boring. Sometimes even you don't feel you're doing an engineering work.

headline: Going through growing pains but still great employer if you find the right team
pros:
* Excellent compensation and benefits. Takes really good care of its people, from excellent free food to subsidized laundry.
* Lots of unique engineering scale challenges.
* Engineers have a lot of autonomy and decision power.
* Variety of different areas and expanding options in every office.
* Fairly easy to switch teams and even offices / geographical location.
* Great dev infra. Most menial jobs are automated.
* Fast paced and growing - lots of opportunities for career growth.
* Still kept some good things about startup culture like focusing on what matters.
cons:
* It's becoming more corporate with growth - harder to find opportunities that really move the needle, getting more political, more processes, etc.
* With size, discrepancy in culture between orgs is growing. If you land on a bad position it may be harder to switch.
* After negative media cycle on social media, isn't attracting same passionate people as before
* Your friends and even random people will want to tell you how they feel about social media. Some will even blame you for Trump.
* Culture of "move fast" and "focus on impact" taken to the extreme in some orgs which causes lots of incidents, unnecessary stress and terrible codebase.

headline: Left but Returned
pros:
- Best people
- Challenging / interesting work
- A culture that really cares about their people
- There are very few companies that truly let their employees build the future. While our leadership establishes vision and targets - how we get there is left to the employees. We truly believe in the "This is your company now". If you don't like something about FB, come and join us and change it.
cons: - None to think of
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to emphasis expanding different perspectives on the leadership team. Our challenges are a result of us being naive and expecting monolithic behavior. We expected these behaviors because we never imagined our platform would be used to highlight injustice in the world (glad it is!), exploit elections (we are working hard to stop that), and/or sell illegal products. We've have done a tremendous job responding to these unexpected challenges - but if we had more diverse voices / experience making the initial decisions, we could have anticipated them.

headline: Terrible Place to Work
pros: Facebook is run by sociopaths. The only benefit of working here is to improve your resume.
cons: Expect to work 50-70 hours per week on a dumb project. The company always wants you to act with urgency even when the projects are ill conceived.

headline: Very Positive requesting
pros:
- FB has done an incredible job of creating a positive culture. For a company of this size I'm amazed at how supportive everyone is.
- There is a strong culture of competence.
- Lots of room for career growth + guidance from management on how to get there
- Explicit/formulaic bonus structure. It's not having zero ambiguity
cons: There is so much new information coming out every day. If you don't dedicate time to read it (roughly 1 hour per day) you will quickly fall behind

headline: People Focused Company
pros:
I have worked here less than a year so far, but I have loved every minute of it! I joined during COVID and it became clear extremely quickly how much they deeply care about their employees and their well being. Can work-life balance be challenging in a company full of top performers with high performance expectations? Absolutely! But it is really on you to manage your own time and success. There is no pressure from the organization to work after hours and using your PTO and leave options is greatly encouraged. 

I personally love the casual and open culture. When they say "bring your whole self to work" they mean it. Coming from a more traditional company it took a little time to adapt to this as well as to adjust to how people communicate with each other but now I'm hooked. 

The opportunities for continued learning and professional growth seem boundless. They really like to promote from within and there are so many resources for building your career based around what interests you the most.
cons: One challenging aspect is that everyone has an option about Facebook and we are constantly on the news, but that's true of any top company. Recruiters should be used to having tough skin anyways.

headline: Amazing Company!
pros: Great company culture - open, inclusive and caring. Amazing perks and benefits. Lots of talented people with great personalities
cons: New joiners may need more time to get used to the work culture of moving fast and prioritizing ruthlessly

- team is very open to feedback and improving protocol/systems

headline: Amazing
pros:
- Leadership is phenomenal. They truly care about people and have an incredibly strong ethos and value system. 
- The candor and openness of culture (which can be con in trying times - see note below)
- Caliber of talent. I have truly never worked at a company where there is such a high minimum bar for both competence and kindness.
cons:
Given Facebook's historical "move fast" and autonomous culture, there are a lot of byproducts that make it more difficult to work here than you would expect at this size of company:
- Disparate tooling ecosystem and preference for homegrown tools over enterprise tools (which has lots of positives, but in many regards it means reinventing the wheel and bugs)
- Siloed teams working on similar things, but not knowing of or talking to each other

The other main con is information overwhelm. As a social media company, Facebook is in a unique position to influence and have a stake in social issues that have global impact. For better or worse, that means divisive opinions in the world coexist and are surfaced within the walls of the company and all over our internal workplace. It's hard not to get caught up in this and "focus on work" when a lot of what's been surfaced is so deeply engrained in what our product does and/or how our culture should be.

headline: The best place to work!
pros:
- Strong leadership. 
- Plenty of benefits and perks.
- Competitive salaries. 
- Many career resources to help you develop yourself and build a path at the company.
- Working with smart people that add up to your career and job on a daily basis.
- Really strong culture that has stayed that way despite fast and constant growth.
cons:
- Despite having improved, the company is still heavily US and Europe-centric. 
- Reduced growth opportunities if you are not based in the US or some European locations. 
- Constant company growth sometimes translate into ever-increasing complex structures that make your job more difficult.
- Work and life balance is a challenge that is perceived by almost everyone at the company, but felt differently across locations. Offices outside of the US tend to get less headcount and, with that, you might be working longer hours to make sure you're doing everything you need to.
advice_to_mgmt: We should stop the line much, much, much more often. We should also be reminded and encouraged to do so as a company.

headline: Great
pros: Great Teamwork and collaboration. Pivots rapidly

headline: Still a great place working remotely
pros:
- Autonomy. This can be scary at first. You're in charge of your own destiny and nobody will tell you what to do. That doesn't mean your manager isn't there to help you figure this out.
- People. Access to some of the smartest people in the business.
- Access. You can dogfood unreleased Oculus hardware, play with apps only available in other countries. Everyone is keen to get feedback, so you can actually shape their roadmaps.
cons:
- Transparency is waning. There have been so many leaks that the weekly Q&As are less transparent these days, which is a shame because we need it more than ever.
- External cynicism. Most of the reporting out there even from otherwise reputable media organisations is piss-poor and just full of empty rhetoric. That's not only annoying when you work here but bad for the world because this company DOES need to be held to account by the public and you can't do this when everybody is screaming about the equivalent of Hilary's emails.
advice_to_mgmt: Be bold. Take a real stance against racism and fascism.

headline: Good company for growth and learning
pros:

Really solid career growth if you can perform well, the team's are very data driven so it is easy to track goals and understand if you are doing well or not.
cons: Working for a company that is always in the limelight can be quite difficult especially in roles where you always have to interface with external people who might not have a positive view of the company.

headline: Bureaucracy and politics galore
pros:
Salary is top of the industry 
Benefits, food, amenities are top-notch
cons:
Endless bureaucracy - the amount of time spent convincing leadership and XFNs that something is worth doing far exceeds the amount of time spent doing it.

Politics and turf wars - multiple teams are competing for ownership over the same decisions. Directors will employ their teams as pawns to gain turf and evaluate them on their ability to do so.

People treated as competition, not partners - FB will intentionally pit peers to out-do each other, seeing this as a motivational tactic.

Churn and turnover - as priorities, ownership, and methodologies change, those part of the prior regime are cast aside.

Contractor (ab)use - tens of thousands of contractors doing work indistinguishable from FTEs, being paid less and without benefits and fired at the drop of a hat.
advice_to_mgmt: None. Encouraging this behavior has gotten FB to a $750B market cap as of this writing. If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it.

headline: I'm so grateful!
pros: Work-life balance, compensation, learning tools, internal resources, continued education
cons: I'm not a tech guy, so I feel a little lost in some conversations

headline: Big Tech company that's still learning what that means
pros:
- The engineering culture is still very bottom-up: teams generally have a lot of power and responsibility to determine what they work on.
- Internal developer tools are a huge focus. Anything which slows developers down is fixed if possible.
- Very good internal mobility: bootcamp means you have a good deal of leeway in finding a team, and, after a year internal mobility is encouraged.
- Tons of opportunities to make millions of peoples' lives just a little bit better. Like it or not, Facebook's products are used by over a billion people worldwide. There are few places where improvements and fixes can have such a broad reach.
- Lots of intellectual challenges: There are many types of challenges in building products for billions of people: technical (scaling and perf), product (how do you make it useful for everyone), regulatory (how to not fall afoul of privacy regulations), security (how to minimize badness that happens due to the products), and more.
cons:
The biggest challenge facing Facebook right now is that it is simultaneously too big to run the way it runs now (with teams trying to fight for impact and all hacking on the same products), and too small to fit with the well-intentioned goals that Mark has for all of the ways that Facebook can help people.

A company without any strong sense of unifying purpose tends toward bloat and stagnation. It feels like this is the direction Facebook is heading. The amount of infighting between teams around responsibility and ownership of new features is growing and will only keep accelerating.
advice_to_mgmt: Find a way to stop growing exponentially. Start paying out dividends and focus on delivering value to users and advertisers alike.

headline: Great place that cares about employees

It's tough leaving one job for another and but the support that you get, the inclusiveness, and the overall willingness of everyone to help you onboard is honestly a great feeling. It feels like everyone wants you to succeed and that everyone buys into the idea that there's enough sunshine to go around. I've never been at a company with those values.
cons: Onboarding is tough. Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading and playing catch up. Expectations are high to move fast, so join prepared to hit the ground running.

headline: Great & exciting work environment, but progress can still be made!
pros: Much more balanced from a work/life perspective relative to other Bay Area companies. Make sure to provide their employees with competitive salaries to attract top talent. Are interested as a company to pursue new opportunities/technologies and open to exploring new ways of doing things.
cons: A lot of tools still need to be developed to be able to most efficiently do your work. Standards for data storage/files (e.g. Dropbox/Google Drive or Google Sheets/Quip) still need to be solidified as all are in use and it can make it difficult to access information.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to support and value bringing on top talent. Try to strategically reduce the amount of document storage/file solutions and support (and allow time for) projects to improve processes and files to support foundational activities.

headline: The work is rewarding!

cons: It's a company that is very much in the weeds of social and economic challenges. It's a tricky balancing act. It almost doesn't matter what products you work on. Whether you agree or not with what's in the media - you have to be strong and focused in order to do your best work. Bottom line - it's easy to get distracted with it being a company in the middle of so many worldly issues - but this right here is the place to do your most impactful work.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing.

headline: Best company in the world
pros: This company is incredible - from the top down the communication and support system is top notch, transparent, and direct. There is a focus on personal and team growth, and impact. We are working on some seriously difficult problems impacting billions of people, and we are always thinking of ways to evolve and make things better. The negative press in the media, to be frank, is a bunch of bologna. If you are an individual who wants to do work that truly matters, be challenged, felt support, and get paid really well a long with unbelievable benefits and an environment that puts everything in place to help prevent burn out - then Facebook is your place. This company showed their true colors during covid, and they came out proving they are a leader in the industry in every facet of being a major organization.
cons: I have experienced zero cons in my 10 months here so far.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you’re doing, listening to people with empathy and considering all factors that go into this huge and difficult decisions we make as a company. Change doesn’t happen over night, and we are on the right track.

headline: People & Values Focused
pros:
People-first culture, where brilliantly talented people from diverse backgrounds are celebrated & supported.
Impeccable product, business operations and commitment to social good. 
Truly lives & breathes values in daily interactions.
Simply outstanding place to work.
cons: There are challenges that come with working for a mission based company of Facebook's scale, which some may find overwhelming.

headline: Excellent people / inclusive culture
pros: People are really nice. So helpful that its almost unreal. Onboarding even during Covid times where its WFH, the people actually make time for you and are willing to help you with something that may be totally outside his / her area of expertise or JD. Being a large company, it has people from variety of religions, ethnicity, etc., etc., etc., (we cant say enough of those things). However, here it feels all the same. Being different is celebrated and welcomed. Being your own self is the way here.
cons: The company revolves around its people. I feel that could be a downside as people leave at some point. So, its better to have set systems in place. Again, this may not be entirely possible for this company because of the pace at which it moves.
advice_to_mgmt: Not an advise per se but I would suggest continuing to care about your people as that is something not many employers do. It is that fact that stands out for Facebook. May be that is the reason that people love doing what they do here.

headline: Existentially Draining

cons: It constantly feels too political where upper management is making decisions you don’t agree with.

headline: Challenging but Impactful
pros: The work is challenging but impactful. I am given autonomy for the impact my role has. I am around motivated and driven people who at the end of the day strongly believe in the mission. Working remote has been easy to do and I am pleased to see that they will expand this aspect once the world returns to some normalcy. Leadership is transparent and values their people. Excellent benefits. Impactful work.
cons: The company is still growing exponentially, some job openings do not feel strategic. Less than 6 months in and very happy with job, not a lot of cons right now. Ask me in 6 more months.

headline: Best working culture I've experienced in my 20 years career
pros: FB is an excellent workplace for any engineer that wants to collaborate, values colleagues, get things done and work on interesting, innovative projects that actually have an impact on the world. At FB managers don't belong to the elite group and engineers are looked down upon as just worker bees. They don't get in your way, they actually support you in meaningful way. Here at FB you are encourage to be you, best self and you are supported by you peers in you journey of profession and personal development. Best culture I've experienced!
cons: It might not be for everybody, if you are characterized by individualism, conflict producer, avoid ownership and work, with no sense of community.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't change. Continue keeping up the hiring bar and the company values.

headline: Growing during a Pandemic!

-Pandemic wfh lack of interaction to reap some of the culture rewards
advice_to_mgmt: - Better onboarding and support for new hires during this extended remote work period.

headline: Pretty straightforward
pros:
The job expectations and promotion progress feel very transparent at Facebook and I feel that my manager has my best interests in mind. I receive plenty of help from senior engineers and feel that I am progressing well as a programmer.

My team also agrees to work 40hr weeks, which is not what I was expecting before coming here (excluding oncall).
cons:
I work on a ton of refactoring, so having to understand undocumented and poorly written code can be a pain :(

When I am oncall, I can be paged to fix the production service after work hours though I haven't been paged while sleeping yet.

headline: A great place to work!
pros: Great people, innovative environment, flexibility when needed, supportive and fun!
cons: I don't have any to mention

headline: Fantastic Place to Work
pros:
- Salary / Perks
- Culture
- Openness
- Technical Depth
- Autonomy
cons:
- Proprietary Tech
- Competitive
- Political
- Difficult to pursue intellectual interest
advice_to_mgmt: Really, it's tough managing such a place a large company and addressing all the potential issues. Specifically for data engineering though, I would hire people to service in the internal tooling that actually require to use said software in their day-to-day to achieve their role. Also, more headcount per stakeholder -- although, I know that's an issue they've been dealing with for years.

headline: This is by far the best place I have worked
pros: You can tell they work really hard to value you being an actual individual, and that diversity in how we approach things is a good thing as opposed to an everyone is the same approach. The pay is great, and I feel like I have a really good career path. Things are growing really quickly in my field here, and there seems to be quite a bit of space to move up and focus on what I really would like to do. There is free food, and they even gave funds for me to improve my home office. I feel very lucky making it on the team.
cons: Because an open and diverse workforce is encouraged, there is a sense of entitlement in some of the all hands meetings. I haven't felt it in my department, but you can see it come out some times.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up. There really is so much potential to make people's lives better and more connected.

headline: A Great Place to Work

advice_to_mgmt: Maintain the current respect for engineering talent, continue to focus on impact BUT maintain adequate emphasis on long-term impact, not just quarter to quarter or half to half impact

headline: Mixed Feelings
pros: Friendly people, friendly managers. Amazing company and products. Excited to be part of such an amazing organization. Friendly work culture and collaboration environment. Very good infrastructure and tooling. Great perks. Good upper management.
cons: Competitive, stressful and high pressure working environment. Subpar communication. Bottom up management is challenging. Middle level program and project management totally lacking. Communication in a COVID-19 WFH environment challenging when the work culture historically was office based. Instability is normal: releasing to production and taking risks is actively encouraged. The codebase is in places low quality. The majority of the documentation is outdated and therefore unusable. High turnover of staff means little continuity; the only people who stay long enough usually end up so stressed that you have to deal with people barely being able to function due to burnout.

headline: Great company
pros: Empowering, amazing perks, great pay, smart people, employee focused.

advice_to_mgmt: Continue to be kind, even under pressure

headline: Beware the microculture within Facebook
pros: Company aspire to be a leader of change
cons: Micro culture with certain departments or groups can be toxic
advice_to_mgmt: Consider getting rid of the quarterly performance review: it's driving short-term "quick win" culture that result in most reinventing the wheel, becoming territorial and aggressive towards one and another. Consider, instead, annual performance review supplemented with quarterly 360 feedback for each other.

headline: Culture Shock in the Best Way Possible
pros: Amazing communication from the top down. Everyone has access to all of the important information to ensure that work is done.
cons: it can be a little scary coming into such an open culture when viewed from the perspective of other companies, but this isn't a con, it's just a new way to adjust to; especially this new concept called "family" apparently I had reproduced and I get to spend time with them instead of slaving away at work like at previous places that i have worked.

headline: Strong engineering culture with a clear focus on people
pros:
- Stellar coworkers
- Generous compensation and benefits
- Focused on positive work culture and interpersonal skill development (e.g. conflict resolution, giving feedback, inclusiveness)
- Best-in-class engineering systems
- (In most orgs) Less red tape / unnecessary process than Google and Microsoft, for example
cons:
- Association with the Facebook brand can be difficult in elections press cycles
- "Golden handcuffs" : So cushy it's hard to leave

headline: good company to work
pros: I was employed by Basic Solution, but was working at Facebook full time. The company is amazing, it is such a pleasant place to work at. Everyone is supportive, even though if you reach out to them out of the blue. My manager always there for me, and prioritized our needs, and constantly supported system optimization
cons: Facebook depend on contingent work

headline: Great Benefits/Compensation and Compassionate Leadership
pros:
Facebook focuses on giving every employee a voice. I have never worked for a more compassionate and transparent company before.
Pay scales are based on your geographic location as well as experience so you are able to afford to live where you live. 
The health benefits and perks are the better than any other company I have found. 
Promotions are based on ones impact, not tenure, so everyone is hard working and cross functional relationships contribute to your efforts rather than hinder them.
cons:
If not in product development or engineering at times your team can feel like an after thought for issues like mental health concerns when dealing with graphic content and adequate headcount to get the job done. 
Lack of career path and job options for positions outside of engineering.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't forget about the smaller teams that aren't engineers, specifically teams like IRT that deal with graphic content and stressful active emergencies. It's an important job that can often feel unsupported. When developing new products the impact on support teams like legal should be assessed and processes/policies should be put in place before pushing it out.

headline: A great opportunity to work with great people
pros: Having been here for a few months, there is an incredible level of freedom to contribute in many different ways. As a developer if something needs fixing, its gets tabled for fixing. I've been more used to hierarchical approaches to management, so facebook is a refreshing change, allowing me to bring forward many different aspects of my skill set, not just the narrow set defined by my job title. Diverse and welcoming company, offering many opportunities to learn new skills and projects.
cons: Took a little while to get used to the lack of being told what to do. It may seem a bit chaotic at first, but ultimately that is an incredible freedom.

headline: Fantastic company and culture to be part of

Bar the lockdown has been quite severe in terms of cultural setback. Benefits are second to none.
cons: The gargantuan corporation size - Can risk making one feel like a "run-of-the-mill" number employee
advice_to_mgmt: Keep personalising team engagement, as you already do

headline: A great place to work, but a lot of moving fast for no good reason
pros:
Pretty good/ competitive salary 
Excellent health insurance 
Solid name recognition for future jobs
Top notch perks
cons:
Leadership moves from crisis to crisis to crisis. The attention focus is relatively short on the hot issue of the moment and that trickles down to every org. You can be working on the number 1 goal or project from Jan - June and knock it out of the park. Then by July everyone's attention has shifted and your work is no longer relevant. A lot of institutional knowledge is lost this way. 

The company skews young as well, so there are a lot of inexperienced people who want to make their mark/get their promotions and they work hard but don't get the guidance that would help them work smarter. The result is that some teams take "done is better than perfect" and "ask for forgiveness rather than permission" to another level, which can make work tedious. Almost everyone comes from elite schools and has great stats so some really lean in extra hard into making themselves stand out, sometimes in ways that aren't the most useful or healthy. 

There's also a hierarchy Technical people on top, then Business people (cause they make the money) then lawyers then everyone else. People in ops often are at the bottom of the totem pole.

Transferring internally can be especially challenging, as there are no extra considerations for internal hires.
advice_to_mgmt: Incentivize building good products rather than launching things as quickly as possible.

headline: Never met a better job
pros:
I could go on and on, but here are some highlights:

- You'll work with some of the smartest, hardest-working folks on the planet
- People love trying new things and innovating
- Your writing can fly on a mind-blowing scale
- Complex, globally impactful problems will be yours to unravel
- You'll be surrounded by people who truly want you to succeed
- Management can feel downright wholesome at times
- Feedback culture is a real thing
- People talk openly about their mistakes and failures
- Tons of freedom to define your position and move up, around and sideways
- Generous and extremely thoughtful compensation
- They put their money where their mouth is when they say they care about employees
- You can express yourself freely (employees openly disagree with leadership without fear of losing their jobs)
- Lots of very real transparency from leadership
- You can still feel startup vibes even though it's Big Tech
- It's just exciting
cons:
- It moves verrry fast so you'll need to be committed to protecting your time.
- If you need a ton of specific direction and structure, it may not be for you.
- People send you the memes

headline: Pretty great so far!
pros:
- This company espouses some admirable values. And for the most part, the people here really live those values. I am convinced they want to do good in the world, and help each other thrive.
- You are encouraged to find a role which excites you. Your first ~2 months as a software engineer are spent in 'bootcamp', to receive training and to find the team that most interests you.
- Largely engineering driven. Lots of freedom to innovate, if you can.
- The company adapted well, and quickly, to the COVID crisis.
- Fantastic compensation and benefits.
cons:
- Most of the codebase I've seen is messy and badly documented. It is difficult to find what you need and understand what you find. Making an impact requires equal parts software engineering and archeology.
- There is *a lot* to learn w.r.t. internal processes and tools, much of which won't be transferable to other companies. They prepare you for some of it, but not most of it.
- They have only recently begun to take automated testing seriously.
