headline: Amazing for female engineers
pros:
I'm a software engineer who has been at Facebook for almost a year. It is hands down the best place I have ever worked.

To be frank, I didn't have high expectations going in that it would be very different from the misogynistic cultures I've had to navigate at previous companies. 

Before working at Facebook, I'd kind of come to accept that being a female engineer would always be a somewhat isolating existence and the best I could do would be to find a team with 90% great colleagues and just try and avoid the creepy and rude ones as much as possible. I'd seen that as long as they performed well (or held some other utilitarian value for the company) they would always have a place in a company and their treatment of women would be an open secret and accepted.

Honestly, my first couple months at Facebook made me aware of how much effort I'd been spending navigating those types of situations.

It's incredible working with people who assume your competence rather than constantly having to battle to prove yourself.

It's amazing seeing constant efforts towards dissecting internalized biases and senior male employees openly discussing their efforts to catch themselves unconsciously interrupting people. It's laughable to try to imagine this happening at my previous companies.

It's so precious being able to find a place where you can just focus on your work.
cons: It's a long commute for San Franciscans who come down to Menlo Park because we don't have an SF office yet.
advice_to_mgmt: I wish we were less humble and more braggy about the culture here. I didn't realize until working at Facebook how different it was, and I think I would've come sooner if I'd known.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thank you for sharing. We are heartened to hear your experience of working here. Creating a supportive and nurturing workplace is so important and it takes every one of us to keep this place special for all.

headline: Great
pros: Facebook is the greates place to work
cons: There Are No Downsides To Working At Facebook

headline: Product Support Team - Disappointment
pros:
The pros are - 

- The overall company culture
- Good food

I did not find any pro in the product support team. 

I would recommend working at Facebook, but be very aware of which teams you join, the core responsibilities, the manager, the career level your are joining at etc.
cons:
- It was a struggle to spend time in such a monotonous and mundane role. 
- I was sold this role to be a product role, but this is a pure Operations role. 
- Do not be fooled when asked / told about strong analytics required etc, you would most likely end up answer to angsty folks in sales teams and doing customer service.

Please spend your time in a core role, it is where you'd have value in Facebook. It is easy to feel rudderless in this role (no matter what is told to you during your interviews). Employees in non-support / core roles are valued in the company, unfortunately this team and its immediate umbrella organization is not one of them.
advice_to_mgmt: Please place focus on the Managers. Growing a pool of weak and inexperienced managers will lead to poor work experience and affect the amazing culture the company has built. The hiring process is skewed and not properly representative of this role - ensure the managers are held accountable for this.

headline: The Greatest Place to Work
pros:
* Tech lead company
* Engineers control their own destiny
* As an engineer you choose which team you want to work on
* You choose what you pursue
* So many interesting people
* Chance to work with the experts in their fields
* So many interesting projects, from FB itself to autonomous drones, to Oculus to AI, etc. etc.
cons: * Some teams have a lot of travelling (but at least you get to fly business class with a flat bed)
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing and keep Facebook being such an invigorating environment and great place to work.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thank you for sharing. We're happy to hear that you are invigorated by the technical opportunities, autonomy, and community here at Facebook.

headline: Facebook Environment
pros: Friendly environment with best engineers
cons: I think everything is well

headline: Glassdoor is terrific
pros: You meet everybody. It's a great way to meet people. And it's very sociable. I loved working at this place
cons: It's not easy though. You don't know who's real or who's fake. And even though you have a lot of access to a lot of people. You have to keep an open eye.

headline: Love it here

headline: Great place to work
pros: The food is free and always delicious.
cons: Overbearing management needs to let engineers be.
advice_to_mgmt: No more overbearing please

headline: Community Operations Contractor
pros: Position was through PRO Unlimited, Inc. @ Facebook. Great place to work with a lot of in-house perks ... food/drinks etc.
cons:
Training was done by coworkers. You need to get up to speed immediately! Job was very demanding with a high quota to meet. M-F, Weekends and Holidays
Parking was horrible for downtown office location. Or you could take a bus or ride a bike.

headline: Collaborative & Truly Focused on Diverse Thinking to Achieve Mission
pros: FB really embraces bringing different ways of thinking to the work place because it is the right thing to do but also because it makes the work better. They study everything and then to the best thing - if you don't like data, don't come here! All voices are equal & everyone is encouraged to participate in the conversation. In fact, if you don't - that is bad. But be prepared to back up what you say. And know you will get direct feedback on how you can get better, because we all can. Feedback is real and designed to help you get better, not judge you. Overall, an amazing place that moves fast towards a clear mission that everyone in the company is behind. Leadership is open & very strong.
cons: I can't think of any right now. It can be a long commute for some. And it is growing really fast, so construction of new buildings can be loud.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing!
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: We are delighted to hear that you are experiencing the value of feedback and diversity in action. It's people like you, sharing their feedback, who will continue to make us better as we grow.

headline: All good here.
pros: - In FB you work hard but FB also works hard to make you happy.
cons: - Engineering processes can be chaotic due to the rapid growth of the company.

headline: Facebook has become Falsebook
pros: One of the best early stage environments I've ever been privy to.
cons: The company scaled and while doing so the hierarchy that didn't previously exist took over the company.
advice_to_mgmt: Bring the old Facebook back.

headline: Good company, Remote locations suffer
pros: It is one of the best companies to world for. Culture and benefits are amazing.
cons: However, remote locations with less than 100 FTEs suffer.
advice_to_mgmt: Retain your employees. Hire them only if you can keep them

headline: Contractors are and will always be underdogs
pros: Good perks, though moslty for full time employees, great food, office space and culture overall.
cons:
Huge gap between contractors and FTE's, even the badges are different so everybody instantly knows where they belong. No mixing with 'real' Facebookers. 
The company is becoming more corporate and work-life balance is non existant. They make you feel obligated to love FB and consider yourself lucky to be a part of the family. And at the same time they send you emails about contractors eating too many snacks... 
Instead of giving contractors priority when applyig internally, seems like it's even harder for them to get to the company which is crazy considering most contractors work harder and now more than FTE's. They would rather hire a complete outsider and train them from scratch.
advice_to_mgmt: Figure out what do you actually want from employees. A guy from my team was told he is 'too visible' for Facebook?! Google grabbed him after few days :) The other one is not entusiastic enough for the company and he was the most knowledgeable person in the team of 100 people.

headline: Good
pros: Good job it is. Nice work environment
cons: Salaries are not nice .

headline: Great Place to Work but
pros:
- At it's best working at Facebook is fast paced, fun and extremely impactful. I've been given opportunities to work with many great colleagues who care deeply about the work that you're doing and will challenge and encourage you to do better. 
- Support staff at Facebook is amazing whether it be the people who greet you in the morning, facilities, IT, the security guards, chefs, or the the people who work at the gym. Everyone is super friendly and has your best interest at heart. It's like going to work at a 5 Star Hotel every single day :)
- Feedback is taken very seriously and typically acted upon. For example a couple of years ago Facebook didn't offer 4 months paternity leave for employees outside of the US and after receiving feedback from international employees this was policy was expanded globally
- Perks are amazing, free food, gym (or membership for offices without gyms), laundry, great healthcare.
cons:
- Mid-level managers are a hit or miss. I've had 4 different managers in 3 years at Facebook and my experience at work has greatly been dependent on how competent they are. My best manager pushed me and opened doors and was a true advocate for me within the company, whereas my worst manager who was also a first time manager made me feel as if I was working on an island. If you're joining Facebook in a non-tech role you should definitely try your best to get a feel for your future manager.
- As the company has hired over 10K+ people over the past 3 years roles and responsibilities are definitely becoming more specialized and opportunities to drive tangible impact are becoming increasingly difficult for people in junior roles
- Pay and benefits for people working in international offices are not comparable to working at HQ. For example IVF is offered in the US but not non-US offices.
advice_to_mgmt: As Facebook grows and continues to invest in hiring, finding people with prior management experience will be key to retaining and developing talent.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: We appreciate your honest feedback. We'll continue our investment in hiring experienced people managers and developing our existing manager population. We know how important a Manager is to your day to day experience at Facebook.

headline: Can't imagine a better work environment
pros: Learned to code while working at Facebook. Tons of internal mobility. Great culture and values. Mission driven. Everyone is trying to do the right thing.
cons: No cons. Seriously, if you're not trying to work here, reconsider. Unless you can't stand working for a place with great benefits, lots of autonomy and a genuine mission worth caring about. The commute sucks and there's a lot of work, but it's important work worth doing.
advice_to_mgmt: Top management at Facebook focuses in on urgent problems and fixes them. It's really impressive to see them in action

headline: Awesome Company/ Great Employees
pros:
Aside from the countless perks that are literally too long to list out here, one of the best things about this company is it's people. Everyone goes above and beyond to help each other to succeed. It truly is a team effort. 

Upon arriving to the office every morning, everyone from the reception staff to your team says hello to you, and genuinely is interested in your life. People love coming to work every morning and are excited about what they do here every day, and it shows. 

Many companies as competitive as this expect a lot from their employees, and so does Facebook. However, they also encourage a healthy work/ life balance, ensuring their employees are taking enough time off (either by working reasonable hours every day, and/or actually using all of their PTO) to be able to stay fresh and ready to work when at work.
cons: Not many cons to the company. It is a large company, so I guess the biggest con would be you are not going to know everyone at the company. But with how friendly people are, you will make friends in no time!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the awesome transparency! It goes a long way with the employees.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Smart people
Great perks
Employer cares about employees
cons: Too many people trying to solve the same problems

headline: I found my people
pros:
I really feel as though I've found my people.

I've had this dissonance in past roles: ever since academia years ago, I've been out of the "research" phase and into the "engineer at a X company" stage, where "X" is occasionally a software product but more often a service or commercial product. The culture was not one of making the right things, but making the profitable thing now. Driven by sales people, there was a lot of grandstanding, peacocking, both in the culture and in the message.

Facebook has my people, my culture. We do things in the way that scales and makes engineering sense. Sure, perfect is the enemy of good enough, but if a temporary shortcut remediates a problem or a need, it's quickly iterated to improve, all the while immersed in a tech culture: Pusheen, Archer, Dr Who, Starwars, memes, the micro-actions that continually reinforce a culture-fit or a culture-miss.

I'm in the culture fit. Sure, I get a very competitive salary, plus my tech chops improve (when C++ gurus review your work, your C++ quality improves), and the food, and the perks, but above all, this is the place I feel I most fit.

I'm in my mid-40s. I "get schooled" my mid-20s. ...and it's awesome.
cons: Pace is a killer. The work is complex, as are the discussions about it, I have little fuel in my head to code after work. Big personal desire to keep up to the more efficient engineers. I don't want to pass-a-fault, but want to move-fast, get all the things done. It's exhausting!
advice_to_mgmt:
Open a highschool.

We have hired so many of the good people, the recruiting funnel is sparse. We need to grow our engineers. Open a high school to get right-of-first-refusal :)

headline: I couldn't imagine a better place to start my career
pros:
+ Tremendous autonomy: It is still very much a culture where you are expected to find impact and deliver.
+ Fast paced culture: Very few people try to stop you from getting things done. Everyone values the benefits of iteration
+ Easy internal mobility: No interview, no BS. Everything was decided in a day for me.
+ Great perks: Comp, food, office space, healthcare, you name it!
+ Exciting work: Facebook is building everything from social media to VR, React to airplanes.
cons:
- Tremendous autonomy: It REALLY is up to you.
- Size: Definitely feels big if you are trying to meet new people.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thanks for sharing! We're glad to hear that you are enjoying career growth and autonomy here at Facebook. Thank you for all you do to support our mission of making the world more open and connected.

headline: Great company
pros:
Great mission and culture
Great people
Great perks
cons: Very flat org = hard to move into management
advice_to_mgmt: Help employees develop career plans

headline: Poor Work Culture
pros:
- Extremely talented staff
- Excellent development environment
- Strong feedback in code reviews
- Flexible work location
- Convenient services provided (shuttles, food, laundry, gym, etc)
cons:
- Terrible work life balance
- Myopic semiannual performance reviews (straight up Hunger Games)
- No vision or direction for products 
- Competitive and poorly adjusted coworkers (the average engineer is very strange)
advice_to_mgmt: Don't allow people with very limited work experience to become managers. All of my managers were terrible, had extremely limited vision, and could not keep the team cohesive and motivated.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: We appreciate your feedback. Taking care of our people is a top priority and as we grow and scale, we will continue to invest significantly in growing the company's future leaders.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Move fast, exciting project. Bottom up culture that make things interesting and possible

response: We appreciate your honest feedback. We appreciate your patience while we address the challenges of our growing and thriving campus. We'll keep moving fast to make this happen!

headline: Life-Changing Opportunity/Environment. Really Underrated in the Valley, IMO...
pros:
There are an endless amount of pros about working at Facebook. If I were to pick one pro out of all of them - it's the people. Whatever you heard or read about Facebook really doesn't give the place enough credit. I'm not in HR/recruiting or even management, but I do see a common trend in everyone they bring on board. Everyone is smart, motivated, non-judgemental, and freakishly CARING. There are so many people with heart at FB.

To be honest, you can be one heck of a coder, but if you're selfish - I don't think you will get hired here. I've previously worked at Google and MSFT; FB blows both of them out of the water (maybe I'm a little biased). Other pro's of course are... 

+ Free world class food options all day long on the main campus cafeteria (MPK 20/21).This includes great snacks/drink options everywhere else as well. 
+ Fantastic PPO/HMO health care options. The premiums are very reasonable.
+ Resources. They will give you everything you need so you can do an amazing job - period. Hardware, software, etc... 
+ Did I mention the people? :)
cons: FB (especially MPK) is expanding very fast. Things get unorganized and chaotic. Communicating with colleagues in international branch offices can be tricky.
advice_to_mgmt: At the end of the day, we spend most of our time with the people we work with. Keep bringing on great, empathic people. I really think it has transformed the culture (in a super duper positive way).
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thanks so much for sharing your experience. Mark and Sheryl, along with the Facebook leadership team continue to set this example for us by "walking the talk." We are building a different kind of company here, thank you for recognizing and reinforcing the practice of "shipping love."

headline: Great place to work if you want challenges
pros:
Opportunity to choose projects that you are excited about. Projects are driven from bottom up, with leaders just giving advice rather than orders. 
everyone is really smart but humble, the culture lacks office politics, amazing company leaders

headline: Not easy but worth it
pros:
The scale, with over a billion user worldwide wide, you would be hard pressed to find another company with the reach and impact that Facebook has. 
Its a design led organization: Designers do way more than just make things pretty. They drive product road maps, craft and execute at a very high level, and collaborate cross functionally.
cons: You will feel overwhelmed when you first start. That feeling will subside. At facebook you will have the best resources and support to help you ramp-up.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to listen to your employees.

headline: Autonomy, impact yet political

headline: Great place; stagnated growth
pros: The perks are unbeatable and it's a great place to start a career, learn how to function in a fast-paced environment, and learn the principles of work/life balance.
cons: I experienced stagnated growth. Internal mobility was hard, especially for those of us who were high performers.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't just say that you want to grow your people, actually help them find opportunities to stay with the company and grow beyond their current roles.

headline: FBU Intern
pros: Great company culture and loved Mark Zuckerberg's transparency with all employees
cons: Facebook claims to be very open-minded but it's definitely liberal and I would say that conservative values or ideas clash with the culture
advice_to_mgmt: Everything was great - I can't think of any feedback right now.

headline: High Rewward - High Stress
pros: Lean Teams, Great People, Fast Career Growth, Transparent Enviroment, Great recognition systems, Numerous learning opportunities
cons: Ambiguity in majority of tasks, High Stress, Bubbly and at times noisy environment, big chunk of work success is based solely on the connections made within the company, inconsistent people management
advice_to_mgmt: Consistency in people management is required on all levels
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: We appreciate your open and honest feedback. We agree that people managers play a very important role at Facebook. We will continue to invest in developing our people managers across the teams.

headline: Amazing Company, Leadership, Employees and Opportunity
pros: Facebook is truly a best-in-class company. They hire the brightest people. The leadership is truly transparent and addresses any new projects or ongoing concerns. The perks are amazing and the opportunity for growth are endless. I love it here
cons: The company is growing quickly and offices are getting crowded.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing! The great leadership has helped this company recruit and grow!

headline: 5 Years @ Facebook
pros:
Benefits
Flexible Work Schedule
Intelligent & Motivated Coworkers
cons: As Facebook gets larger there is more middle management and more political bs

headline: A 100% real Great Place To Work!
pros: Mission, Culture and Benefits are the best!
cons: The main challenge is the Traffic during rush hours!

headline: Best job/company I will ever work for. Hands down.
pros:
The list of pros is endless: 
- Company culture (they don't just talk the talk - the culture really IS as good as it sounds, if not better)
- The most brilliant people in the world are your coworkers and friends
- Amazing managers and management philosophy
- Endless opportunities to grow, learn, stretch, move around, change, and to have impact
- Best perks you'll ever find (amazing benefits, pto, parental leave, food, wellness, the list goes on)
- Incredible leaders (Mark, Sheryl, Schrep, etc) with visions for the future and love for what they do
- Facebook TRULY cares about its people above all else

I could go on and on - Its the #1 place to work for a reason.
cons: None really that I can think of. I mean it. Everything I could say as a con really ends up being neutral or positive in one way or another. Manage your time well, find balance in your life, and be a champion of your own career and you will be fine.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros:
+ best company in the world
+ amazing offices
+ super friendly, super talented colleagues
+ clear, actionable mission
cons: - it's bigger than it used to be, but that's not such a con as it's still fast moving
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing, it's an unbeatable culture
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thank you for your service! We will keep working to hire people who care deeply about our mission to connect the world!

headline: Best company I've ever worked experienced
pros:
Very progressive in conducting business and cultyre. The company encourages feedback, so management is not only receptive, but also very responsive in changing if it is warranted. The company breeds entrepreneurs and autonomy. Leadership is as transparent as I've seen any business be (big and small), and really takes care of its people first. 
I've worked at and for dozens of companies and clients who are "progressive", "exciting", "innovative", and no one compares to FB.
cons: There are so many opportunities, it's hard to know what your career path might be. It's an extremely competitive company based on the caliber of talent at the company. Life/work balance is encouraged and supported, however it's up to the Employee to make it happen...and if others don't, it's hard to keep up if you aren't as efficient.

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
Competitive compensation package if you join the company at the right time (when stock price is low.) Otherwise it won't be too attractive unless you are E5.

Lots of things to learn in the company, good benefit.

If you can get a management role, you will be in haven. Most of the managers their life is very very easy, they only need to care about their team don't get downsize in the political wrestling.
cons:
Manager's turn over rate is too high. I got 8 different manager in three year. Some area got lots of politics, watch who is the head of that department. 

Instagram, Messenger has pretty bad culture at this moment. 

Literally no life when you want to get good perf review ratings.
advice_to_mgmt: Fire those manager who doesn't have good pulse review. Don't keep bring lots of manager from outside especially from those company which culture is bad. They bring the bad culture into the company as well. (e.g. Yahoo at this stage)

headline: Becoming Google
pros:
- Great benefits - free food, fully covered health, dental, vision
- External partners want to work with you - easy to make deals, get great rates from vendors
- Attracts talented people
cons:
- Consistently under-resourced for what we're expected to deliver 
- Inconsistent leadership - people put in charge of marketing teams who have never been a marketer 
- Extreme hierarchy - the business side of the organization is not flat 
- Two cultures - the public culture you hear about exists on the product side of the organization, not the sales and marketing org.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to keep the talent bar high and keep the culture strong

The perks are magestic, not just free food but gourmet meals served 3 times a day, it will ruin hotels for you!! You feel like your making a difference constantly.
cons: Busy busy environment but I like that so not a con for me!! You cannot get away with being lazy
advice_to_mgmt: Maybe to sync more across regions outside of review time.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros: Culture is carefully engineered to be a great place to work. Engineers are given great benefits and compensation, a lot of autonomy, and a lot of resources to grow.
cons: Very few, as long as you diligently maintain your own work-life boundaries.

headline: High performance but not high pressure environment
pros: It's a great environment; high performance but you don't feel too much pressure. Great middle management and friendly interactions with other teams. Working from home is an actual options for at least 1 day per week (no meetings Wednesday).
cons: The usual cons of working in a remote office several time zones away from the mother ships: you get to have sometimes meetings in the evenings and need to chat with people at times which might be uncomfortable.
advice_to_mgmt: Cigna is a bad benefit provider; dump them and find someone who actually answers the phone.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: We appreciate you taking the time to provide this feedback. We'll share this information regarding Cigna to the relevant program managers so they can take action re: service.

headline: good, fun place to work
pros: great food, smart people, you don't take your work home with you
cons: pay could be better, fairly corporate atmosphere

headline: Great contractor experience!
pros: Great contractor benefits such as shuttle transportation from the city, and a variety of food and snack options to fit any diet. You can also get involved in the many diverse social and sports clubs, and meet other employees that way. The Menlo Park campus is beautiful, and Facebook provides a variety of facilities and spaces for employees even when they're not working.
cons: It's not particularly easy to transfer teams or move up as an entry-level contractor, unless you have the right skills — or happen to meet the right people. There are also restrictions to certain benefits and activities, but it's definitely not a make or break situation.

headline: Human Resources Fail
pros:
Globally it is a good company to work at, great mission and vision and strong values. 
There are some good communication channels to expose problems.
Strong encouragement and support to give their employees a healthy work-life balance.
cons:
The values do not apply in GMS (Sales teams) and even less in regions that are not in US.
The LatinAmerican management is irresponsible. There are problems in each country in terms of compensation and growth opportunities. 
The worst experience is the recruiting process with tons of promises through the phone and they are not able to send you a written offer until you have accepted & signed online. After your first paycheck you notice that they didn't get all the benefits that were promised through the phone, because "they couldn't write it on the contract where you could only see your yearly compensation" "because they were local benefits". 
Salary payment processes are outsourced and unmanaged by internal teams, resulting on taxing issues and each country's inflation and devaluation affecting the life quality of the employees by not being able to adjust the salaries when all living costs have dramatically increased.
The local management teams are not receptive on the employees concerns. 
In each region; salaries and seniority levels are given not by real performance or experience but by relationships.
There is retaliation on complains, there have been open "advices" to avoid complaining. 
This is worrying for a company with the open culture like Facebook.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay attention to your team's local concerns.

headline: Amazing Company
pros:
+ Culture
+ Benefits
+ Resources
+ Career Development
+ Work/Life Balance
cons: - The commute from SF to Menlo Park

headline: Director, Customer Insights
pros: Great opportunities, lots of perks, A teams!
cons: Long hours, cut throat culture

headline: Awesome culture
pros: Amazing inclusive, open, honest, caring culture. Perks are amazing (free gourmet food, 4-months paid parental leave, $$ for gym/fitness activities you can use for ski passes), no shortage of interesting problems to solve, working with wickedly smart people is also great. Inspiring weekly Q&As with Zuck and sometimes Sheryl.
cons: Pressure to move fast. Work life balance could be better.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thanks for sharing. Taking care of our people so they can focus on moving fast is vital in making the world more open and connected. We'll share this with our internal teams to continue improving.

headline: Technical Recruiter, Leadership
pros: My manager and team are phenomenal. Everyone I have gotten to work is brilliant, respectful, courteous, helpful and fun to be around. The mission at Facebook is motivating and speaks the truth about the culture.
cons: This company is very fast-paced. If you are not willing to put in the work and time, you will fall behind. You need to be self-sufficient to be successful here.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work. Would love to hear you speak more on campus. I am completely motivated by you!

headline: Overrated
pros:
Great culture.
Free food, good benefits.
cons:
Salary is insufficient to make a proper living.
Very little career development.
advice_to_mgmt: Employees are an asset not something you can squeeze.

headline: Kickass company
pros: An amazing company to work for offering a plethora of opportunities. Transparent and no BS.
cons: Need to maintain a high energy all the time. Hard for introverts to work at.
advice_to_mgmt: Need to take long term strategic decisions

headline: Love this company
pros:
-Great benefits (free food, free insurance, free accounts like Care.com and Dropbox)
-Flexible schedules
-401k matching
-stocks and bonuses
cons:
-growing too fast for space
-a little disorganized sometimes because everyone moves so fast

headline: facebook
pros: benefits, culture, flexibility, people are the key benefits
cons: crowded, some work-life balance issues, not as transparent as expounded.

headline: Great Place and co-workers
pros: Co-workers are great and culture is the best in Silicon Valley.
cons: Continue to reward employees with more stock.

headline: What do you think?
pros: The work life balance was great! Worked with tons brilliant engineers and project managers!
cons: Hard to be heard as an individual.
advice_to_mgmt: Take extra time to care for your employee's opinions.

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
Awesome free food (3 times a day high quality breakfast, lunch and dinner, made fresh from scratch with organic ingredients)
Smart and driven people to work with
Insane compensation (mind blowing!)
A strong culture of fairness
Strong bottom-up work culture
Impact driven, much less politics than other companies
cons: Intense environment, highly demanding, but also highly rewarding
advice_to_mgmt: Top priority must be to retain this culture as the company grows.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thanks for sharing. We're proud of our people, the way we work and the opportunities there are here to have an impact. We're happy that you are thriving at the intersection of it all. Caring for and supporting the best parts of our culture will continue to be a top priority for us as we grow. Thanks for your advice.

headline: Best company
pros: Autonomy, mission, food, people, quality
cons: There aren't very many cons, especially compared to other companies.

headline: Good place to develop.
pros: Free culture, flexible time, bright future.
cons: Has no enough increasing space.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Facebook is truly a mission driven company and genuinely cares about its users. Day in and day out, you live by your values and see leadership living by them
cons: Things could be chaotic at times

headline: Amazing place to work
pros: Company culture, opportunity for impact, deal with engineer problems at a unique scale and benefits.
cons: Intense and fast-paced environment. (can be a good thing, but definitely not for all)

headline: Everything you could want from an employer
pros: Industry leading benefits, a great office and total package is very competetive
cons:
Role definitions are sometimes a bit vague - but leaves scope to define your own role
Base pay is not particularly competitive but made up in stock and bonuses

headline: I love working for Facebook
pros: work environment, pay, smart ppl to work with, work life balance, added perks
cons: It's as good as it can be!!!

headline: Market Lead
pros: Amazing company to work for. Great values, support of their employees and overall company mission.
cons: Expect more clear career growth path
advice_to_mgmt: Better career growth guidance
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thanks for sharing your feedback. We're glad to hear you are enjoying your Facebook experience. We want people to play to their strengths– doing what you're both good at and most energized by. While we have learning and development courses to help guide career conversations with your lead, please feel free to reach out directly to your HR Business Partner, as well, for additional support.

headline: Happiest I've Ever Been
pros: Facebook is a truly incredible company. Sure, they give you three meals a day, crazy benefits, and all those bells and whistles, but I would recommend this company to anyone 1000 times over even without all that stuff. People leadership is best in class, things here move REALLY quickly, and internally it feels more like a startup rather than a massive corporation. I feel more connected to our C-level team than I have at any other company, probably because they are so open and transparent about their decisions.
cons: If you can't deal with ambiguity then you probably shouldn't apply. We move fast, and managers aren't super prescriptive about daily tasks and responsibility. Everyone takes ownership of their own time, which is great, but I imagine some people would struggle with that.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing.

headline: Best In Tech
pros:
* Smart coworkers - some of the best in the world
* Amazing perks 
* Incredible product 
* Many opportunities
cons: * Some entitled coworkers - lots of younger people whose first job is at the best company in the world

headline: Amazing opportunity to impact the world
pros: Top talent not just in engineering but across the company in all areas. The culture is very inspiring and motivating and keeps me excited every single day. On top of that I get to work on problems on a scale that is hard to find anywhere else in the world.
cons:
Being able to choose the way you have impact on Facebook's mission is very liberating but also imposes a lot of pressure on every single individual. You have to prove every half that you are worth the investment Facebook makes into its people.

The London office certainly has a smaller selection of teams than California. And knowing that you would make significantly more money across the pond is also awkward.
advice_to_mgmt: Be bolder. In the last months we seem to be too scared of rubbing people the wrong way. We shouldn't back down from things we know are the right things to do.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thank you for sharing. We agree that we never want to forget our core value of being BOLD. We are so excited about the continued growth in London, already a dynamic hub for cross-functional teams and projects. Our global offices are core to our mission-driven work of connecting the world.

headline: Facebook is amazing
pros: They really care about you. Flexible about working from home.
cons: Location of the office (very hard to get to)

headline: Contractor at Facebook
pros: Flexible, good work/life balance, free meals is a plus.
cons: Contractors treated as second class citizens compared to full time employees.
advice_to_mgmt: Need to be more communicative with teams

headline: Good situation
pros: Good place to work. Treats you well.
cons: Not much. Maybe a little too Silicon Valley.

headline: Wrote the news, was replaced by algorithm
pros: Laid back, welcoming to young people
cons: Was easily replaced in poor company decision
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the real people

headline: Total rocket ship!
pros: Great perks, generous vacation, clear promotion process
cons: Work life balance is very difficult to maintain

headline: High growth brings lots of opportunity
pros:
The working environment
The people
The level of growth means there is lots of challenging work to do
Flexibility with working hours & possible to work from home when needed
A good place for working parents
Fantastic benefits & perks
cons: If you are focused on job titles & climbing a corporate ladder it's not like that at facebook. Career growth & promotion is possible but the structure is quite flat. You don't need to take the people management route to get ahead. You can choose the individual contributor route & become an expert in your space.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep training new people managers to ensure they have the right skills as teams grow.

headline: Phenomenal
pros: The people, the mission, the way the company respects its employees. Everyone here is super pumped about work, but in a way where team work is prioritized over individual ambitions.
cons: Things move fast and change a lot. Products can get scrapped very quickly if early evidence shows negative metrics. This can somewhat be discouraging to the people working on it, however, is, many times, understandably a necessity.
advice_to_mgmt: Add more structure to project execution

headline: Facebook
pros: Good salary, culture, benefits, business prospects
cons: I cannot name a single one

headline: If it stays like this, I may never leave
pros:
The culture here is truly like nowhere else on the planet. Any company can pay lip service to things like collaboration, fun, caring about people, wanting you to feel comfortable at work, building community, etc. But having an open and honest environment at our size is one of the hardest things to do, and yet Facebook seems to do it so effortlessly. I love coming into work every day because I know I'll be challenged in the right ways, I'll embrace hard conversations because I know we're all working to the shared mission, and I know that everyone leaves their ego at the door without other agendas. It's truly magical and like nowhere else in the world. 

Also, you get used to it after a while, but the perks are out of this world. I never worry about much of anything in my personal life because Facebook takes such good care of us.
cons: Facebook's size means your scope of work may not be as broad as it was at a 5-person startup. However, most days I see that as a positive because we get to masterfully execute our day-to-day and we're growing a lot.
advice_to_mgmt: As you're already doing, keep prioritizing the culture first and foremost when we add so many new people.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: We are glad to hear that you are enjoying the experience of working at Facebook. Our mission-driven company is a direct result of everyone deeply caring about Facebook and each other. As we continue to scale and grow, we will keep watch over our culture and continue to nurture it together with individuals like yourself.

headline: Very positive
pros: Good culture, awesome co-workes, smart management
cons: No real cons, great opportunity

headline: Great Culture and great products
pros: Compensation, Mission, People, Culture and Product. We can also add awesome offices location and perks.
cons: It can be pretty easy to lose track of reality. Sadly the vast majority of companies don't offer the same environment.

headline: I'm a Creative Shop Strategist and I love my job.
pros:
- Working with smart, passionate, driven people.
- Working towards a collective issue.
- Working for incredible, transparent leaders (Zuck and Sheryl are amazing)
- The perks. Oh my god, the perks. Your quality of life is just better when you work for Facebook.
- The future.
cons: - Work/Life balance could be better.
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thanks for your feedback. We're so glad to hear you love what you do and the experience of working at Facebook. As for work/life integration, we are here to support with conveniences and services to help. If you need additional support, please do reach out to your HR Business Partner.

headline: Facebook is an awesome place to work
pros:
Engineers are treated as first class citizens
Lots of perks
Good work environment
Othee employees are friendly and helpful
cons:
I work quite a lot
Work-life balance is not that good (it is not really bad either)

headline: It's the best company in the world
pros: I joined Facebook about four years ago and it's by far the best thing that wever happened to me. Every day I'm challenged to do what I do best, while driving impact and (in)directly contributing to the overall mission of making the world more open & connected. What I also love is that jobs and structures are created around a person and not vice versa. Yes thing move fast, change quickly, shift around but you get the trust and comfort to make impact. It all comes down to taking ownership.
cons: The lean structure and importance of individual contributors have created a structure where ownership is key. You don't always get guidance on what or how to do things. For some people this might not work.

headline: Software Engineer III
pros: Very good work environment, work content.
cons: Bay Area is very expensive

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
1) The only metric we're measured on is "impact". This feels completely fair to me. It also means you get to pick your own hours as long as you get some impactful things done and you're still in sync with all of the other people on your project.
2) It's easy for engineers to switch teams. That means you don't need to know what you enjoy working on before you join and you can't get stuck with a bad manager.
3) New York-specific: the company is in East Village, which means you can live in the most exciting part of the city AND have the luxury of walking to work.
4) I think Facebook's company history is interesting.
5) Facebook's language infrastructure is phenomenal. Its PHP and Javascript is type-checked, which makes it so much easier to read without typeof checks everywhere.
cons: 1) New York-specific: There's about 15 different engineering teams to choose from, which can be a deal breaker if your heart is already set on a particular team we don't have.

headline: Best case scenario
pros: Fast moving, exciting, smart groups of people. The products are amazing for consumers and businesses. I honestly never thought I'd be one of these people saying the most positive review on Glassdoor but I am honestly blown away with how genuinely great Facebook has been the first 6 months.
cons: There is some feeling of imposter syndrome because most are really really talented, but it only makes you better by being around such talent.
advice_to_mgmt: Reduce the noise of inputs of information, consolidate thing so prioritizing is more stream lined.

headline: People Based Company
pros: Being part of a company that is helping connect the world, not just people but connecting and growing businesses. You are surrounded by not only some of the most innovative intelligent people, but people that want you to succeed which develops a very supportive environment. Great benefits, growth and career opportunities (globally not just in the US)
cons: Most roles are Full Time (5 days a week) due to the teams being lean. Limited options for those looking for 3/4 day positions.
advice_to_mgmt: Teams are lean - You need to be able to Manager and develop your team but also be hands on.

headline: One of the best places to work
pros: work-life balance, great food, beautiful campus, great people, diverse workforce
cons: meeting rooms are scarcely available

headline: Rapidly Growing, Great Benefits
pros:
- The company is strengths-focused, so they want you to follow your passion.
- Lots of amazing benefits
cons: Company is growing so quickly, it's going to be hard to maintain a close community feel as it grows & scales.

headline: A great place to work
pros: There are some of the best talents in the area. Challenging problems and good career opportunities.
cons: There is no food on weekends.

headline: Great corporate vision
pros:
Great smart people
Great perks
Great diversity
Free food
Management moves fast and react fast
Open culture and code
cons:
Some smart people can be rather snobbish
Actually heard "what's ROI" from a engineer
Disconnect from Eng vs rest
advice_to_mgmt: Run a mini-business course during boot camp and a mini-Eng course for business side. It's not a eng vs business. Reorganization are scary if not handled properly.

headline: Recruiting Coordinator
pros: transparency, benefits, culture, projects, team outtings, shuttles, food
cons: company is growing, so there's some growing pains (moving, etc.)

headline: Happy researcher
pros:
Fast moving
Great benefits
Work independence
Good colleagues
cons:
Ambiguity in roles
Struggling to define themselves

headline: Awesome colleagues
pros: I'm learning a lot from the people I work with, both technical and soft skills.
cons: Large company, teams doing overlapping work across timezones. Difficult to coordinate.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep coaching your reports so we can keep improving

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros: People who are truly passionate about the work they are doing and actively believe that a more open and connected world is a better one. Consistently encouraged to stretch and take on more responsibilities.
cons: Company is scaling very very quickly, so there are some growing pains associated with that - I do not believe these are serious or will be long term issues.
advice_to_mgmt: keep doing what you're doing!

headline: Associate
pros:
Amazing benefits and culture
Full of diversed and smart people
cons: No specific con to mention

headline: Market development lead
pros:
- It's all pros - the people I work with are the sort of people I would choose as friends anyway
- Everyone is super smart, super humble, genuine and really friendly
- Unlike other big companies where you become blocked by processes, Facebook lives by its move fast mantra and new innovations in products happen all the time
- The free food is ridiculous, it's 7 star quality, absolutely delicious 100% of the time 
- There are lots of career progression opportunities because we keep growing 
- There is never a dull day and our sales conferences and all hands sessions are inspiring
- You get to test new products before they go out on the market 
- Rewards for good performance are fantastic
cons: Nothing! This is the longest I have been in any company and I feel as happy today as the first day I walked in.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Keep doing what you are doing
- Mark Zuckerburg is a genius and a world thought leader and all his management team are top class

headline: Incredible company raising the bar when it comes to taking care of employees
pros:
Working with the smartest people
A vision led company 
All the food!
The benefits package 
Competitive comp
International opportunities
cons: There are honestly very few. Facebook is a growing company and that runs the risk of losing its culture
advice_to_mgmt: Keep teams small and lean. Continue to recognise individual achievement. Don't rest on your laurels!

headline: Incredibly Empowering
pros:
You have an amazing level of freedom in deciding what team you want to work on and what you want to do within that team. It is your responsibility to decide how you want to generate value for the company.

Also the compensation and benefits are amazing.
cons: You are measured based on results achieved, not on how hard you try. I think of this as a Pro, but I know a number of people find it to be a Con.

headline: Media Solutions Manager
pros: Smart people are a blessing to work around
cons: Sales Org Politics can be difficult to manage

headline: Great culture
pros:
- Fast shipping
- Smart people
- On point strategy
- Transparency
cons: - High bar for success

headline: How its like to work for Facebook
pros:
1. Great energy
2. Highly motivated folks
3. Good work
4. Connecting the world literally
5. Awesome perks
6. Decent salary
cons: 1. Little bit distraction because of so many awesome things around

headline: Working at Facebook is very fulfilling
pros: Very flat org structure, you get to decide on projects and direction directly with your fellow engineers. Great people (this is the first place where i was able to learn from others), great perks and pay, everybody is onboard with the company's mission.
cons: The office is in menlo park - pretty far from SF

headline: Best company I've ever worked for
pros:
Amazing culture.
Awesome management. 
Opportunities to grow. 
Ability to work on stuff I actually care about. 
Great benefits.
cons: Company has grown a lot. I joined in 2014 when everyone was on one campus. Now there are a lot of buildings.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing. Allow people to work on things they care about.

headline: Production Engineering
pros:
Huge breadth and depth you can choose to work in
mix of feature development and ops work, free to focus on either or both.
scale of systems is truly enormous
cons:
Work life balance varies widely between teams.
some teams PE works with can be filled with divas.

headline: Its Great
pros: culture, coworkers, benefits, fun, money
cons: management can be sort of bad at times

headline: Market specialist
pros: Great perks, working hours and environment pretty flexible, people are really friendly and most if them can teach you a lot. Also everything you do affects a lot of people and it's quite an amazing feeling to see that.
cons: It's an "engineering first" company. So when you're working for an operations department and your work gets overlooked it can be a bit frustrating.
advice_to_mgmt: Not much at this point. It's an amazing company for it's size and I appreciate M teams efforts keeping it this way for this long.

headline: 6 months in
pros:
Motivated teammates. Everyone is willing to help out.
Wonderful campus with plenty of perks: free food, onsite health and dental, lots of green space
Leadership is transparent and cares about employee needs
cons:
Things move quickly. It can be difficult to keep up with the changes.
There is always more work to do.
Public sentiment of Facebook is not always great. Many people seem to think Facebook is evil, but internally nothing seems further from the truth.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus more on marketing the Facebook brand. We need people to understand how hard we work to be a positive influence.

headline: Incredible place to be; not incredible place to grow
pros:
* Culture there is positively amazing, and it believed and lived. Consistent throughout offices around the world--a rarity.
* Benefits are world-class
* Mission driven--everyone believes in it
* Zuck is fantastic
cons: * At this point in the organization's life they are more inclined to hire managers from outside instead of promoting from within. Many employees have been burned by violated expectations around this. Therefore, no longer a great place to get new responsibilities quickly--you kind of just stay in place as the pyramid grows around you
advice_to_mgmt: Ambitious people that want to perform big and be rewarded for it are increasingly turned off by your outside hire strategy.

headline: Great place to work at
pros: There is a lot of flexibility, freedom, focus on impact, access to the greatest minds in the field. Lots of perks, benefits, it's almost hard to take advantage of all of them since they are so many. Like is just great when working here.
cons: Too much free food? Not really. I don't know, maybe just that it's not a start up anymore, so you won't have the chance to become a multimillionaire quickly.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Awesome company. Tons of opportunities and challenges. Best compensation and culture in the industry.
cons: Every engineer, regardless of level, works more independently than most other companies, which can be a challenge for people fresh out of college with no industry experience.

headline: A wonderful place to be!
pros: People really care about you
cons: It will ruin all other employers for you

headline: Culture
pros: It matters: Facebook puts a premium of its people and the culture. It means people will treat you with respect and listen to your thoughts.
cons: Culture comes first. While we are all encouraged to be our authentic self, if your authentic self is an butt hole, don't bother applying. Sometimes we put feeling ahead of actions as we work through the culture piece. Overall, it is a great way to operate.

headline: Amazing
pros: It was amazing! there is so to do and the only thing is, they have really god pay for the job do. I highly rate it!
cons: There is non. honestly the best company i have ever been to and worked at. highly recommend this amazing work place

headline: Amazing place to work
pros:
- great mentorship
- many opportunities to grow
- challenging
- a lot of benefits
cons:
- extremely high expectations
- stressful
- heard stories of many interns crying during the internship
advice_to_mgmt:
- maybe put more time into team allocation
- keep up with the amazing work enironment
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thank you for choosing to intern at Facebook. We greatly value your time, energy and skills. Taking care of our interns and supporting them so they can have meaningful and rewarding experiences is something we value deeply. We'll share your feedback with our internal teams to further improve the program.

headline: Simply the Best
pros: I have never been more proud of the company I work for. Not only does Facebook take great care of its employees, it also takes care of the people that use its products. The values instilled within the company are the values that are projected. I'm constantly excited to go to work, learn and I look forward to the challenges ahead.
cons: I'm sure there are downsides. But I've been employed here full-time for quite a while and have yet to see any.
advice_to_mgmt: The management team is great at being transparent. And setting up peers and contributors to be successful in their roles.

headline: First company
pros: interesting projects, have sth for all sorts of people
cons: traffic jam from / to company

headline: Fantastic company to work for
pros: I absolutely loved my time at Facebook. I was lucky enough to work with talented, passionate, knowledgeable people who were super supportive and friendly. You're positively encouraged to express your ideas and trusted to work autonomously. The work is challenging and interesting and the social aspect is great too; there's always something to get involved with should you want to. They provide free breakfast, lunch and dinner which is pretty amazing. Despite contracts running 11 months (which sucks) they actively stay in contact / try and find way of getting great people to stay / come back. The hours are long - but no longer than any other job I've had in London and the rewards and job satisfaction are well worth it.
cons: Hard for me to find any cons, but if pushed would say lack of headcount.

headline: One of the best companies to work for
pros: - They take care of basically all our needs. Laptop, mobile phone, food, shower, shares, health and life insurance, transport allowance, wellness and gym benefits amongst other stuff.
cons: This can be a very competitive environment and it can be a bit challenging depending on the nature of the employee.

headline: Product Specialist
pros: Great company and team culture, lots of learning opportunities outside of role
cons: Anything I view as a con can be addressed by discussing with my team or providing feedback.

headline: Feels like joining an elite squad of super engineers
pros:
Facebook hires comparable to the best talent I've worked with in the industry, with regards to smarts -- but also with at least a modicum of social skills :)

Enormous opportunity to influence business direction, chase after your own ideas, and really stretch yourself to your fullest potential.

Almost everything that should be provided is, without lengthy approval processes, unparalleled trust in employees at all levels (you don't need to be a bigwig to get perks).

Employees are empowered to build anything, any app, service, feature. If you are a big fan of autonomy and self-driven growth, Facebook is the place to go.

Managers don't bark orders or give commands, but spend the vast majority of their time as a support role, and encouraging leadership between engineers.
cons: Can be intimidating at times, and coworkers definitely work a lot. Perhaps similarly to startups where everyone is motivated. You have to set your own work-life balance, but flexibility exists to allow you to do so (you never feel intimidated to have to work long hours, it's more of a self-motivation question).

headline: One of the best jobs you could want
pros: The amount of pros here is ridiculous. You have really nice, smart people as co-workers. The work is insanely interesting and challenging. Lots of room for growth. Free food, insane perks, fantastic pays, etc.
cons:
Working with smart people is a pro and a con. It's easy to stress out about not being the smarted person there. You'll often feel you have to work extra hard to keep up, but thats something you overcome when you realize you wouldn't be there if you aren't qualified.

The area described above often affects work/life balance... because people feel this way they tend to work a lot so then you feel like you do too. After a while you find a good balance, but its easy to fall into the trap of constantly being involved in work.

headline: A little too dynamic for their own good
pros:
- Open, positive culture (it really is): goals are assigned to you at the beginning of the half mostly basis your strength areas

- Opportunity to work with one of the industry leaders in online media - the platform and its underlying are a tech enthusiast's dream

-Not a 'hire and fire' company. They really care about their employees.

- Lavish, almost extravagant benefits: you can get spa massages reimbursed, for instance.
cons:
- Facebook feels like a young and aggressive teenager. Granted, its prime focus is to grab a bigger slice of pie from Google but that seems to be driving its entire business strategy. 

- Hyderabad undergoes re-orgs way too frequently, which has resulted in mass attrition with several senior managers moving on.

- Under-hiring talent: There is no difference between the role/designation of an ISB MBA with 3 years of solid work ex and an undergrad fresher from a local college. HR needs to work out this motivational deterrent else attrition is set to rise.

- Inverted pyramid hiring in the sales team: Way too many senior and mid-level managers are being hired as individual contributors for roles that are given to college grads in other locations. Limited growth opportunities because of this.
advice_to_mgmt: Please rethink your hiring bar, especially in Hyderabad. Some of the full-timers can barely communicate and several mid-level managers are NOT a culture fit.

headline: The complete package
pros: The most talented people you will find in any large corporate organization. This significantly improves both the company's and your chances of professional success.
cons: Commuting from SF and the difficulty in getting promotee
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up!

headline: Relatively New Engineer Perspective
pros: So many smart people that are super humble and easy to interact with. Facebook keeps titles and ranks hidden so company feels very flat. Perks are incredible they really care about their employees.
cons: Company has grown a lot feels maybe less tight knit than in old days.

cons: rapidly growing so it feels chaotic at times

headline: Company overview
pros: Excellent culture, excellent leader, good benefits
cons: Not really . Everything is good

headline: I've worked at a lot of places; this is the best
pros: Coworkers are really smart, politics is minimal, and focus is on what you can accomplish that will help the company.
cons: If you're working in California, the rent and commute aren't great. The East coast offices are where its at.
advice_to_mgmt: keep up the good work!
response_role: Director, Global Recruiting Programs and Operations
response: Thank you for sharing. Happy to hear that you are able to make an impact in Facebook Boston, a great location for those on the East Coast!

headline: Best place for a software engineer to work.

headline: Best Company on earth
pros: Um, where to start. Basically the hype is true. I'm not an engineer/dev type. Perhaps this is more standard for those career tracks. However, you'd be had pressed to find any company providing this kind of environment to its employees. Salary is great, bennies are great, managers are awesome, culture is fantastic and the company its doing really well. Its stable.
cons: Don't really have any. I've heard some people say they would prefer to have an office vs open floor. Well guess what, everyone from Mark down is sitting in the open floor plan, so no one is getting a raw deal. And I love it personally.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work.

headline: Mission Driven Culture
pros: Mission driven around making the world more open and connected, company looks after it's employees, focus on impact, built for the long haul
cons: 15K+ employees across 30+ locations means it's no longer a start-up

headline: Ok

cons: The culture is deterioriting fast due to accelerated growth.

headline: great work

headline: Good place to work
pros: Food, Smart people,Good pay, Food, Flexibility
cons: There are no cons of working here

headline: Best of all the places I've worked
pros:
Great culture. High level of independence and reliance on individuals doing what they see as the best use of their talents for the company (with guidance from managers and others if needed). Each team is a little different in how they operate, but because you can pick your team after you join (and have gone through bootcamp and met many of them), you can find the fit that matches you. And if you find you need a change at some point, then you just find the next team/project (or come up with your own) that again satisfies you and helps the company as much as possible.

The perks are awesome. Free food, snacks. Lots of variety, high quality. Great benefits - I'm a big fan of the onsite medical/dental options. It's a company that cares about its employees and you can feel it imo.

Open culture. Smart people. And a growing business make it the best in tech right now.
cons:
Problems that basically persist for most tech companies in the Bay Area like commute sux. Hard to get a good commute, and if you do, then you're probably paying a steep price for it. Shuttles help a lot if you're coming from SF or surrounding cities, but still suck overall.

Generally, prices for housing suck anywhere you live in the Bay Area. If you're already here, then you already know that. If not, then be prepared - it sux.

Diversity is still a problem. Facebook is trying to fix this, and it comes up all the time about what more can be done which is good, but at the end of the day, it's still a problem.

headline: Project Manager

headline: Good job

headline: Focus on Impact

Having so much financial success allows the company to make some bonehead product decisions without major repercussions (this can be very frustrating after a while). Many teams didn't have a strong design voice while I was there. Over-reliance on data in decision making.
advice_to_mgmt: Embrace design leadership at the executive level.

headline: this is a great company

headline: Great company with a bright future
pros:
Hands-down the smartest people I've worked for in my career
Great open culture. People are driven by team and company success, not personal ego.
Pay well-above industry standard, for every job in the company.
cons:
There is one little *thing*

Some devs came up with a lottery program. Once a year it generates a bunch of random numbers and assigns one to each person in the company. Then of that list of numbers it generated, it randomly selects one. Whoever that number is assigned to is the lottery "winner". The winner is then taken to a private, sound-proof room where they are chained to a wall and then are beaten to death with a tire iron by Mark Zuckerberg while he screams "LOTTERY In June STOCKS BE HEAVY SOON!!! MUHaHAHAHAHA!!!!"
advice_to_mgmt: Better lottery prize please?

pros: career opportunities, benefits, package, people
cons: fewer benefits than competition,

The company is willing to invest in you, so don't hesitate if you don't know a specific programming or technology.
cons: Most of the tools used are custom to Facebook, although more and more are being made open source.

headline: Great company

headline: Great place to work
pros: Young and vibrant office. Great company culture. Good vertical as well as horizontal career opportunities.
cons: Employees turnover mainly because of people moving to Dublin specifically for the job/company. Some members of senior management clearly lacked experience.

headline: Joined for the company, left because of the manager
pros:
- Awesome company
- Amazing perks
- Good pay, great stock options
- Hiring process is very streamlined and makes you feel very welcome
- Bootcamp is the best training I've experienced in my 10-year career at any company
- You get to pick a team you join
cons:
- Your experience is a Russian roulette and 100% depends on your manager and your team.
- HR promise things that are a lie - for example, that they hire you for the company and you can switch teams if you're unhappy, but if someone influential on your team wants to destroy you, they will (and with HR's blessings, HR will show you the door instead of being the helping hand, because they have a line up of 500 new hires next week, so who cares)
- Non-existent work life balance (which I don't mind as long as I'm able to actually do my job efficiently and not spend countless hours on useless, counterintuitive corporate processes, meetings and politics - that's the frustrating part - long hours and not getting much done)
- Immature, clueless, helpless management - manager will provide no help in a toxic situation, approve of back stabbing, won't listen to your concerns, will play politics and favorites - and since the review process 100% depends on your manager's mood, you're in for a rollercoaster ride.
- Micromanaging, lack of autonomy - they tell you they hire you for your talent and experience (after all, you're one of the lucky 5-10% top candidates who actually get through the series of 5-7 interviews), only to treat you like a 3-year old who cannot be trusted to make even the most trivial decision by themselves. And of course with your hands tied, you can't perform well and "be bold" (like on the wall posters across the office) or make "impact", when every line of code you write must be first approved (and blocked!) by someone from the clique who wants to climb the ladder on your back, so a power struggle begins (and you're going to lose because you "don't belong"). Officially you're evaluated solely on some expectations, but unofficial stack ranking performance system (you're compared to peers) means peers are passive aggressive and compete against you instead of collaborating with you, and of course will play politics and back-stab you.
- Your experience, skill, talent and knowledge don't matter if you're new to the club. Someone senior in the team (but junior in terms of total industry experience), who is your manager's favorite boy, will get better projects, more impact, more decision making and the power to destroy you if you dare to hurt their fragile ego (by daring to give them useful technical feedback and suggesting ideas that may actually solve the problem better). If you're not happy with the leftovers you get or actually want to make some impact, participate in decision making, improve some inefficient processes (so you and the whole team can benefit and perform better) and solve some problems, you are made feel very unwelcome and shown the door.
advice_to_mgmt: Just hire competent managers who know how to deal with passive-aggressive toxic workers, with conflict, who know how to foster collaboration instead of competition, who are objective and actually sometimes listen to feedback instead of just talking their employees down all the time. Who understand that autonomy and growth are important to job satisfaction and understand what diverse working styles actually mean.

headline: Facebook Engineer
pros: Work life balance, we do not punch a clock
cons: Management is lacking focus on the teams.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your subordinates.

headline: Facebook engineer
pros: Great place to work with great people.
cons: No complaints here. Just wanted a new challenge.

headline: Can't Imagine Leaving
pros:
1. Wicked smart people. I find that I'm learning from a LOT of my co-workers and I was a top 5%'er at my previous company of 300,000+ employees.
2. People are really collaborative, in that they won't go change something without talking to the person impacted.
3. Amazing internal tools to do my day-to-day job.
4. Really impressed with Mark and Sheryl. They are genuinely as kind and intelligent as they appear from the outside.
cons: 1. the way engineering is prioritized #1 in everything leads to arrogance among engineering directors
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep up the great work.
Be careful, don't let eng directors become arrogant jerks over time.

headline: The best place to work ever!
pros:
- Work and life balance is a must
- You always feel like your work is the most important thing
- Great environment and you're surrounded by professionals and very talented people
- Is always a pleasure to work in a company that has changed the world as FB did and keep doing
cons: - It is hard to maintain the same culture in such a large company
advice_to_mgmt: To make sure that they're taking into consideration any feedback we gave about the company.

headline: Move fast, dream big
pros: It might sound cheesy, but the best part of working at Facebook is knowing that management truly cares about my success and wellbeing. The benefits are nice, but being trusted and supported with stellar people? That's what really counts.
cons: As you might imagine, you do run into some entitled, privileged employees. That said, it seems to come with the tech territory. It's certainly also a fast paced environment with ever-shifting deadlines, though I wouldn't consider the work life balance to be much worse than other companies.
advice_to_mgmt: Invest even more in diversity of employees. Continue to value managers who support and care for their reports.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: excellent work environment and colleagues, social benefits

advice_to_mgmt: please pay more attention to your workers' advices

headline: great place
pros:
Good place to work
smart colleagues
cons: too much work but I think this is normal for a big tech company like facebook

headline: Technical Program Manager
pros: Best place I've ever worked in my whole career! My coworkers are talented (and nice!), the work is fulfilling, interesting and intellectually stimulating. The pay is competitive pay and the perks are just ridiculously awesome.
cons: Work hours are longer than my previous job (this is not a 9-5 gig), but it's because I care about doing a great job. I think I can work less hours if I didn't give a damn, but I actually care about my work and my mission.
advice_to_mgmt: Be careful of allowing growth to get in the way of doing our job. I hope that Facebook doesn't get consumed by bureaucracy like other companies I've worked for in the past as it grows.

headline: F
pros: Health Benefits, Lots of free food
cons:
For a social company, face to face interaction with most management lacked depth..managers are always so busy and in a rush, and then it was on to liking and commenting on the next thing in their newsfeed, the next urgent request, the next team to manage...

You see many employees managing "their internal brand" and posturing via their fb posts. It is exhausting. 

Senior executives are driving government politics not shared openly with employees.

headline: Great Place
pros: Great Culture. Operates super fast-paced. Ability to work on impactful issues. No micro-management mostly and a lot of freedom
cons: Culture is extremely skewed by Californian culture which becomes repressive to any discussion on some of the ideas.
advice_to_mgmt: Embrace the facts and numbers. Be bold

headline: Ok
pros: Free food is something really nice
cons: Nothing I can think of right now.

headline: Working at Facebook is as good as it gets
pros: The people I work with are what makes Facebook so amazing. Everyone is legitimately passionate about their work and the impact their having. Perks and salary aside (both of which are great), it's amazing going into work every day knowing that what i'm doing is having a direct impact on our 1.7 billion (and growing every day) users. I get excited to come into work every day, even after 1.5 years, and I wouldn't trade that for the world!
cons: When I first joined one of the things I loved was the internal transparency, there were no "locked doors" and leadership/management was always very open about things going on at the company, but lately it seems like upper management are keeping more and more things confidential without any explanation as to why.
advice_to_mgmt: Be more open and transparent about ongoing projects, work, and roadmaps because it ultimately leads to better and more impactful work since your employees can see the road ahead and get excited.
response: Thank you for taking a moment to share your experience. Transparency is important to Facebook both from a company and product point of view. We will share this feedback with internal teams and work hard to ensure that our 'be open' culture continues to be a critical part of how we work together.

headline: Awesome office in Seattle!
pros:
- Internal tooling: Coming from Microsoft, the internal tooling here is nothing short of incredible. Everything just *works*, and it's mostly consistent throughout the entire company. Everyone uses the same code review process. Everyone uses the same build tools. Everyone uses the same check in process (per repository). Everyone uses the same employee feedback process. etc... There are also lots of internal services that are really helpful. Services for deployment, managing configuration, a/b testing, etc. Because everyone uses the same tools, everyone invests in them and they're well-documented, easy to learn, etc.
- People: everyone I've worked with is really smart and happy to lend a helping hand. Haven't had any issues so far.
- Work: I've enjoyed the kind of problems that I get to solve at Facebook much more than the kind of problems I got to solve at Microsoft. I worked on four different teams at Microsoft. The problems here are more challenging and require scalable, efficient solutions.
- Culture: The culture here is fantastic. Internally, there is a lot of transparency. There isn't too much politics. You can make improvements on part of the codebase. There isn't much process to slow you down. There is a lot of individual freedom in what your prioritize and work on.
- Work life balance: I've had great work life balance here. I typically work 35-40 hours a week, and I've not once stayed late for dinner. On-call is pretty light--much easier than on-call at Microsoft. This might vary by team.
- Food: Really good food. Lots of healthy options (and unhealthy options if you want a cheat day).
- Benefits: Pretty happy with the benefits. The transportation options are really good. The baby benefits are great.
cons:
- 401k matching is capped at 50% match up to 7% of base salary
- No matching contributions for charitable giving
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work!
response: Welcome to Facebook! We are glad to hear that you are enjoying Facebook Seattle, a location with big growth plans for our software engineering teams. Our teams will be delighted to hear that you are getting the support you need so you can focus on meaningful impact!

headline: It doesn't get better than this.
