response: Thank you for taking a moment to share your experience. We value caring for each other as much as focusing on impact. We'll share this feedback with our internal teams to improve the employee experience.

headline: Hell for Contractors
pros:
Free food
Happy hour/free alcohol
Open work space
Technology
Weird themed rooms
cons:
Contractors are treated like subhumans, not allowed to certain events

Contractors through certain companies have no one acting on their behalf or acting as liaisons between Facebook and the contracting company

Entire teams can and do get laid off with no warning
advice_to_mgmt:
Treat your contractors like human beings

Make sure you have people in place to act as liaisons between Facebook and the contracting company

Give your contractors some job security

Be more transparent

Use direct language; don't hedge reports and updates with fluffy language and idealism

headline: Software Engineer

cons: Starting to see some lack of transparency nowadays as company scales. Engineers are sometimes spoiled and argue on small stuffs all the time

headline: Amazing Culture
pros:
Amazing company culture that's embedded in most of its employees. Feedback is done in the most constructive way possible. No BS, genuine attempt to minimize politics (yes no company is 100% politics free), super fast paced, yet respectful of individual time and space. Highly collaborative environment, and everything is measured by impact to people. 

Employees are committed to their works and committed to have fun as well! Most of us are unpretentious or trying to hard to impress or look busy, even though the work is very intense! That's why visitors always thought that we hardly work!

Be warned though, this company may not be for everybody, particularly if your strength revolves around internal politics and bootlicking, or you prefer companies where you can relax and do minimal work, or you don't like to have tough conversations to solve tough problems, or you don't like to work with a team where everybody knows what each other is doing.
cons: Writing this just because I have to, though there's really no cons that I can think of. If I really have to think of something, perhaps it's the amount of interesting information that you have to keep up with everyday.

headline: Better than Google!
pros: I've worked for Google and Facebook and feel more valued at Facebook. From interview, first day, and onwards, it's embedded in your head to be your "authentic self". Facebook seems like the hip, new Google and the impact is tremendous!
cons: Parking is limited but lots of ways you can get to work. Benefits are great but there are some that don't compare to Google like 401k isn't as competitive.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep improving perks to attract more talent. You are doing a great job retaining talent!

headline: Love it here
pros: I've never felt so excited to go to work. Aside from the perks (that kick butt), every employee is extremely intelligent, hard working and friendly. We joke around and solve problems 10 minutes later. Managers are just as cool and the new guy. No one pretends to be anything that they're not. I like the honesty.
cons: Trying to think of something. Lets see... Oh I can see how someone can gain weight very easily! Aside from the free delicious food, employees love bringing in baked goods that they've made at home.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep grooming the next generation of leaders.
response: Thank you for "shipping love" in Facebook Austin and sharing your experience. We are glad to hear that the sense of our Facebook community is core to how you work there, just as it is in our offices around the world.

pros: I enjoy working with really smart people, in a moving fast, impact oriented culture. Bootcamp process is also awesome opportunity to talk with multiple teams.
cons: Was not able to find serious cons. Maybe that the food is too good and most of employees gain weight after a few years of working there :)

headline: Great place to work; Hard to navigate career growth and internal politics
pros:
- Amazing benefits. They really take care of employees. 
- Great workplace environment. Coworkers feel like family and are very supportive of each other. 
- Mission of the company truly runs deep. 
- Flexible work hours and environment. There is generally a high degree of trust between employees.
cons:
- The open floor plan can be completely draining (especially for introverts, like myself). 
- Very unclear career growth. I started as an early career employee and one of the main reasons I left was because I felt like there was really little investment in my professional and personal growth. I found that Facebook really likes employees that will work hard and make them look good, but they don't care about helping you move up to the next level. There was no clear progression. A part of this is the flat organizational structure, which appeals to some but not to all. 
- Very millennial feeling (I'm a millennial too) and can feel extremely unprofessional at times. No line between personal and professional relationships. Again, this is up to personal choice but it didn't feel great to me all the time. 
- Cult-like worship of upper management (Mark and Sheryl). They are awesome people to look up to but people are not critical enough of the company all the time. It felt like people were always blind-sided by the flashiness of M-team's messaging. 
- Facebook hires a lot of contractors to full-time positions (especially in Austin), which can feel irksome. 
- Since the company has grown so much, they need to stop acting like a startup. 
- It's easy to do work that isn't actually fulfilling but is necessary to run the company. 
- Loved the mission and messaging of the company but didn't feel like my work was impactful in any way, which was an unfortunate feeling. 
- Pay is not that good for entry level/early career business side roles. Engineers make a lot more, unsurprisingly. 
- This is an engineer-run company, after all. So if you are on the business side, expect to be heavily reliant on engineering resources, which can be extremely draining and frustrating. 
- Facebook says it's easy to transition between roles and teams but I found that to not be true. That's another reason why I left. It may be easier on the engineering side. Additionally, being a remote office truly limits your networking and career opportunities (even if they tell you otherwise). 
- I had more managers than I could count in one year. The turnover was way too high and I didn't feel like anyone was invested in me. I wasn't growing and as an early career professional, growth is my top priority.
- Facebook is a global company and most of its users are outside of the US. However, the mindset is still extremely American and I frankly found the way in which people talked about users outside of the US to be downright offensive at times. There was no desire to get to deeply understand user behavior and market trends outside of the US. Given how the world economy is trending, Facebook will be in a bad position if employee mindsets don't change. There are companies all over the world (especially in Asia) that are taking over (and have already taken over) the spaces Facebook is trying to break into as of late.
- A combination of unclear expectations and high manager turnover led to not-stellar performance reviews for me. 
- People always said I could work on what interested me and what I was good at but whenever I tried to do so, I was shut down.
response: Thank you for taking the time to share your experience and feedback. Taking care of our employees is paramount to our continued growth and success. Being a part of the Facebook Family is not only a phrase, it's what we believe and practice every day. With that in mind, we'll share your feedback with our internal teams in Austin to improve upon the employee experience.

headline: Interesting work, great benefits, good work-life balance
pros: In my experience at Facebook, I've found the work to be interesting and industry-leading, and the people to be smart, engaged and impact-driven. We get stuff done. At the same time, the company benefits are great, and I've been able to achieve a good state of work-life integration.
cons: Working in NY will require travel to MPK (headquarters). My travel has averaged about ~20% of my time. NY is still a growing office, so opportunities at senior levels still seem limited.
response: We are certainly growing Facebook New York across all teams, from software engineering to sales. We look forward to supporting the growth there and the meaningful work of our teams as they connect the world.

headline: A good company in fast moving pace!!!!
pros:
+ Grate place to work with super smart people
+ Taking very good care of emplyee
cons: - Ultra fast moving pace company

headline: Awesome Company to Work for
pros: Great work culture, diverse group of people to work with, wonderful benefits.
cons: Fast paced, but enjoyable :)

headline: Amazing place to work. Great culture. Great mission.
pros: Always new opportunities. International and highly innovative. Excellent work life balance, and lots of potential for career growth. The company has a very interesting road map with tons of new products yet to be realized.
cons: Company is getting bigger. Starting to slow down. There is beginning to be a lot of emphasis on managing internal stakeholders which is symptomatic of a transition into being a large multinational.
advice_to_mgmt: Think big, act small.
response: Thanks for sharing. As we continue to scale and grow globally, it will be important to stay focused on moving fast and focusing on impact with the agility of small and flexible teams. This is a collective goal for all of us. In HR, we'll work hard to support and empower this environment. Appreciate your feedback.

headline: Great place
pros: smart people, great culture, fast moving, sky is the limit
cons: work life balance, too much work, too many things at to quick a pace

headline: Good work culture
pros:
1. Independence to drive project
2. Working with a lot of cross functional partners and learning how people with different background work
cons:
1. A lot of Hierarchy in India office
2. Difficult to maintain work life balance

headline: Best place to work!
pros:
+ Open and transparent management
+ Diverse team
+ High salary
+ Great perks
+ Amazing culture
cons: - Not having offices in many big cities like LA

headline: Very good overall
pros: You have the resources to do your job, you work with other highly-skilled people, you make a positive difference to the world.
cons: Head office is in California, which can mean a lot of late nights for meetings. Free food makes you fat.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: great perks, young, impact, pay
cons: code quality is not good

headline: Facebook review
pros: Good learning opportunity, Awesome culture and will get responsibilty
cons: I cannot think of anything negative about Facebook.
advice_to_mgmt: I would not like to change anything about Facebook. It is doing pretty good and should continue the same.

headline: Best place to work
pros: Love the openess and the food is grear
cons: None. No real cons.

headline: Product Support (Not every team is created equal)
pros:
Benefits
Food
Gym
Youthful Culture
Great Executives
Very smart people (engineers)
Beautiful campus
cons:
Not every team is created equal at Facebook. I'm a Product Support Specialist at Facebook working under the Global Shared Services department. Unfortunately, the role that was stated in the JD is not the role that I am in. 

I was told the Product Support role would be a precursor to Product Management and that you will be spending a lot of time strategizing and helping product teams with their product roadmaps. A couple weeks in, and I soon realized that this role is purely operational and SLA based. We manned bug reports on a daily basis. Everything was numbers driven, but not in the right way. We were encouraged to analyze the tickets to find ways to improve SLA. 

Leadership is quite weak. They only listen to our goals and aspirations but neither help us or nor point us to the right direction. Most of the team don't plan to stay for long. Everyone seems to have a plan B or to be using this role as a springboard to another one within Facebook.

Although I hear great things from other teams, this one is not it.
advice_to_mgmt:
When hiring for new recruits, don't sell them on what the team will be in 2 years. Let them know what is the current state of the team. Be honest about how much time is spent on day-to-day "tasks"

Try to be a leader and not numbers driven for your own career benefits.

Facebook is an open company, uphold those cultures.
response: Thank you for your feedback. We'll share this with our Global Shared Services and Recruiting teams to ensure that we're setting clear and transparent role expectations, as well as developing our teams, so employees experience Facebook as a place for long-term career growth.

headline: Facebook is the worst job, except for all the others
pros:
Facebook is probably the best big company to work for. The company cares a lot about having its employees being productive and satisfied with their jobs and it works hard at maintaining an environment to support that. As a survivor from the real world, this is really rare -- pretty much every company-wide system is designed to make life easier for employees. The benefits and conveniences offered are amazing.

Many decisions about the company and its goals are made fairly transparently and open discussion about most things is encouraged. This can get really annoying at times.

Unlike most companies, Zuck is actually a pretty inspiring leader. He makes mistakes, but does learn from them. He has really lofty goals, though, and doing the right thing is highly subjective when trying to change the world.

If you are politically savvy and willing to work hard and make sure others notice that hard work, you will go far. You will learn a lot if you seek out opportunities to learn, and work with a lot of very talented people. You have to own this yourself, though; don't count on a lot of support.
cons:
Facebook still believes that it is a magical meritocracy reasonably free from corporate nonsense. While there aren't any Office Space-style TPS reports to fill out and you don't have to bring in your own coffee and toilet paper, it is now just a big company job like any other. If you want something, whether it be a promotion or a good dessert from the cafeteria, you have to plan how to get it, execute on the plan, and then make sure everyone else knows what you did and how great it was. You also have to share just enough detail to be convincing but not so much that people can poke holes in your story or usurp your dessert acquisition techniques.

The typical first level line manager at Facebook doesn't have prior management experience, only knows the Facebook way of doing things, and is overwhelmed with all the pressure being placed on them. It's a really hard job, too; your manager will be responsible both for setting the direction of your team and for making sure you and your colleagues grow at the company. Most people are not good at either of those things, let alone both. Be aware of what your manager is looking for and how to best communicate it.

Everything FB does is subject to a lot of public scrutiny, and you will know how the sausage is made and see that the goals of the company aren't focused on invading privacy or global domination like everyone else thinks. It's hard to see this thing that takes up so much of your life lionized and loathed by the press and your friends.

For engineers, a lot of the tools you will use day-to-day are incomplete, broken, poorly documented, and might not be supported anymore. You will get used to this. "Move fast and break things" is more complicated than it sounds, and that's really hard to adapt to when coming from a more traditional company. Have big goals but chop them up into small tasks with well-defined success indicators and communicate them early and often.
advice_to_mgmt: To the director- and VP-level people that have been at FB a long time: it's not the same company you went to work at lo those many years ago. There are between 5 and 50 times more employees now, way more products, and way more moving parts. If you want Facebook to stay Facebook-y, invest in the culture that you love. Teach people how to be successful and reward individuals that focus on impact that makes everyone's work easier and the product better, not on whatever new hotness made a contrived graph go in the right direction. Lots of things aren't working right anymore and it is up to you to start the hard conversations about which sacred cows can't provide enough milk for tens of thousands of employees because you never taught the new people how to talk about that stuff.
response: Thanks for your feedback. We care deeply about our employees, which is why we strive to create an open and transparent workplace. And we need to do this as a team that's constantly evolving and improving. We'll share your feedback with internal teams to enhance the employee experience. Thanks again for your time.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Work on a product used by Billions, run by a CEO and executive team of rockstars. Mission driven, Flexible, cutting edge products used by people, developers, publishers, advertisers etc. Awesome perks.
cons: Long commute from SF to HQ, Company getting large now and it's harder to work on most impactful products.

headline: Great compensation if you can cut it
pros: Great benefits and compensation. Lots of different technologies to work on, lots of opportunities for visibility and impact. Good place to learn and explore mobile, full stack and backend infrastructure. Fun place to work when things are going well.
cons: High stress, lot of turnover. I've had a new manager every year. Some teams have a 24/7 work expectation. Highly competitive, and you are competing with lots of smart people. Seems very difficult to get a promotion and junior people who don't rise fast enough are pushed out. For senior engineers, one bad project or not enough impact and it can be very difficult to course-correct.
advice_to_mgmt: Fix the fake news problem. Recognize that incremental improvements and investment in software infrastructure pay long term dividends and reward that. Not everything is easy to quantify in terms of impact and a lot of work on quality goes unrewarded.
response: Thank you for your feedback. Incremental improvements and sustainable investments in quality are important. We see this in our weekly Q&A meetings when Mark recognizes people during the 'fix-of-the-week' and in celebrating the Faceversaries of tenured employees. That being said, we can and will do better and appreciate your feedback to help us improve.

headline: Really disappointed
pros: Great co-workers overall with a few bad eggs that just seem to cause issues.
cons: Pressure to over achieve. To many cooks in the kitchen, and I'm not talking about LTD.

headline: Open, Connected, & Diverse
pros: You can be who you really are and no pretense. Every day is a new learning experience with wonderful opportunities to grow.
cons: Great placr to work! Can't think of any!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work! Love working here! Proud to be a Facebook employee.

headline: FB: Hard Problems and Fun People
pros:
It's a social networking company so it pre-selects for social people. Most of my coworkers want to be friends in addition to colleagues.

The scale is amazing: it's exciting but also humbling to sit in a room and talk about how 1B will use our product.

With that scale comes the requirement for precision in algorithms, data structures and code clarity that I've never experienced before.
cons:
Being very data-driven can push out more sentiment-based projects and sometimes puts too much of a burden on teams to identify exactly the right metric to optimize for.

Tooling for developers is improving but with such a large codebase and so many developers, creating a branch, making a change and building can take a long time. This is especially true on mobile.

headline: Technical Recruiter
pros: Best hiring experience I have ever had, fairly quick process, good communication and transparency.
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Amazing
pros: Besides the usual (brilliant people, delicious free meals for breakfast/lunch/dinner, beautiful campus, great benefits, cutting edge technology, etc..) I was surprised by how open the information transfer is from team to team and how much flexibility and options there are for career growth.
cons: Despite the great salary, the cost of living in the area is still a pain point.
advice_to_mgmt: I would like to see more tech talks from people outside of Facebook.

headline: A workplace that aligns with my personal values
pros: Great personable, consistent and admirable leadership. Majority of the workforce puts effort into aligning than realigning on the mission and the company's core values. All the benefits and convenient services offered on campus help you focus on what you do best. Love the people—some of the smartest, most passionate, and committed—I get to work with.
cons: No particular cons, except note that it's a pretty large organization that is ran by countless autonomous teams meaning experiences in each team could be quite different.

headline: Partner manager
pros: awesome team, good salary, strong perks, flexible hrs
cons: rigid management, progression slow, slow strategy, more experienced management
advice_to_mgmt: more streamlined processes

headline: Great company
pros: Great culture, strong engineers, very nice campus
cons: it's getting bigger and bigger

headline: Full-on
pros:
Virtually no numpties: not the smartest group I ever saw, but definitely - for any company with more than ten employees - the one with the least wasters.

Devs are the most important people in the company. It's nice to be that person, people that have worked in investment banks will know what I mean.

Good perks.

You can do anything or buy anything that gets the job done: senior management have very few things that "you just can't do"...
cons:
... though one thing you can't do is work a four day week, at least not as a manager.

It's pretty full-on: there's always loads to do and for a UK manager, 5pm-7pm Mon-Thurs is video conference season. If you don't mind coming in late to stay late that can be OK, but if you prefer to start early, it makes for a long day.
advice_to_mgmt: Consider more flexible working arrangements.

headline: Great diverse company
pros: Open Work environment. Great benefits and pay. Diverse work environment with top level talent in every department.
cons: Semi-chaotic. Not super structured work environment.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to keep clear goals to drive towards.

headline: Production Engineer
pros: you get to choose what you want to work on most of time.
cons: needs to focus on the impact.

headline: Engineering Manager
pros: I get to solve problems with fantastic colleagues, some of the smartest people I've ever worked with. I get to work on truly important challenges - products and systems that impact 1.7bn people. I also get to do what I love, using knowledge I gained from my PhD. Then there are the perks of being there - the free food, events and great office.
cons: It's hard work, and pretty intense. It can be hard to extract yourself from the fast pace and the scale of the problems.

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: really relaxed, casual dress code, competitive pay
cons: sometimes worked late when deadlines were die but very rarely

headline: Meh
pros: Not as cool as they used to be. No longer a start up.
cons: They're just not that awesome compared to the alternatives. Do you really want to work on a product your mom uses more than you because it's just not that relevant to you?
advice_to_mgmt: Do something useful. Stop trying to subvert the freedom of the internet by giving facebook first internet to the world. Give freely or not at all.

headline: Operations
pros: Amazing company, great to be here and learn about the culture, ecosystem, and products.
cons: I think the commute is clearly a problem, but also sometimes bureaucracies exist where they should not.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep contractors engaged. They all maintain desires to work here long term, and many have much to offer the company.

headline: Great company, strong exec leadership
pros: Executive team is incredibly strong. Great people to work with across the globe. Lot of mobility options.
cons: Middle to senior management likes to play the game and it can be hard to move upwards if you don't have management support.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't focus on the people that speak the loudest or self promote the most within the groups. Really look to everyone on your team to have an equal voice and create forums that allow that, especially for international employees.

headline: Great Culture
pros: Highly collaborative, smart people, mission driven company, fun colleagues, fast moving, energetic
cons: At times, lack of focus...placing too many bets and not quick enough to abandon some and focus on ones that are showing early success
advice_to_mgmt: Focus

headline: Career-defining
pros: Amazing people, great perks, opportunities to make an impact that simply are not available at other companies. A++ would work again
cons: "Resource" allocation is out of your hands, difficult to get things shipped, internal fiefdoms, occasional gross misprioritization around dumb products, innovation is slipping

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: The people; the calibre; the environment; the stimulating work; the care; the perks.
cons: I can't imagine leaving is going to be easy.

headline: Great Work Experience
pros: Facebook is a fun company to work for. People are laid back. Lots of fun activities and celeb appearances. Good compensation and lots of room for growth.
cons: Facebook is currently gentrifying East Palo Alto. A lot of families in the areas surrounding Facebook can not afford to compete of housing with the Facebook employees who are making high salaries.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to work on diversity and inclusion. Be more aware of cultural bias and prejudice and always nip in the bud to ensure all members of the Facebook community feel comfortable.

headline: Studio Video Producer
pros: The company has a very family-oriented feel
cons: The main campus is in fountain valley
advice_to_mgmt: please hear us

headline: Internship at Facebook
pros: Good environment and interesting projects, along with amazing salary and benefits
cons: There is a danger of working too much just because all the benefits make you think that you owe the company to work more than you already do

headline: Amazing
pros: I had an amazing experience interning at Facebook. The recruiters did a good job putting me in a team that I really liked to work with. I got to work with really smart people.
cons: The only downside is that bay area is not a nice place to live in if you are young
advice_to_mgmt: Give more feedback, sometimes some managers hold themselves when being clear about the project

headline: Best place to work
pros: Amazing agency in your work and tons of exciting things to work on. Culture is awesome as well.
cons: Not many. I suppose one could be that most teams work long hours.
response: Thanks for sharing your feedback! We're glad to hear that you're finding autonomy and fun in your work here. We've only just begun!

headline: software
pros: it is a good position to work, but a little bit too busy for every day
cons: nice for the fresh people to get in. but not good for old worker
advice_to_mgmt: there is a huge gap between worker and management. so work better for that please.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Facebook's products are used by more people than anything else. The company's mission -- to connect the world -- is good. There are many, many choices of projects for software engineers and you get to pick your team.
cons: Facebook is a big company with rules. If you are a software engineer, you are compared to all other software engineers. If you do part of the job of a software engineer and part of the job of a something-else (PM, manager, analyst, etc), it will be hard to evaluate you. Also, it is common to have a lot of manager changes.

headline: Facebook
pros: Very nice to work at, awesome people around, interesting projects in lots of areas, you can have huge impact, good salary and benefits.
cons: Move fast and break things may not be the best motto; it's a big company, hard to coordinate across different offices.

headline: Amazing place to work!
pros: Open and transparent culture, promotes ownership, data driven and results driven culture, very inspiring top leaders, and lots of exciting projects
cons: Work life balance could take a hit, the company is quite large now so need to make extra efforts for visibility to leadership
advice_to_mgmt: Keep managing the lean and flat teams. Facebook is probably the only company that has more than 10k but still has ability to operate as a startup! And I believe most of it has to do wirh that.

headline: Open and transparent, great focus on driving meaningful impact
pros:
- Awesome colleagues who are very talented and driven
- Open culture, lots of structured and unstructured learning taking place
- Management is usually pretty good with their people
- Meaningful company mission and impactful individual work
- Perks are fantastic
cons:
- Big company now, moves slower than before
- Lateral movements into certain departments are more difficult than they should be
- Engineering and product related functions are somewhat treated better than others (management is good about combating this)
advice_to_mgmt: Your people are the top asset, don't forget that! I hope Zuck is still doing weekly Q&As!

headline: Excellent company that takes care of its employees
pros: Company with strong leadership, clear vision and exciting products to work on. Good benefits, events and true care about work-life balance.
cons: As the company grows, it moves much slower and certain product decisions take longer than necessary to execute. There is not always a clear development path for employees
advice_to_mgmt: Move much faster and eliminate unnecessary layers in decision-making. There are often too many stakeholders involved and things tend to slow down, although Facebook still "moves fast".
response: Thanks for sharing your experience. As we continue to grow, we'll need to work hard to keep our teams flexible to balance our "move fast" culture with the need to "focus on impact". These core values make us stronger as a community when we find the right balance.

headline: Great spot to be
pros: A lot of free food and and perks. Opportunity to define your own projects.
cons: Responsibilities tend to be narrow especially as the company continues to hire rapidly.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue the transparency and communication to all levels of the organization. Mid level management needs more accountability.

headline: Motivational work environment
pros:
Work culture is amazing, you get to work with the best of the managers 
Always inspiring to move fast and ahead
cons: The contract hiring policy is not that great the way contractors are treated is not very positive , they should work in this sphere

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Extensive experience as an Executive Assistant. Handing complex calendar management, travel itinerary, expenses, preparing documents for meetings, clients visits, handling mailboxes
cons: It's a great place to work however limited career growth options
advice_to_mgmt: Great team player and attention to detail

headline: Inspirational Workplace
pros: Benefits aside, the best thing about working at Facebook is the people. It is very rare to be the "smartest person in the room". There is always someone who is better than you at something. This makes Facebook a great place to grow your skills and learn new things. This is made even easier by the friendly and open environment.
cons: Many employees are young and ambitious, which is great. However, one downside to this is that people are eager to push themselves to prove what they are capable of - Facebook is a place where talented people can shine. This can lead to a self-imposed work/life misbalance.
advice_to_mgmt: The company has a great spirit and culture - the main focus should on preserving it as it grows.
response: Thank you for sharing your experience with the learning opportunities, sense of community and focus on impact here at Facebook. We work hard to support our employees so they can focus on the things that are most meaningful to them. Thanks for helping us build a thriving community.

headline: Great environment, people, tech
pros:
Great work environment, awesome people, many opportunities for learning technologies in-depth. Lots of leeway given to engineers to work on areas that they believe are important.

Benefits are awesome.
cons:
Hours are entirely flexible, so It is up to employees to keep their work-life balance in check.

I'm at a remote site, so will occasionally need to stay late for meetings with other places. This happens to me about once a month.

headline: Awesome company!
pros:
- Extremely smart people. I am really working with the best of the best engineers I have ever met.
- Move fast. Decisions are being made rapidly and objectively. No bureaucracy. The change lifecycle idea->implementation->a/b test->production can take less than one day!
- Bottom up. Many ideas and decisions are driven by engineers. Managers rarely would tell you what to do, but rather help you to get done what you think should be done. The protocol between the ideas and company goals is metrics. As long as your ideas are aligned with the metrics your org cares about you have green light to implement them.
- Diversity. Facebook cares about diversity a lot, which makes the atmosphere here really inclusive and comforting.
- Care about employees. Facebook cares about the employees. A lot. All these free meals, snacks, drinks, equipment, business trips to headquarters, tax consultations, massages and much, much more. Everything is done to allow you to take care of all your needs and allow you to focus on the job itself.
cons: - This is Facebook London specific. Many teams are working very closely with teams in US, which means that at least a few days a week there will be video conferences with US around 5-6 pm.
advice_to_mgmt: Maintain the culture!

headline: Great place to work, if you have no opinion of your own
pros:
+ good autonomy on the job
+ great (but varying with team) work/life balance
+ decent comp and benefits
+ plenty of opportunities, if you can / are willing to relocate for the next hot project
+ daily engineering problems other companies may not see in a lifetime
cons:
+ just another corporation, that doesn't like people with strong opinions
+ "trust the system" attitude to decision making and transparency
+ less senior people who question things, and have strong opinions, are often just silently managed out while the "culture" message openly encourages having such difficult conversations

headline: Fun workplace, smart engineers
pros: Great perks, good atmosphere, lots of impact
cons: Many of the problems have already been solved

headline: Good place to start your career
pros:
Perks
Salary
Work Culture
Travel
Work is interesting
Stock 
Comfortable job
cons:
Current Management
Work life balance as you would have late meetings
Transparency

headline: PMM
pros: Facebook is full of high-achieving, smart and conscientious people. The vision and subsequent goals are highly ambitious and keep everyone on their toes. We value individuals and bringing your authentic self to work, and that makes it a great place to become friends with your coworkers and shed the stress of work vs. personal separation. We also use Facebook as a core internal work tool, and I can't imagine working somewhere where it isn't used.
cons: Facebook has grown at such a rapid rate that the quality of people has gone down a bit. There are roles popping up that are more administrative and low-impact. Promotions can feel like seat time + politics rather than ability and impact.

headline: Community Operations - Hyderabad
pros: Facilities given to the employee, to travel to work and at work are very good. They try to provide a very comfortable enviornment to work.
cons:
1. The Hiring department of the company is below par. Only importance is given to Work experience not essentially in the area of expertise required. Employees coming from Premier graduation and Post graduate insitutes are considered at the same level as that of candidates from local institutes(probably done to save cost of relcoation, not expected of such a big brand)
2. The talent across Hyderabad floor and across international offices (I have visited 2) are extremely mediocre, essentially because of point number 1.
3. The attitude of collaboration and working as a team, is severly lacking in most hires in the company. 
4. The middle and senior management is hogwash and power rests in the hands of 1/2 managers who play office politics well. 
5. Middle level managers are totally impotent, Because essentially they have no power which is attributed to managers in a usual organizational set up.
advice_to_mgmt:
1. Improving hiring techniques, more experience =! Good hire, Education Pedigree is equally important
2. Do not undergo Reorganization frequently, classic strategy to lose good talent, Though one may be arrogant enough to attract good talent time and again but things do cap off and Name spreads like fire in the market!

headline: Lots of entitled and well compensated employees working through chaos
pros: Tons of benefits, some that you will never had a need for, but it's nice to have the option. Top tier compensation.
cons: Get ready for lots of chaos mixed with a bit of attitude from it's entitled employees. The company is focused on growing and things (lots) fall through the cracks. As a result, multiple changes, lack of clear direction with minimal assistance or guidance from your manager, if any at all.

headline: Nice Benefits but Not True to Healthy Work/Life Balance They Promote
pros: The amenities are nice for full-time employees, but it feels like a smoke-screen almost. I feel like we're being blinded into happiness with all these things being thrown at us to take advantage of. I'm starting to see through them and realize what they are truly for...to make you think you are happy and have the best job, and work for the best company ever, when you really don't...they got us by the balls here...
cons: Laptop and phone each employee is given is not a perk, but a leash...you are always expected to be on them even when you are not at work trying to enjoy the life you are actually working for. Because they have issued you these items, there are no excuses.
response: In our 'move fast' and 'focus on impact' culture, we know it can be a challenge to find the right level of work/life integration. Please speak candidly with your Manager and HR Business Partner in order to share concerns and explore options. We hope you are able to spend time on the things that are most important to you.

headline: Mission-driven, huge impact, helping people
pros: People care about helping others and live by the company's values. Huge opportunity to learn. Great autonomy and flexibility for employees.
cons: On-calls shifts can be tough

headline: Internship SWE
pros: Decent perks. Fast-moving company. Nice location. There are plenty of tech talks present on campus that are nice to attend.
cons: People are reasonably self-absorbed and highly individualistic culture exists. Much work at this point (because of Facebook's size) remains highly incremental and menial in a sense.

headline: Landslide win over Google for career growth
pros:
I just left Google and joined Facebook, and felt so much happier. The reasons are:

1. The real impact
At Google I joined a team whose product is only used by less than 1000 people, and even for that product I was assigned to do a peripheral part, whose functionality actually doesn't matter at all. Just for that module, I had to write unit test for every silly part of the code, and took long iteration cycles. I admit those are good engineering coding trainings, however taking precious time in my life to work on something that doesn't matter is just a waste of my life.

In Facebook things just move so much faster. There are standard software engineering review process but not as rigid. Just during training (boot camp) weeks, I had tasks to change very important part of Facebook's core code, and the second day after I check-in my code, it got shipped to almost 1 billion people. As a software engineer I cannot recall a moment I felt better for my job.

Then I joined a team that's extremely important to Facebook's revenue. A mistake in the code I changed could cause Facebook million dollar a day. However Facebook just trusted us, allowed us making mistake and having quick iteration cycles to test ideas fast. If I make a coding mistake in my team in Google it might cost Google nothing in terms of revenue as my product was small, however the development process was so strict I could not have chance to try my innovations or test my ideas. But in Facebook that's all possible.

2. The organizational structure
Google's organization is now very structured and hierarchical. Facebook is having more layers, but the working style is still flat, and social-network style. Speaking to people in different teams, form an idea, lead a virtual team and complete it, this style is still valued. My boss is more like a mentor helping me navigating through the ideas, rather than an authority telling me what to do.
cons:
1. I don't quite like the office decoration style. A little bit stressful and factory like.
2. The compensation is better than Google but not as good as other smaller companies.
3. Despite good acquisitions for solidify the position in social media, social networks, there is still uncertainty about the future of this company.
response:
We're happy to hear that you are thriving at Facebook and have been making an impact from day 1. Being nimble and moving fast, much like a start-up but at such a large scale, is what makes our culture unique. Giving people the autonomy to be bold and work on making an impact just makes sense. 
--Your friends at Facebook

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Open, autonomous culture with broadly scoped roles. 
- Mission driven company to the core and everything we do is aligned around achieving this. 
- Company sets over the top ambitious goals and this ensures everyone is stretched and challenged in the best possible way.
- Dream team pairing of Sheryl & Mark - visionary leaders with integrity and 2 of the strongest operators out there.
cons: Having worked for 6+ years there has definitely been some cons along the way as we scaled the business but I honestly believe that Facebook has never been better, more challenging place to work than it is right now.
advice_to_mgmt: As we scale, keeping us focused around our mission and culture - this is what makes this place feel different and people want to stay to be a part of it all. Its more about the 'we' here than the 'me'.

headline: Good company
pros: Culture and benefit, lots of impact, smart people
cons: None that I can think of

headline: AVOID Publisher Solutions, otherwise fabulous place to work
pros: Mission-driven company with a decently open-and-transparent culture (except when you have feedback they don't want to hear--see below). The perks are phenomenal. For most teams, there is a clear path to personal success (again, see below for important caveat).
cons: The Publisher Solutions org has been in flux for over two years. I no longer have any confidence that the leadership knows what they are doing. Rather than helping their people identify and align on impactful projects, they are turned inwards, patting themselves on the back from the top down and only caring about posturing in their own careers. It's politics in the worst way, and can go unchecked at a company as large as Facebook. They systemically suppress the talents of people who do not buy into the secret club. It has not been my experience that this toxic culture exists outside of that org.
advice_to_mgmt: Talk to your employees--find out why some of your smartest people aren't having intended impact. Listen to your employees when they ask for help, and look into whether it indicates a broader, systemic issue.

headline: Great place to work but old time middle management a risk
pros: Great place to work, fantastic colleagues, developing yet supportive environment.
cons: Long time middle management who joined company at an early stage and no longer have the competence to run larger teams as the company grew.
advice_to_mgmt: Swap out non-performing middle management. Lots of lower level managers been around for too long without career progression since they reached their capacity goal. These stand in the way for higher performers.
response: We're glad you are surrounded by a supportive environment. Our people represent our culture. We are working hard to train our managers and enable growth, so we'll take this feedback and share it with internal teams. Thank you.

headline: Lots of potential with too many weak managers
pros: The benefits & perks are great, Facebook is obviously one of the best knows brands in the world. Lots of smart & genuinely great people. Challenging work.
cons: Zero career progression unless you're happy to spend a minimum of 3 years in the same role. Management in Recruiting are really poor which demotivates everyone and makes them feel as if they're not supported. Too many managers were promoted on tenure alone and are awful people managers.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire Recruiting Leads from outside the business.

headline: Mediocre
pros: The most attractive aspect of working at Facebook was the lay prestige. The salary was competitive and, of course, one of the big reasons to work there, but you can get that somewhere else relatively easily.
cons: The work itself was not very interesting, and there were a few months I got stuck doing absolutely abysmal maintenance work on old code. Among management, there are a few bad apples that can make working there less pleasant.
advice_to_mgmt: I left Facebook quite a while ago, and things change quickly, so I'm not sure how much of this advice is relevant but I can say a couple of things. Firstly, employees should be given more freedom over what kind of work they are doing. This can possibly be implemented in the form of 20% time personal projects or something like that. Secondly, high performers should be more publicly recognized.

headline: Great place to carve your career
pros: Amazing culture, flexibility, opportunity and the perks and benefits speak for themselves. The first place in an 11 year career that I've felt truly challenged and empowered to do my best work and think outside the box. The ability to get things done with little red tape is unparalleled.
cons: Little that i've experienced - tough place to keep outperforming yourself when surrounded by such smart and talented people.
advice_to_mgmt: Try to stay close to the culture as possible as we continue to grow.

headline: Good company
pros: Lots of opportunities and amazing work culture
cons: Work life balance cane become a problem

headline: Amazing!
pros: Great team! Great experience! Love it!
cons: I don't have any cons as of yet on the job.

headline: HRBP
pros: A compelling mission, amazing people who raise your game, a fantastic work environment, and a culture that allows you to be yourself.
cons: We're in fast growth which means you have to be prepared to keep up with scaling our products, services, and teams. The good part of this is great career opportunity but, for people who don't know how to scale, it requires new muscles.

headline: Excellent
pros: Benefits, growing fast, with lots of smart people
cons: Flat organization, growing fast, becoming quite big

headline: Best Place To Work. Period.
pros: Open culture. Ability to grow, fast. Transparency. As amazing as the perks are, the day to day of Facebook is what keeps me here. This is the best place I have ever worked, bar none.
cons: None. This is truly a special place to work.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing. This is a special place.

headline: Good software internship
pros: Super flexible hours, casual and transparent culture, really smart and fun people. Great food and intern events. They really care about their interns, and will work hard to set you up with a project you'll like.
cons: Not for introverts. You have to have a facebook to work at facebook (self-explanatory), but they also place a lot of emphasis on being friendly with the team, going to social events, etc.
advice_to_mgmt: Addressing some long-term issues, like cleaning up the codebase and removing/replacing legacy code, would make it much easier to build new features quickly.

headline: Facebook
pros: Facebook is awesome to work for
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Coming up on a year employed, and I'm finally getting my sea legs...
pros: Incredible group of talented, creative, and motivated people. Company with a vision and a set of products that you can get behind -- morally and technically. Plentiful opportunities for advancement. Creativity is very highly appreciated.
cons:
Sometimes Facebook feels like barely organized chaos. But it somehow works! A huge part of the culture is bottom-up -- i.e., the day-to-day, week-to-week direction really does flow from the employees much more than the management.

It took a while to get used to the open spaces and the diverse campus locations, but I'm used to it now (a year in) and again, and it doesn't really get in the way that much.
advice_to_mgmt: Provide more transparency in terms of vision. Let people know what is going on in your heads more often. The townhalls are great, but I'm talking about VPs and directors, and not just within their own orgs. Short posts, without lots of wordsmithing. Keep the ICs in the loop in your visions!
response: Hi there - thank you for sharing! Transparency, feedback, and authentic conversations are very important to our culture and our mission to connect the world. This should be practiced by everyone at Facebook whether individual contributor or people manager. We will continue to shape our culture with feedback like this, so we can keep improving. Thanks again.

headline: What a great place to work
pros:
There are many, but here are a few of my favorites:

- Play to your strengths. Too many companies and too many people work on improving weaknesses, in hopes of becoming well-rounded. This is fine, but often the better strategy is to play to your strengths, where employees do more of what they're good at, and less of what they're not good at, in a diverse team. I've never seen this done as well as at Facebook.

- Moving fast at scale. There are so many tools and frameworks to help you still move fast, as fast as any startup, that's it awesome. So impressive at Facebook's scale.

- World-class team. I know this is said often and loses meaning, but it's true here. Every single person is both smart and nice, a rare combination.

- They care about the right things, and don't care about the wrong things. Both parts of this are important. Too many companies sweat the small stuff that doesn't matter, e.g. who's invited to a meeting or whatever. At Facebook, everyone is just trying to make a positive impact, without care for politics etc.
cons:
- Things change fast. If you're not at ease with change, or if you're seeking a place that never changes, this is not the right company for you. This includes projects, tools, technologies, teams...

- There are multiple technical ways of doing most things. It's not always clear which is the best way, so you have to ask people. I think that's actually OK as you get to know your colleagues. But if you're the kind of person who wants perfect documentation for everything, this is not the place for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Stick to what you're doing, it's working :)
response: You've highlighted some of the key things that make our culture unique. We are so glad you are thriving in this fast-paced environment. Thank you for taking the time to provide feedback!

headline: Best Company Ever
pros: Mission. Leadership. Values are lived, not just talked about. Good compensation, benefits and perks.
cons: Commute is long from San Francisco. Other than that, I really don't have any cons.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep looking for ways to maintain the culture even with the growth. Keep valuing feedback - it's such a big part of what makes this place tick.

headline: Facebook research scientist
pros: free food, and smart people working with
cons: more engineering and workload is pretty high

headline: workplace
pros: fun challenging ability to grow mentorship
cons: time consuming fast paced busy work

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Staff are treated very well.
cons: Contracts aren't extended past 11 months.

headline: Intern
pros: The supportive network, the collaborative feel, the startup environment, the talented people, the food, the other perks, the work ethic, the organization, the mission and so much more
cons: Everyone has incredibly different experiences based on team/manager, which may create unrelatable experiences. Move fast is no longer in play

headline: This is the best company I've worked for
pros: Mutual respect; egalitarianism; meritocracy; flexibility. This place makes employees feel welcome and relevant, regardless of their age and gender. What matters is how good you are at doing your job. Everything else is irrelevant. I had some reservations about the the open floor plan, but it actually works to energize the people. You can hear the brains buzzing :-)
cons: The open floor plan has a downside: if someone comes in sick with a cold or flu, its too easy to pass it on to others. It is addressed very thoughtfully though, so it's not such a big deal.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Good salary and way above average benefits; work is demanding but very satisfying. It's a place for doers, aiming for technical excellence.
cons: none, really. It's an excellent company to work for.
advice_to_mgmt: focus on culture

headline: Fantastic Experience
pros: The benefits from working at FB are amazing. They are not just throwing money at employees on useless items. They are thoughtful and trying to make people more productive and healthier with the items they provide.
cons: It is a very young company. The benefit is that it creates an aggressive and flexible style of working. On the flip side if you like consistency and predictability - this is not the place for you.

headline: Great company to work at
pros: Massively interesting projects, lots of places to get involved.
cons: Way too many politics for a tech company.
advice_to_mgmt: Encourage good managers, not just high functioning ICs thrust into management roles.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great perks , dental, insurance, food
cons: Some weeks are longer than others, but that's normal.
advice_to_mgmt: I like the culture of being open.

headline: Best decision I ever made was to join Facebook.
pros:
Autonomy - managers are trained to empower, not micromanage

Great workplace - all of the perks

Freedom - make no mistake the workload is intense. But I have the freedom to work on my own terms and make my own decisions about balancing work and life

Meaning - you are working on products that impact so many peoples' lives. It's truly a once in a lifetime opportunity.
cons:
Intense workload - you need to be the type of person who can handle this (most Facebookers can).

Fast growing org means sometimes the right processes are not in place, or processes are broken, which can lead to churn/frustration/breaking things. This is par for the course in every fast growth company.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to nourish what is special about Facebook. Be careful and measured about implementing processes, so that Facebook's work culture doesn't turn into that of other tech giants (bureaucratic, political, all that bad stuff)

headline: Best place I have ever worked
pros: Great culture and benefits. The company leadership are really open, honest and promote venerability and failure.
cons: Fast paced company where sometimes keeping up can be overwhelming
advice_to_mgmt: keep up the good work!

headline: Internship
pros: Great benefits, compensation, area. Food is absolutely amazing
cons: Work/Life balance isn't as described. Most interns I met were working 12 hour days, and this seems like its the norm for some teams.

headline: 5 years in and still loving it!
pros:
- Hard problems
- Strong management/mentorship
- Tons of resources
- Strong company values
- Excellent executive leadership (Mark/Sheryl/Schrep/Cox)
- Focus on diversity
- Food and general benefits are top of the charts
- Flexible work schedule
cons: - Commute is O.K.; I find it productive but friends who get carsick, less ideal
advice_to_mgmt: As we scale, don't lose sight of the core values.

headline: Mission Driven. Impact from Day One.
pros: People here care deeply about the mission to connect the world. Everything we do connects to the mission and Mark talks about the mission in practically every talk. We encourage people to be their authentic selves. There's no "work you" and "personal you." There's just "you." People care deeply about each other here. And you have the ability to make an impact beginning on your first day. Some places it takes 6 months or a year to make meaningful progress, but here you jump in and make a difference right after orientation.
cons: It's really fast paced and things change quickly. You have to be able to ride the waves and adapt quickly. So many people are grateful to be part of such an amazing company, but there are a few bad eggs who ruin the culture because they takers, not givers. We need to serve more humble pie in the cafes.
advice_to_mgmt: Remember to teach employees the importance of gratitude.

headline: User Operation Specialist
pros: Great atmosphere - people come from all background. This has been the most diverse campus I've worked on so far. There's plenty of resources around to help you shape up and improve your current skills. Free food is always a bonus.
cons: Gained 10 pounds after starting here. As a contractor, it's extremely difficult to become a full time employee, but at least you get some experience and you're able to put a great name on your resume.

headline: Great Company
pros: Awesome people，awesome environment，nice and competent people
cons: very stressful, bottom percent of people get kicked
advice_to_mgmt: nope

pros: Fast-paced work environment that is fun to be in!

headline: Software Engineer

headline: great working here
pros: Less bureaucracy than other similar-sized companies, open culture, internal mobility and encouragement to try out different types of projects, lots of development- and learning opportunities. High-quality coworkers -- everyone tries hard and the environment is generally collaborative. I am constantly being challenged by big, open-ended problems. Firm generally tries to be customer-focused and to do good within the constraints of being a for-profit company.
cons: Perhaps this is how it is at most companies, but team priorities/goals often shift fast. Team goals tend to be a bit siloed and different teams sometimes work at cross-purposes.
advice_to_mgmt: Greater coordination across teams to enable more "global" rather than team-specific optimization.

headline: good stuff

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great culture and people to work with. Amazing mission and leadership.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Amazing place so far
pros: Smart people, fast paced and decentralized work environment which gives immense freedom to people and teams.
cons: I came from a corporates which are not so fast paced and it is difficult onboarding with facebook. But honestly it is worth it

headline: sexist idiots
pros:
Great young vibrant team
Decent money but Dublin so expensive
cons:
High pressure
Sexist managers with such a disregard for females
response: This is not the environment we promote and strongly encourage you to reach out to your HR Business Partner to discuss any experiences which are out of alignment with our culture and core values. Thank you for your feedback.

headline: Great place to be!
pros: Great perks, people, vision of the company, freedom, compensation
cons: Limited horizontal career mobility if you want to switch teams.

headline: Incredible Place to Work
pros: Facebook moves unbelievably quickly from an engineering perspective, and there's an electricity in the workplace, driven by the company's mission, which is unbeatable.
cons: Career progression opportunities aren't completely clear.

headline: Media Partnerships
pros: Great benefits, work culture and management team.

headline: Best place to work, ever!
pros: Phenomenally smart people to work with which raises your own bar every day, and a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction whenever you do something impactful at work. Hard to beat the benefits
cons: No cons yet, just don't get too big and lose track of what employees care about. Hard to share ideas with the entire organization

headline: All the tools to have impact
pros: Working at Facebook is great: wonderful opportunities, great perks, competitive salaries, an open and flexible work environment. Your voice will be heard
cons: Professional growth and career paths are not clearly defined. Promotion opportunities depend more on reorgs and team growth than merit.
advice_to_mgmt: Clear ownership of projects is necessary. Internal team competition hurts us.

headline: Technical Recruiter
pros:
+Impact
+Working on really cool stuff
+Ownership
+Culture
+Future of the company looks really positive and bright
+Making the world more open and connected
+You learn a lot from really awesome people around you
cons: -Recruiters aren't allowed to work remote.

headline: Awesome company
pros: Great office environment. Advancement opportunities for skilled contractors. Free snacks and meals!
cons: Perhaps an irregular work week.
advice_to_mgmt: None. Great company!

headline: Love Facebook
pros:
The perks are amazing. 
Transparency and openness of policy, leadership, and code base. Props to leadership admitting to their faults/failures and working to learn from them.
Supporting your growth - personal and professional.
cons:
New managers in transition, but that's inevitable.
Pressure to work more - this is very team dependent. Despite efforts to say work however you like, if many people on your team is working throughout the night, it's hard not to feel the pressure.
Open office space isn't for everyone - where's my flow state? This has improved with more and more rooms being allocated for personal use and ability to update work status. 
Seattle office is older than MPK.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up. Try to bolster some of the extra programs in the Seattle office. i.e. volunteer groups seem pretty dead here.

headline: data engineer
pros:
The only pros I can think of is not really job related. The Disney like setting is good to bring your kids and family to if they are visiting. But the novelty wears of after 2-3 visits. The summer picnic parties used to be fun before but now it is too crowded and held at cheap locations - like this year it was at one of the piers in SF. 
As a data engineer you can try to understand the topology of the data systems and see how they work. You can look at the code base and see how they all fit together. See how the log streaming works and how it makes its way into the data storage. These are not job related activities but it will help you in your interview at your next job.
cons:
There are several. Note that the role specific ones are only for data engineers. What I have found is that there is a lot of difference in the way different groups function, so if you join as a SWE or as a product manager, your experience may be different.

1. The work environment is very open and very noisy. There is absolutely no privacy. This becomes more of a bother here because there are so many people now in all of their buildings. The only time when I was able to do any serious work was when I was working from home.
2. As a data engineer, you will be working with a very old version of Hive (0.10 I think). This is the version even before the one with windowing clauses. I was used to working with a better version that also had CBO and I found this limiting. Not only that, if you do this for a year or two you will be at a disadvantage when you switch jobs.
3. The data engineers are at the lowest rung of the pecking order. Some call them 2nd tier engineers. I call them data peons. They do not get any say in the kind of work they get to do. Any grunt work can be passed on to you and because of the way the review system works, they can screw you if you show any displeasure. An example of this is the data visualizations. The data engineer is expected to do that. I never had to do that before. So you will be spending a lot of time doing housekeeping work like making sure the pipelines run, making sure the font and color choices you made on the dashboards are pleasing to the analysts who sit on top of you in the pecking order. And to add insult to injury, the visualization tool is a home grown one and none of the skills you get from using it are going to help you in a future job i.e. if you plan to continue doing visualizations.
4. Data peons are treated differently as compared to software engineers. Whereas on occasion the software engineers get to work exclusively on different projects for up to a month, there is no such options for data peons. So mobility is very very limited.
5. The performance review system is stacked against data peons. Because they are at the lowest rung, most of the people reviewing them are analysts or above. So the analysts are the overlords even when some of them are absolute idiots. The only ones who can survive in this system are ones with a servile attitude and with mediocre talent and ambition.

Some of these are because of recent org changes. A lot of the people I know who joined around the same time as me have left the company.
advice_to_mgmt: Even though Mark is one of the most open and humble CEOs I have even worked for, there is a lot of abuse and harassment happening in the lower levels of the Org chart. I think you should listen closely to complaints that are made to the HR and review them.

headline: Not happy
pros: Lots of perks, many smart people
cons: Inexperienced management and already full of politics

headline: Marketing Expert
pros: Training is great, great experience working across all business verticals.
cons: little to no advancement opportunities for those who aren't in the "old boys club"

headline: Overall ok
pros: high salary, good environment, training are good
cons: bad management, high turnover rate

headline: Probably the best job I'll ever have.
pros: The move fast culture and insanely high ratio of competent co-workers make Facebook one of the most satisfying and exciting places to work in the world. Easily one of the best workplaces where you feel pampered and privileged to have a job there. The food options are vast. You'll never go hungry. There's plenty of interesting spaces around the office to meet, chill, or focus. Easy access to IT and resources removes roadblocks from your workday. Projects and tooling are shared openly within the company and knowledge transfer is highly encouraged. Aggressive device refresh policy (every 2 years). Zuck Q&A on Fridays. The ability to easily float between teams makes finding something new that you're passionate about is much more likely and keeps your employment fresh.
cons: Your desk area can often get loud. The company often doesn't follow through enough on released products, discontinuing them within 1-2 years. You must come into the office at least 80% of the time usually, which means you must relocate near an office.
advice_to_mgmt: Open offices in more affordable areas that don't have extremely high real estate costs. Have succession plans well in advance for products if they don't work out.
response: Thanks so much for the thoughtful feedback. We strive to work hard and smart to achieve our shared mission. As we continue to grow, we are committed to improving the ways we support our employees, so they can focus on the work of connecting the world.

headline: Phenomenal Company
pros:
Amazing Food – 3 cafeterias, 8 restaurants, and continually stocked microkitchens are fantastic

Amenities – Facebook is beyond generous with the benefits and amenities provided ranging from generous vacation days, on-campus spa, on campus doctor and dentist office, wonderful transportation accommodations 

People – Some of the most intelligent and nicest people I have had the absolute pleasure to work with. Everyone is welcoming and helpful and more than happy to work with you with zero feelings of competition or hostility. 

Transparency – Facebook is 100% transparent internally with its employees. Ranging from being able to browse the entire codebase no matter what team you're on, to being able to ask Mark any question you have at weekly Q&A.
cons: Work/Life Balance – Speaking as an intern, you feel implicitly pressured to spend as many hours as you can on campus to leave a good impression as well as work on your project. This can lead to many hours a week at the office.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work. The transparency is beyond appreciated, the food is phenomenal, the programs are great, and the employees make it an absolutely wonderful place to work.

headline: Hi there
pros: One of the greatest companies the world has ever seen. Zuckerberg for President 2016. Love this place. It's just great and friendly.
cons: Nothing, can't say a bad word about them. Lol. It's just funny they are so good. Great benefits and great office. Here I go tooting their horn again.
advice_to_mgmt: Lower salary. I was making too much money. Save some for the fishes. Lol! The social network was a great movie. Haha, fun.

headline: Amazing
pros: Great place to work, amazing perks and people. Couldn't imagine myself anywhere else
cons: No cons, the stereotype of working in tech is overrated
advice_to_mgmt: The best

headline: Great place to work overall. Getting too big and complacent as it grows
pros:
Great place to work overall. 
Takes great care of employees
Best perks!
Best culture
Best CEO
cons:
Getting too big.
Getting complacent and hiring bar is getting lower.
Lots of cliques at work
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on keeping the edge and keeping the culture !

headline: Perks are nice, work was boring
pros: Three straight meals, great coworkers, a motivated team, cool offices downtown

headline: The Internship Experience Of My Dreams
pros:
- Everyone, no matter how "high up" they are at the company, is very willing to help with whatever question you might have. You can message anyone at any time and they will generally get back to you within the hour.
- As an intern your opinions and ideas are valued. I came up with my own product and feature ideas on the side, and I was able to implement them and test them publicly.
- The company culture is very open. (Almost) everything at Facebook is no secret - Mark is willing to answer any question you might have about company direction and stance at the weekly Q&As, and at any point you can ask what people are working on, and they're willing to share.
- The projects you're able to work on are high impact projects more often than not.
- Everyone is passionate about their work and incredibly good at what they do. I learned a crazy amount this past summer.
cons:
- The work culture is largely self-driven. There's no particular structure or strict schedule for getting work done, so if you're not self-motivated, you could fall behind without much consistent feedback for your performance.
- Work-life balance can be a little unhealthy at times. There felt like there was a bit of pressure to work even while at home, because a lot of people do.
advice_to_mgmt: Not much. My experience was absolutely incredible, and I learned a LOT this summer. Maybe there could be a better system for suggesting ideas and new projects - I felt like I came up with a handful of cool, slightly bigger feature ideas this summer but they often wouldn't be escalated to the project managers or receive any feedback, and just go unnoticed.

headline: Software Engineer Intern
pros:
1. Flat management. Easy to reach out to everybody even as an intern.
2. Everyone is friendly and willing to help.
3. Intern have the same right as pull time and do the same thing as full time.
cons: Your evaluation rely a lot on your peers.

headline: mangemant
pros: easy to use facebook and is good for publication

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great benefits, culture, mission. There is a lot to love about working at Facebook. Most employees believe strongly in the mission.
cons: Commute from SF is tough, and manager support is pretty hit or miss depending on the person. You have to stick up for yourself and be proactive if you want to learn.

headline: Don't speak up. Sit quietly and don't rock the boat. Be happy
pros: Looks good on resume. Free food
cons: The customer is a commodity. Complain or try and expose the scams advertisers are engaging in and you are removed.
advice_to_mgmt: Customer service is not to be dispensed with a computer algorithm. Real people exist. It matters

headline: A Once Amazing Culture is Slipping Away
pros: Amazing amount of perks - food, a truly "frictionless" IT department, etc. The benefits package is the best I've ever seen and gets re-examined every year to adapt to the changing company population. Facebook, the company, is amazing. What the company is doing to connect the world is something that is truly astonishing and amazing. Being able to work for an employer that is changing the world before our eyes is something not many people will ever get the chance to say they were a part of!
cons: The culture of some of the departments is slipping away faster than most people would like to admit. The company is becoming more and more "corporate" with more politics settling in. This ranges from managers hiring friends and old colleagues, completely bypassing our interview process, to putting "policies" in place against company culture that puts unnecessary roadblocks in place, slowing down productivity. The company is growing, which can be appreciated, but the amount of emphasis that is being put on us that we need to move to being "more corporate" is completely against what the company was built on.
advice_to_mgmt: TRUST your employees. A little bit of trust goes a long way. This isn't the government or a large corporation - this is Facebook - a once choice employer who is getting eroded by managers doing their best to build an empire and put as many layers of insulation between them and their lowest ranking employees.

headline: The greatest place ever
pros: I've been blown away by how incredible this company is. From its openness to its diversity, Facebook has truly surpassed all tech companies in terms of culture, perks, and employee lifestyle. As a software engineer, I've learned, grown, and made an incredible impact in just a few months.
cons: I seriously can't think of a single negative thing about Facebook. I couldn't see myself working at any other company.
advice_to_mgmt: Micromanagement doesn't exist. I get credit for what I do, and there's a pretty clear understanding of my role and room for growth.
response: Thank you for sharing your Facebook experience. It's great to hear that you feel challenged, energized and recognized for the work that you do!

headline: Facebook free launch and snack
pros: satisfaction eating need and it is a motivation
cons: it will let employee increase weigh

headline: Love it!
pros:
Moves fast. 
Work with smart people. 
Very less politics.
Open culture.
High bar for candidates even as company as grown.
cons: Moves too fast for some of the teams that should be doing more research.
response: Thanks for your review. We're so glad you love working at Facebook :) Move fast, be bold, focus on impact, build social value, be open -- these values drive how we work. We are happy you see that every day!

headline: Delivers promised other companies make
pros: Many companies I've worked for talk about access, enablement, open environment, work/life balance, frequent reviews and promotion. FB actually does this: almost anyone can see code for and fix almost any problem. Reviews happen twice a year, and my manager brings up the promotion track more than I do. They aggressively push giving your family the off-work time, and plan events which either include small family members or give non-parents a good steam-blow-off as well
cons: There's a bit of fiefdom but very little. Sometimes hard to get code-review. We move a little fast for documentation sometimes, and there are often 5 ways to do that one thing and they're very similar with cute animal names.
advice_to_mgmt: Very pleased with the company. Showing concern and continuing to invest in and grow your people is the best for retention. Maybe more roles that cross-pollinate work and all-hands to share our work. Incentivize merges and tech debt burn-down
response: As we say at Facebook, "feedback is a gift," so we really appreciate your review. Growing our people by investing in their strengths is one way we will continue to take care of our employee community. We agree that collaboration, employee recognition and disciplined iteration are keys to achieving our mission to connect the world.

headline: Great place to work

advice_to_mgmt: it may be time to grow people internally to continue attracting great people for hiring and organization purpose.
