headline: BiZ Apps Team in Facebook
pros:
Its an amazing company to work. Though the team is not.
People will be given option to choose the team after they are hired. 
The Company shuttles are extremely helpful in working even while we commute.(No Fun) 
The IT Support is extremely quick and very helpful.
The Food and rest are very yummy. Every day You might have to think what cuisine should I choose today. What ever you choose, It will just be there on campus.
cons:
I was into BizApps team at Facebook. Facebook is an amazing company to work but the team is not.

All the above was only to an extent and the critical part which had really kept me under pressure was

There were three people who were asked to develop three Modules. later they asked me to integrate the other Modules into mine. What others developed is just an initial version and UI, Javascript wasn`t following any standard. Later when I was integrating I had to rework everything from level 0. project manager, Manager, Team Lead, UI Expert were all supervising my work. When ever they pass by my desk, they would ask me to make few changes may it be to the Layouts, data to be displayed etc. the worst part is that their opinions do not match at all. 
for instance .. Project Manager would stop by my desk and asks me to change the layout and I obey and customize the layout to include that change. Later team lead would stop by and says "This is disgusting Layout. better change it. when I change it taking his suggestions. Manager would stop by and says its the worst that he has ever seen in his life and asks me to include his recommendations. Later UI expert comes and commands me not to follow instructions of any others and to just follow his recommendations as he is the UI expert. When I do that Others (Project Manager, Manager etc) hate the changes and I was evaluated low in performance. 

In the due course I was evaluated low in performance and I was blamed for missing the dead line. 

I did try to convey my situation to people but no action was taken.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros:
Overall, my experience working at Facebook was awesome. Lot of smart people, interesting projects, dynamic company, great leadership, great perks, etc.
I really liked feeling that we're all in the same boat, one huge team working on a common objective.
cons:
If you get a bad manager it can be hard to deal with.
The commute is a pain if you live in SF. The shuttles are great, it's just that the 101 gets worse everyday. But of course, at least is closer than Google or other companies.
The company is growing fast, so it's getting harder to have a lot of impact.
advice_to_mgmt: Sometimes people that are too young and inexperienced moves to management without proper support and it ends up being really bad for their reportees.

headline: Great Place to work

thoughtful management 

Career opportunity is definitely better than Google but fewer than other start ups.
But a lot of great people to learn from.

response: We appreciate you taking the time to provide feedback. In our 'move fast' and 'focus on impact' culture, we know it can be a challenge to find the right level of work/life integration. We hope you are able to spend time on the things that are most important to you.

Upper management, You charge facebook $30+ an hour and pay employees 12.75 an hour - nice hustle!

advice_to_mgmt: Don't miss 1 on 1s. Prioritize the career of your employees and make sure you they are happy with the work that they are doing

headline: Sunny with a chance of lowballs
pros:
- brilliant people all around, a pleasure to work with the best minds in the industry
- recognition for the work you do does exist, even if it only means a pat on the back
- work/life balance does exist, as long as you get the work done
- your work is impacting product that 1.7 billion people use
- amazing perks
cons:
- recruiters will low ball you on the initial offer as if their life depends on it. Even though they may have 1000 RSUs to grant they will deliberately start with a 700 hoping the unsuspecting candidate gulps it up in hopes of working for the "best company to work for". 
- There is unprecedented growth, which means high volume of hiring, which means C grade people are creeping in, including peers and upper management coming in from companies like Microsoft bringing their big company (read: 
- With great minds come bloated egos. Egoists and self proclaimed war heroes abound. God forbid you happen to cross paths with these people, but if you do, then be prepared for a political poop storm of epic proportions.
- Managers are good only for 1:1s and calibrations, they dont actually drive ideas and projects, engineers do. Its easy to settle into a bubble and lose interest in the work unless you take the initiative to explore other options on a regular basis.
advice_to_mgmt: Try to cut out the red tape as much as possible. Invest more in recruiting efforts in order to bring in top tier (and modest) people in, its not the directors that build the company but the white collar workers.
response: Thanks for sharing your experience. As we continue to grow, bringing in and engaging top talent is critical. We will continue to be focused on moving fast and removing red tape wherever possible. Keep the feedback coming, so we can keep ourselves honest.

headline: Depends on what you're looking for in your career
pros: Amazing benefits and great people.
cons: Becoming a very large company with politics. Getting harder to get things done quickly. Some areas of the company are pretty reactive rather than proactive in their work.

headline: The Happiest Place on Earth!!
pros:
I just started working at FB ~2 months ago, but I already love it so much! There is so much transparency from day 1, it was actually a little alarming at first. But it's awesome to get to see what everyone is working on and to be able to easily contact anyone in the company. Even though the company is pretty big, you still get the same family-like feeling of a small startup. Everyone is very approachable and helpful, so it's not at all intimidating to contact your POC to get help you need. It's a very supportive and healthy work environment! 

Other pros: Q&A with Mark every Friday (he is so funny and brilliant!), delicious food everywhere (I already gained 10 lbs), beautiful campus, so many amenities and perks, brilliant and kind coworkers, really fun woodshop classes, I could go on and on!
cons: Information is not very well organized. For a new person it can be a little intimidating to navigate and find the info you need, so that takes some getting used to.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work!!

headline: Data entry
pros: Communication, and support system from co-workers or higher ups. Very competitive and challenging when it comes to getting a lot of customers.
cons: A lot of work, and moving around if you don't like walking around too much. And sometimes you might not get a break for lunch.

headline: Facebook
pros: Great colleagues, amazing atmosphere on a workplace, very nice environment.
cons: The project I was working on has ended and they couldn’t offer me next cooperation.

headline: A mixed review!
pros:
- A leading tech player in the world committed to making the world more open and connected. Everything Facebook does will impact people in a massive way. Very credible & humbling to be a part of such a journey

- You're taken care of. You really don't worry about day to day things which otherwise eat up your time. The benefits & perks have got you covered

- Bright, Young & Passionate people to work with. You don't want to be a part of a group which has had a conventional approach to things. Peeps at facebook come from different parts of the country, unique experiences & have a zest to perform.
cons:
- The Hyd office is moving towards a "Contractors-Only" office. The best people have moved out & the best projects have been re-allocated to other offices. There's no actual meaty problem to solve otherwise

- People don't question (enough). As a an employee I remember one of the biggest culture drivers & work was people being really passionate about problems to solve. I guess that fire has burned out. 

- Weak Management. An employee would expect a manager to advocate for his / her projects globally. And that has gone down drastically.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Re-brand Hyd office in the global scenario & get more challenging stuff to work on
- Recognize the fact that your best people are leaving (slowly & steadily)

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great benefits. Big name. High impact.
cons: Lots of politics. Big company where you only focus on one thing.
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure people actually work.

cons: Work 10 HR days, no break no lunch no comp time micromanagement staffing issues denials of necessary time off-denial of funerals, expect Saturday and Sunday work weeks, no work from home, but WFH is allowed if building is closed due to blizzards. RUN- don't walk!!! It's a bait and switch!
advice_to_mgmt: WAH, treat us like humans- Matrix is a computer! We need to eat, have bodily functions!Staffing is way understaffed. The bait and switch was just plain wrong!!!

headline: PhD Intern at Facebook

response: Thanks for spending your internship with Facebook. We're glad to hear you worked on interesting work with learning opportunities. We'll share your feedback with our internal teams to further enhance the experience for future interns.

headline: Best company to work, awesome work culture with high value
pros:
Good salary
Lot of opportunities to work on different technologies.
cons: Couldn't find any cons till now.
advice_to_mgmt: None
response: Thanks for sharing! We want to be a place where people can do their most meaningful work and are happy you are finding that here.

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros:
I love the mission behind this company. It's inspiring what people here are trying to do, to connect the world. And I love how people move boldly toward that mission. 

Considering the size of the company, it
runs really smoothly and surprisingly with democratic practices. And the diversity of culture here is amazing, at the same time extremely humbling, because for someone who grew up in a western dominant culture, you realize that you had developed tunnel vision.
cons: Facebook is not as "corporate" as other corporation, but it's still corporate. If you are used to a startup culture where your work is automatically visible without much effort, here, you're expected to speak up to get visibility.
advice_to_mgmt: I'm eagerly awaiting to see how you make the company mission into a reality.
response: Thanks for taking a moment to share your experience. Our mission is central to everything we do, and we are as excited as you are to make it a reality. Being non-hierarchical and ensuring everyone has a voice is a cultural characteristic we will preserve through our growth. Glad to hear that you are seeing this come through daily.

headline: Good, but still a job.
pros: Well known perks are awesome (food, medical etc.), a lot of smart people and fun things to do if you find the time, bragging rights, ability to escalate friends' problems with FB.
cons: High pressure to perform, focus on impact means that even doing a good job on a project doesn't mean you would be commended, review feedback cycles are a drain, zero appreciation for quality, bug fixing or assisting others - engineers are only assessed by new features that can be shown to provide measurable impact to a metric that management cares about. Codebase is messy due to a lot of people (especially inexperienced) moving fast.

headline: Amazing company, lots of work!
pros: Compensation, benefits, perks, shuttles, intelligent people. It's quite inspiring to work under Mark Zuckerberg as well - he truly is a great leader and is the heart and soul of the company.
cons: They keep you busy - achieving work/life balance is challenging, but during such a heavy growth phase, it's somewhat understandable. Lots of pressure as well - everyone around you is so intelligent and hard-working.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Open, friendly, challenging environment. It's hard to believe that a company this big still genuinely feels like a startup but it truly does. The leadership works hard to remove obstacles to people doing their best work, and creating a culture where individual opinions are valued to drive innovation. You are encouraged to move fast and it's okay to fail if you're trying to push the limits and do something new (as long as it's back up with data/metrics/etc.). People are genuinely nice, collaborative, and so smart that you're constantly in a state of learning. London office has people from over 50 countries so great chance to meet some of the smartest people from around the world.
cons: Work/life balance is a challenge but something able to be managed with communication and support from your manager. As with any global company (especially one in such a period of rapid growth), there are growing pains around how to communicate locally vs. globally. London does hugely important work, building and shipping their own products. However Headquarters still think in a very US-centric way, this is something we're all working on.
advice_to_mgmt: Think globally and beyond the bubble of the Silicon Valley.
response: Thank you for contributing to our growth and strengthening our culture. As we continue to scale, being globally-minded and locally-relevant will be even more important. Do continue to provide this feedback to your manager, teams, and groups. We'll also share this with our internal teams.

headline: Engineering Manager

headline: High competition, a lot of bad quality projects

cons: Technology stack of the company is very specific. Be sure to select proper project, and not some legacy stuff

headline: Great place to work and advance beyond your
pros: Very good culture, smart people, fun atmosphere, and tremendous food options!
cons: Any position here is for self starters and motivated people.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing and thank you very much for what you've built.

headline: A incredible place to work for
pros: I've been in multiple tech companies so far and I must say that Facebook really does an amazing job at putting its employee in the best position to make them successful. We have the perfect workplace, our career is the main focus of our managers and diversity is not only encourage, but actively advocate (really, the initiative in term of gender equality, the fight against ethnical or confessional based bias here is fuel with so much energy that it should be a standard in modern companies). Also, the well-known CEO really has a plan and is totally transparent about it. I would definitively work here.
cons: Sometimes, I must admit that the all motivational aspect of the culture is a little bit exaggerated, however, most of those great principles "aim higher, don't be afraid to do something..." are actually enforced so, all in all, it is not a big issue and it's align with the company culture.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on the good job, do not let the growing size of the company change the culture.
response: Thank you for your feedback and contributions to Facebook. We do believe in doing what we say, especially when it comes to giving people the power to share. As we grow, we will continue to nurture the best parts of our culture. Thanks again!

headline: Best work place
pros: Happy work place with free food . Great team and scope of learning more.
cons: less salary for contractors and they are given long term.

headline: Pretty good but not ideal if contingent/contract
pros:
The autonomy - the freedom to do work at a fast pace and little bureaucratic barriers.
The food - there's such a wide variety of breakfast, lunch, dinners, happy hours, drinks, and snacks.
The culture - this term is thrown around a lot but Facebook is very unique. it's almost utopian the way people come together to solve problems. not just work but social problems as well. Ex. the black lives matter conversations.
cons: Contingent employees are treated the same as FTE's for the most part. But you will constantly be reminded you're NOT a Facebook employee. There will be many occasions where contingent employees will be excluded to FTE functions and benefits.
advice_to_mgmt: Do more for the contingent workforce in terms of inclusion, because there is an unspoken level of animosity whenever there's a big company function that excludes contingent employees.

headline: A good place to work at

As many people are unexperienced, professionalism can be lost sometimes.

headline: HR Admin- Austin
pros: Fun, exciting, challenging, dynamic, a lot of smart people, good training offered, free food and amenities. Good growth opportunities, some genuinely good people there
cons: The people in the Austin office are brutal. I felt like I was in high school again. They bash each other, gossip and belittle 'outsiders' or people they don't know. I overheard the 'senior' employees belittling me and making fun of a physical condition I have SEVERAL times. They smile to your face but they are passive aggressive and outright mean. And I performed very well at my job, loved my team in CA, and loved the company. But some of those 'lifetime' FB people are poisoning the culture. I had to leave after a year. And good luck telling anyone. It's career suicide
advice_to_mgmt: Hold everyone accountable for how they treat others, especially people who are different, people coming from different cities and people with physical and social challenges.

pros: Best of the best. It is a dream come tru

advice_to_mgmt: Keep kllling it.

advice_to_mgmt: Salaries and Benefits need to match the MPK office in all of facebook's other offices around the world. Currently UK salaries are roughly less than MPK offices by 20%
response: Thanks for sharing your Facebook experience. We want to be a place where our employees have the freedom to create and focus on meaningful work. As for salaries and benefits, we design those in alignment with each respective country and market.

headline: Great engineering org
pros: Facebook trusts its engineers. We get free food, access to technology as and when it would help our job, a good working environment, and the ability to regularly move from team to team to prevent burnout and ensure that we've spread our knowledge widely. Lots of flexibility in working hours helps, too.
cons: You need to take a good grip on your work-life balance - if you want to be first in, you'll be arriving before 7am, while if you want to be last out, you won't leave before midnight, and there's no-one who'll necessarily stop you being both first in and last out.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep track of the jealousy that's beginning to show up - there are cases popping up on internal messaging systems where, stripped of the fancy language, people are basically saying "those guys want/are taking something, surely that can't be allowed?!?" Better to emphasise that we can afford to provide what people need.
response: Taking care of our people so they can focus on the work of making the world more open and connected is our daily focus. Help keep our culture grounded and unique by providing this feedback.

headline: Facebook actually cares about keeping their employees happy
pros:
Of all the places I've worked, Facebook is the best at keeping their values consistent across the organization. They incentivize positive behaviors and spend money on things that actually improve employee health, happiness, and job satisfaction. Their goals are clear and they are consistent in applying policy while allowing reasonable room for variation. 

Leadership strongly emphasizes avoiding bias, treating everyone equally, and creating a positive environment, and that has a very clear positive impact at every level. As a woman in tech this is by far the most welcoming/comfortable place I've worked.
cons:
Like any software company with a lot of recent college grads (and especially one that places a high value on transparency), there can sometimes be a bit too much handwringing about culture and values and long, circular discussions on whether something does or doesn't fit the culture/values. But it comes from a good place, and again the company leadership do actually support those values and incentivize following them. 

Also, because 'working hard, contributing useful work and accomplishing things' are heavily incentivized, good people tend to be very busy. For a big tech company work-life balance is pretty good, but it is easy to load up your plate with way too much to do, or it's sometimes hard to get time with your manager because they've done that.
advice_to_mgmt: A bit more emphasis on a) time management and b) assuming positive intent would be great. Otherwise *please* keep doing what you're doing; it's great!

headline: Engineering Management
pros: Low bureaucracy, highly empowered
cons: Six month review cycles that take a lot of energy and focus away from projects

headline: Continuous Improvement
pros:
I've been at Facebook for more than six years. The culture is very introspective and dedicated to self-improvement; if it were the same company it had been in 2009, I wouldn't still be there. Everytime I think I might leave, a new awesome project comes up that keeps me around. Seeing Mark Zuckerberg mature into the great leader he is has been magical, and I have a lot of trust in Sheryl and Mark and Mike Schroepfer to make good decisions. 
In many ways, engineers are more productive now than they were in 2009, despite the fact that we work at a big company now. We have more tools, resources, and knowledgeable people at our disposal, which compensates to some degree for the increased bureaucracy you see in some parts of the company. We also launch to hundreds-of-millions-to-billions of users, depending on the product, making our contributions very high-value. Product launches continue to be driven by bottom-up ideas as much as top-down directives. That doesn't mean that you personally are going to have an idea which shakes the world, but it does mean that you have a better shot than other companies.
Especially if you're an infrastructure engineer, the culture is very bottom-up. You still have great latitude to come up with execute your own ideas. The flipside of this coin is that if you're not good at deciding what to work on, you'll need to learn that skill within a year or so; management isn't going to spoonfeed you tasks to the extent they do at other large companies.
When joining Facebook as an engineer, you will still have many many choices of which team to join, and you'll make that decision after a few weeks of "bootcamp" which means you'll have an informed choice. It also means that the quality of engineers is high throughout the company because every person comes through the same interviewing process.
One of my favorite aspects of Facebook culture is focusing on impact rather than hard work. Another is a recognition that you can advance your career without going into management, and that there are many different kinds of talent. There are several different "archetypes" of senior individual contributors that are recognized and encouraged to flourish.
cons: Facebook has become more careful in certain core areas like Newsfeed, Timeline, Ads, and Platform. There are many stakeholders on these products and thus you've got to get a lot more things buttoned up before you can launch a product change in these core areas. We still do experiments but not quite as freely as before. Just understand that the more impact your product has, the tougher it will be to make changes, and place yourself in the company according to your preferences.
response: Thank you for sharing your experience. It sounds like you have seen the growth and evolution of our community over the years, and we thank you for your dedication. Appreciate your feedback.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Amazing perks. Free atmosphere. Good leader.
cons: The project might not have been so influential.

headline: Great company
pros: Great place to work. Talented, smart people.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros: Incredible growth and still focused on impact and success, despite increasing company size
cons: High pressure to succeed, increasing company size no longer really feels like a startup

headline: The Best Place to Work
pros: Amazing, innovate place to work with the smartest people on the planet. Free food, loads of work/life balance benefits!
cons: They tend to hire management outside of the company which in the end is a detriment to company culture.

headline: How you'd expect a company to work, if it was designed by (string) engineers
pros: A refreshingly rational approach to maximising opportunity and efficiency for individual contributors. You're measured objectively on 'impact' but are free to determine where you can find most impact. I work with undoubtedly the strongest engineers (both max and avg levels), the culture is supportive and fast-moving, and I've developed personally more in 8 months here than I have in years elsewhere.
cons: The very high level of achievement is intimidating, and although the company is very positive towards work/life balance, sometimes I try to brute-force some impact with long hours.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't lose the culture as we continue to grow. blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah.

headline: Looks good on the outside....
pros: They have some great ideas that are inspirational. There is never a stop to the ongoing activities and overwhelming number of events. Coworkers are peers of all ages and backgrounds which makes for a unique dynamic around the office
cons: Biggest common issue over my 1 year here: They don't practice what they preach (ie. Culture and work/life balance opportunities). The management team looks down on everyone. No one can advance beyond an entry level position. You get an idea that gets bought or get stuck in an entry level type job for your "career" with barely above avg pay rates. I know that this is a competitive industry but sometimes the stupid people win just because they have the right connection. Bad employees stay while realistic workers realize the mistreatment and all leave within a year. I'm not making this up. Go look up Facebook's overall turnover ratio and tell me how that could lead to happy employees. Every SINGLE person on my initial project was lied to about their working hours (expect 9-5 and told 9-5 then made work overnight/graveyard shifts), benefits (only get to go on campus when with a supervisor), and team management. Too often we are told that our ideas will be considered then a manager gets promoted to a new project for spearheading such an idea.
advice_to_mgmt: Learn to actually communicate and not alienate employees on new projects. Foll
response: Thank you for taking a moment to share your feedback. It's so important that everyone is open and honest when discussing work expectations. If you haven't already, please reach out to your HR business partner. No matter the scenario, employees and contractors alike should have a clear understanding of goals and expectations.

headline: Good company, but not for everyone
pros:
Company is well-run, ambitious management, good execution.
Good perks, good incentives for high performer.
Everyone in every position is strong. Mediocre is not tolerated.
cons:
Pressure is high, because of working with smartest people.
Work life balance is a huge problem. You will push yourself, for sure.
It is not necessarily bad, but definitely not for everyone.
advice_to_mgmt: The culture could be a bit nicer.

headline: Working at Facebook Hyderabad
pros: Decent facilities, good brand name, option to relocate to global offices
cons: No exciting work happens out of Hyderabad office, too much favouritism in place, people suck up to folks in US offices, be prepared to take calls at 10-11 PM almost everyday, people mistake meetings for productivity, no planned investment for the future, this has become more of a back office
advice_to_mgmt: Develop Hyderabad as a fully functional centre of excellence as India is a huge market and you can't rely on a white man/woman sitting ten thousand miles away to figure out the Indian market

headline: Great benefits
pros: Free meals, amazing benefits package, great office culture, fun employee events
cons: Not a lot of room for non-technical junior full time roles, lack of upward mobility

headline: Fantastic place to work, some minor complaints
pros: Facebook's mission is meaningful, it's perks are awesome, pay is good, and the team is phenomenal. In general, almost everything about working at Facebook is as good as you think it is.
cons: My concerns are mostly minor. However, because Facebook hires strong talent at EVERY position, in some cases where strong talent is hired in positions that aren't core to the success of the business (read: if you're not an engineer, product manager, or maayyyybeeee a key sales person), it can be frustrating as your job is just not that important to the company's success. Hungry, ambitious people in these sorts of situations (as Facebook tends to recruit) can get disengaged and frustrated by these facts.
advice_to_mgmt: Keeping things on track as the company grows is going to be challenging. Also, PR moves that seem to demonstrate a lack of empathy or understanding (e.g., Free Basics in India in 2016) can potentially damage the company's reputation.
response: Thank you for your feedback. We believe our work is only 1% done, and agree it's important to keep all of our teams engaged in meaningful work as the company grows. We encourage your continued feedback when you see room for improvement.

headline: Great colleagues, management can be poor or indecisive
pros: Great colleagues, smart people, drive and collective mission, free perks (food, snacks, drinks), new spacious office and swag
cons: Workload, everyone is aiming to move up/across the "jungle gym", it's who you know and how you manage "the game", constantly have to talk up or post your achievements/client meetings.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your staff. Don't just mouth "Ship Love", live it, breathe it, practice it.
response: We appreciate your feedback. In our open, 'move-fast' organization, there is flexibility and autonomy when shaping your career. We also encourage each person to reach out to their HR business partners for advice on career growth.

headline: Do what you do best
pros:
- Huge focus on employee development
- Flat organization - every one is reachable and reactive 
- Sounds cliche but it's an amazing organization with truly amazing intentions, vision and executions.
- Moving super fast and super flexible
cons: Not sure i have any, but I think some people will find the speed and flexibility bothering. Almost 2 years and loving every minute
advice_to_mgmt: Don't change

headline: Product Manager
pros: Freedom to explore, speaking to my counterparts at other companies like Google, Twitter, and Uber it seems that Facebook has some of the most open cultures that encourages product exploration outside of one's primary duties and helping people finding impact across the company in places of their personal interest.
cons: Commute to San Francisco. The commute to San Francisco is unhealthy and inhibits social life. I want to live the city lifestyle, and this is a serious consideration for me. My next job will certainly not involve 3 hours of commuting each day.
advice_to_mgmt: Open a San Francisco office. The commute is actually unhealthy and probably effects the work that is produced.

headline: Best place to work
pros: Hands down the best place to work
cons: Nothing really to note, great place

headline: Deserves the award: the best place to work in the world
pros:
- Work with smartest people in the world
- Efficiency is at the top, it is crucial to make things work in the same quality in shorter time in more scale.
- The company and products develop your skills based on your area of expertise
- There are many perks: three times meals, free food in the kitchens, cool offices, games rooms, activities, parties etc. etc.
cons: There is pretty much nothing to add here.
response: We're so happy to hear that you are experiencing some of the best things about working at Facebook. Thank you for your continued contributions to your team and Facebook.

headline: From the viewpoint of a contractor

Opportunities to communicate with clients who are experts in advertising on Facebook
Learning about Facebook advertising solutions from the basic to comprehensive level
cons:
Discrimination in treatment between full-time employee and contractor
Micro-management working environment applied on contractor
advice_to_mgmt: Develop better management system, especially for contractor as everyone is working towards the same goal for the company.

headline: Manager
pros:
Very collaborative culture
Not a dull moment
Exciting and visible projects
cons: Very fast face so cannot do a deep dive on one single engagement
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing!

headline: Great Place
pros: The place is amazing worked out very well and great working hours for everyone very reasonable
cons: place gets a little crowded while working but it gets the job done for us

headline: Great for lone wolves.
pros: You will be surrounded by very intelligent and very motivated co-workers. You will be given a tremendous amount of leverage to ship features and change the world. The company moves very quickly for its size.
cons: Working style and rewards are highly individualized. It's not the place to go if you prefer working on a tightly knit team. Working from a remote office requires much travel to HQ.
advice_to_mgmt: Facebook has been a tremendous success so far. Keep it up! You might want to explore, however, the benefits of getting people to work together more cohesively.

headline: Once in a lifetime
pros: Still a bit startup-i, plenty of opportunity for impact and growth, great culture, great percs
cons:
Thoughest feedbacks you'll ever get. The speed and level of productivity at which they work and expect you to work is scary.
(Not sure if any of these are cons)
response: At Facebook, we value open and constructive feedback, moving fast, and focusing on impact in order to help our people grow and better serve our communities. Thank you for taking the time to provide feedback.

headline: Culture \m/
pros:
The transparency, candidness and drive for equality. The work culture is what I'm here for.

For me, hikes in compensations are what keep me from being disappointed / demotivated. What inspires and motivates me, what really satisfies me is the work I do with all these awesome people around me.
cons:
Maybe this is me, or maybe it's the culture. You can't really go off the grid for more than let's say half a week. Why? Things can break. and if you aren't there to fix it, it's going to be a disaster (that could have been avoided).

But quite frankly, if I had to choose between ownership/responsibility, and the ability to go completely off the grid, I'd choose the former.
advice_to_mgmt: Incredible leadership team that I'm proud to work with. Continue being pragmatic and head on!

headline: Work balance
pros: Food, people are nice, good commuting,

advice_to_mgmt: treat people more

advice_to_mgmt: Incentivize engineers to work on less sexy projects. Those projects fuel others' full-time jobs and it's discouraging to work without proper resources at one of the world's most successful companies.

headline: its not a workplace, its a family full of mad love!
pros:

cons:

- the motivation at FB is not money, its much beyond it - it is about running my own workplace
- so if you are looking for a clean 9 to 5 job with limited accountability, no one will complaint and no one will ask u to stay back and work and slog, but yeah, your impact might always be lesser - may be because you're gonna compete with the smartest brains in the world.

advice_to_mgmt: - you are still slowly going towards hierarchy! watch out!

headline: GSM

Not a place for introverts or those who value workspace privacy. If you choose to actually go home when you're done for the day - and not hang around or go out for a drink or otherwise spend more time with colleagues - you are met with incredulous stares. 
EVERYONE has drunk the Kool-aid; no one can fathom that the company isn't universally loved.
advice_to_mgmt: Expand the definition of "authenticity" in your mantra "be your authentic self" to include not just obscure or eccentric hobbies, but also other personality types.

headline: Great company

headline: Internship at Facebook
pros: Fun, exciting and challenging projects. My team in particular was amazing. The work environment was very relaxed yet the team was incredibly productive.
cons: Not much, it's a great place. It can be hard to keep a work-life balance if your team is too demanding, but it didn't seem to be a company-wide issue.
advice_to_mgmt: Not much, you're doing a great job, keep it up. Keep hiring the right people, motivating them and rewarding them for a job well done.

headline: Surreal, beautiful workplace with exceptionally positive culture
pros:
The perks are amazing, the compensation is great, the products are amazing, and the infrastructure/tooling is excellent.

Above all else, I love the positive, exciting attitude I deal with every day. Not every single person is totally on-board, but the ratio of positive, excited, friendly people is higher than any other workplace I've seen.
cons: I haven't encountered a significant "con" yet, other than the extremely high expectations - but is that a con, if everyone around you is invested in your success and tries to help you excel?
advice_to_mgmt: Keep supporting the little things that make our culture amazing and sustain all of us.

headline: Best place to start your career
pros: You set your own goals, you initiate your own projects, as long as you deliver all of them, you're on the right track. Apart from that, remember, you're the average of 5 people you surround yourself with. Imagine surrounding yourself with bright minded people.
cons: Difficult to maintain work life balance

headline: I had a good 3.5 years there
pros: I worked with a lot of smart people there. Overall, the company is doing well and has a robust strategy. The perks are great too.
cons: It's grown really fast recently and the culture's been diluted. The product roadmap changes a lot. It's had trouble innovating internally, most product growth lately has come through acquisitions.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep making sure culture scales as the company grows. Encourage a true culture of internal innovation, make sure it's not just lip service.

headline: Great company, great people
pros: Facebook is an amazing company with lots of opportunities. Behind the free food and great perks, you'll find knowledgeable colleagues and inspiring human beings. The "move fast" motto is tuning down progressively for "stable infra" in infrastructure.
cons: Maintaining a work-life balance is difficult. Codebase is still messy in some parts and can be frustrated when documentation and owners are nowhere to be found.
advice_to_mgmt: The lack of code ownership needs to be addressed. The CEO is very transparent but some of the M-team sounds less so, sometimes giving very empty responses to Q&A.

headline: Best company
pros: Great environment to do the most meaningful work - the work you do impacts over a billion people - where else do you get that? It's the way people treat each other with respect, genuine care and encouragement that I love the most - when the environment is right you can do your best work. Facebook has this in spades. Not to mention Zuck and Sheryl - phenomenal leaders - the real deal.
cons: So much to do! They keep saying we are only 1% done? It's tiring!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the culture of openness and transparency and the heart of the company as it grows and keep looking after the people as well as you do now!

headline: Becoming a better engineer here
pros: The engineering organization is great in terms of giving people autonomy, interesting work, flexibility, and growth opportunities. I've encountered good managers here, who truly care about developing their reports and helping them find engaging work.
cons: The internal culture feels uncritical of the company's decisions. Too often, people conflate our business interests with humanitarian interests.
advice_to_mgmt: Encourage lower-level people to be more critical. Such people are more valuable than those who just rehash the executives' ideas.

headline: Visionary leadership, industry experts will be your peers, the ability to impact billions, and incredible benefits
pros:
I am not hyperbolizing when I say that working at Facebook is the best job I could possibly imagine.

You get to work with a visionary leadership team that is incredibly accessible and wants to hear from you. Mark's Townhall meetings grew out of the weekly Q&A that he runs internally. If you want to ask Mark Zuckerburg or Sheryl Sandberg a question you can do it. If you want to give feedback or see changes in nearly any aspect of Facebook you will be empowered to do it.

Your team will likely be comprised of industry experts in your particular area of work. From kernel hackers, PhD's in computer learning, hardware engineers building drones and our own servers, to network engineers that are helping write drafts and RFC's that define the underlying protocol architecture of the Internet - you will find everything under the sun and these people will make you so much better at what you do.

If you aren't enjoying what you're doing in your current role you can go on a Hack-a-month with another team. This lets you expand your skills working on a different set of challenges and stay on your new team when you finish, if you like the work, or head back to your old team to work on something else. The best part is that management encourages these types of moves!

The management teams empower you to work on the things you want to, and gives you the ability to impact billions of people. You work on one of the biggest platforms on the planet and you will see the results of the work you put in everyday in making it better.

Also, the benefits are pretty amazing.
cons:
Any complaints seem like extreme first world gripes given all that the company does to keep the employees happy and progressing in their positions and careers, but I do have a few.

The company will absolutely (and gladly) take as much time as you put in. They don't overly pressure you to work insane hours, but you will be surrounded by overachievers who put that pressure on themselves and create the perception that large swaths of the company are, "always working." This can be a blessing or curse and it is up to each individual employee to figure out the dreaded work / life balance equation for themselves.

The other issue, is that Facebook prides itself on not competing on salary, RSU's, etc. against offers from other companies. While that may seem ok in practice, it results in a revolving door (which is a bit of a Silicon Valley issue in and of itself) between other big tech companies and Facebook. We won't make counteroffers to keep people, but we'll pay them what they wanted before they left to come back which sets a bad precedent for the people who stay.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing.
response: Thank you for sharing your feedback. You touched on some unique strengths of working at Facebook that make us really proud too. We also encourage employees to take advantage of the employee benefits and perks through our Life@ program to help each person find their own personal balance.

headline: Awesome company to work for
pros:
- young, smart, helpful team
- great work culture (company values actually are being lived)
- focus is on making impact. company values your strength and not only that but also encourage you to find your strength and make impacts using that strength. of course the impacts should be in line with company vision and the team's mission.
cons: - nth that I can think of now
advice_to_mgmt: keep up the good work!

advice_to_mgmt: Continue to hire 'A' people and never settle for less & keep them challenged even as company grows. This will keep us number one.

headline: Needs to work on internal management
pros: Amazing experience to be a part of a company which makes meaningful impact everyday
cons:
Some teams are becoming big and hence your impact may seem to dilute. 
Not very helpful in movement across orgs
advice_to_mgmt: Stay lean

headline: Client Solutions Manager
pros: Great place to work! At Facebook you are able to really focus on a work life balance while you find new ways to build upon your career.
cons: Some of the more tough decisions when it come to working at Facebook are that it is easy to get caught up in the hype and and let it overtake your life because there is always something to be improved upon on updated. #hackathon
advice_to_mgmt: My advice to the management at Facebook is that they are doing a great job at keeping individuals satisfied and motivated. A great way to improve on this is by adding new incentives to some of their already successful methods.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Very open culture 
Great place to work
Can really focus on impact
Get to solve problems that have never been solved before
cons: I don't really have any cons. It's been the best company I have worked for.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue what you are doing - fantastic company to work for
response: Thanks for taking a moment to share and for joining us on our journey to make the world more open and connected.

headline: Great company, terrible recruiting organization
pros: Great for young kids with almost no experience, where they can program you into their FB cult. Terrible place if you are a mature, serious professional. The environment rewards people who like to brag, boast, and broadcast their awesomeness. If you work hard but humble and quiet, you will not succeed here. Also, management in general, refuses to fix problems with the process. Performance reviews are geared towards those brown nose the best.
cons: It feels like a cult for young, single people. Mature professionals with families need not apply. If you do manage to join, be prepared to be surrounded by rah rah rah, lots of brown nosing, politics, eating, drinking, and going to the gym with your co-workers is almost required if you want to get ahead here. If you don't join the herd with a smile on your face, you'll certainly feel like an outcast and will be on the black list. Manager smile to your face, tell you what you want to hear, then will stab you in the back. Extremely immature organization. They also make it nearly impossible to hit your goals once you are at a senior level, and then they will fine a way to phase you out and replace you with someone younger.
advice_to_mgmt: Provide management/leadership training prior to promoting someone to a leadership role.

headline: Awesome opportunities, though a sink or swim culture
pros: At Facebook, you have access to an endless number of opportunities, contacts, and perks. You're working with highly qualified people and the benefits/pay are really, really amazing. I didn't fully appreciate these positive aspects about Facebook until I left to work for other tech companies in the bay area.
cons: Definitely a sink or swim culture. You can either do really well at Facebook or flounder around without much support.
response: It's great that you enjoyed your time at Facebook. We know that it's really important for the people who work here to have the support that they need (everyone is different) so that can play to their strengths and feel like they are at their best. We want to encourage employees who might need extra support to reach out to their Manager and/or HR partner - supporting each other is very important at Facebook.

headline: Move fast and break things
pros: Smart people. Prestigious company. Insanely successful business.
cons: Everything is broken, all the time.

headline: best company ever
pros: great perks, great people, great product. feel proud of being the part of the journey of making the world a better place
cons: you're compete with smartest people in the world
response: Our people, products, and the way we work are all centered around our mission to make the world more open and connected. Thank you for highlighting and sharing your feedback.

headline: Great Place, People and Environment
pros: Everyone is energetic and passionate about working. Rubs on you and enables you to aim higher. Good food and perks
cons: Its starting to get bigger so you have to fight for your opportunities
advice_to_mgmt: Keep inspiring everyone

headline: Unethical employer
pros:
Great people in Engineering and Product organizations,
Learning how Facebook has scaled/ growth strategies was rewarding especially once I left Facebook
cons:
Week I moved across the country for the job, I was told the team I joined to be on no longer existed. Forth manager I had in my first four months later kept from me that the work I was hired to do was being removed from Facebook's objectives. 

Some seniors managers keep secrets and are horrible to work for. There's lots of truth to the saying, "I joined for the company and left because of my manager." Facebook a really, really good at selling its kool-aid story to employees. (It's why they have great ratings on Glassdoor IMO.) If you are in a position or team that is dissolved, you only have 4 weeks to find a new job, which isn't much time at all.
advice_to_mgmt:
Don't ever offer someone a job and have them move only to tell them the job doesn't exist.
Hire more ethical people. Not cool that the person that hired me left in my first two months because he saw the writing on the wall.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: Great people and great environment

advice_to_mgmt: keep doing what youre doing

cons: They r no challenges for working with Facebook all I have to day is its a good social network. Good people

headline: Life @Facebook

Best is regarded as Normal 
Intelligent people trying to create impact to the real world 
Innovative ideas are given preference 
Fast paced
cons: There are no cons, probably some will say there is less structure around processes but I think that is deliberately done to move fast
advice_to_mgmt: Don't change

headline: Facebook is Awesome
pros: Facebook has an incredibly impactful mission in the world. Possible the most important tech company of its decade. You get to learn from absolute top talent is many fields. Excellent culture lacking almost entirely in bad office politics. Great pay and benefits.
cons: Facebook is becoming a larger company and lots of time get sunk into coordinating and selling rather than building. Life/work balance can suffer despite considerable efforts from the company to balance things.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work! Stay hungry stay foolish :)

headline: A dream company come true!
pros:
On my first day at Facebook, I remember asking myself, "Is this company for real? How am I here? How does this company exist?" Facebook is the epitome of the perfect company. A wise man once told me about the four Ps of the perfect employment: Product, Problem, People, Profit. 

Is the Product interesting? This product serves over 1.5 billion people - it is the most exciting product to be part of.

Is the Problem interesting? Beyond interesting. We're trying to solve making the entire world more open and connected through communication, through sharing, through education, etc... In any area of the company, the problems are all great problems to solve.

What about the People? The people are literally the best people I've ever worked with in any position I've been through. They are brilliant, kind, friendly and completely supportive. I left my last company as a senior member and at Facebook, I still feel like I'm learning something new from my colleagues every single day. Beyond my colleagues, the leadership here are more than supportive about an individual's career growth to help us grow deep within our roles, support groups to help you become a better manager, classes to help individuals transition from one career to another. I've seen many of my colleagues get the opportunity to completely change paths (e.g. Designer to Engineer, Researcher to Designer, Designer to PM, etc). You pave your own path and leadership here is supportive to help you get to where you want to be.

So what about Profit? Facebook, luckily, is doing very well in this area. At a personal level, Facebook pays also very well. I was lucky enough to have my total acquisition package matched and exceeded which made saying yes to Facebook a no brainer.

Take a great product, great people, amazing culture and a beautiful place to work and tie that all up in a bow. That is what Facebook is and I hope it never changes. I love this place!
cons: The only con I've found is that Facebook's campus is a bit in the middle of no where but honestly with the flexible shuttle system and an all-day shuttle that goes back and forth between downtown Palo Alto, it's not so bad.
response: We couldn't agree more. :) Facebook is truly a special place with a unique combination of people who are the best at what they do working together as one team to connect the world. Again thank you for taking the time to share your experience. - Your Friends at Facebook

cons: EMEA vs US different cultures

headline: Excellent employer. Lot of growth potential

headline: Great perks, but work life balance is
pros: Facebook has great perks. Free food, free shuttle, ability to work from home when needed. There are Q & As with Mark every Friday so you can ask them any question.
cons: Tough work life balance. Often spent time working more than 10 hour days and also working on the weekends. Didn't feel there was career growth within my team due to limited support.

headline: Awesome work and culture, but be careful of burning out
pros: Awesome people and culture that really cares about building great products. Extremely open, you can ask questions to Zuck and Sheryl directly, even as an intern. A culture that cares a lot about people and building great products. Also, things move very fast and fluidly -- I got to ship code to prod on a daily basis. Extremely intelligent, friendly, and helpful engineers and coworkers.
cons: The "move fast" motto is taken very seriously, which can be a bit intimidating at first. Facebook also encourages people to work very hard (sometimes too hard), which can put a lot of pressure on you. As an intern there were many weeks where I worked > 50 hours. At the same time, I did really enjoy my work, and coding was balanced by social events, team dinners, intern trips, etc.
advice_to_mgmt: Sometimes it felt like there was a lot of pressure to get as many code reviews out as possible. While lines of code are a way to measure progress, I think it's also important to be able to spend time designing and coming up with a solid architecture of a solution as well. It would be nice if there was more balance.

headline: Intern
pros: Awesome people awesome perks please really amazing place to work.
cons: Maybe that not all the food places are open for dinner

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
- Facebook is very flexible, people are encouraged to work on stuff they're interested in with the best support I've ever seen in industry these years.
- Facebook holds one of the best standards on its benefits - better than all companies with equivalent size.
- People working here are just happier than average industry level, due to this reason you would feel happier too.
- Company momentum is just great, so this could be potentially a place you can stay for a while.
- Great engineers just come from all other companies, Google, Microsoft, Apple, Amazon. College new hires come from top ones: Stanford/MIT/CIT and things.
- Good amount of people here are both smart and diligent, you have many to learn from.
- Although coworkers are competitive here, they are much nicer to work with than other companies holding same 'elite principals'. For example, I rarely see (though there're few) arrogant people here. The whole culture was built in the sense to favor people who are both smart and humble.
- Culture encourages transparency, so you have to learn hear and accept sometimes very tough feedbacks, but you could end up growing much faster as you can tell.
- If you are good, there's no barrier on 'what you can do'. Facebook does NOT reveal your level to anyone else except your report. So you could see E3 engineers work like E4 or even E5 in the end. But in another way around, it could be tough for seniors.
- Facebook sees deliveries (executions) as 1st priority, so people here just focus on work more than the rest, I believe this is one of the biggest reasons why this company moves faster than other companies with equivalent size.
- Most of work in Facebook reaches great amount of people (1.5B in web, 1.3B in mobile), and great amount of revenue (20B of this year). So you can tell how much impact you can have, and this would to the minimum becomes a highlighting bullet point on your resume.
- People says Facebook has bad work/life balance, I don't agree: 1) you have freedom to pick a laid-back team and free to go almost anytime (they have hackamonth program and it is true), 2) most of time I see hardworking people working hard due to their own choice.
cons:
- People says Facebook has less politics, but I do feel some. Usually come from a group of people joining to same team from same company around same time.
- Culture encourages transparency, so if you're a smooth talker and avoid giving harsh feedbacks, this could become your problem in review.
advice_to_mgmt: In general Facebook sees culture as 1st priority in operations, I agree on this. However it would be great to allow diversities in individuals on small amount of points.

headline: Overall Good Company

response: Thank you for spending your time and efforts interning with us. We're happy to hear that you had a valuable and enjoyable internship. It's hard work connecting the world, but we want to make work work for people. We hope you were able to find the right level of work/life integration for yourself while you were here. Best to you in your future. - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: Great Place Great time
pros: Good pay, talented people, plenty of opportunity. Everyone wants to work at FB these days. Time spent here is 2x 3x mor valuable than anywhere else because of the immesne learning/experiences.
cons: Can be chaotic, Lots of young/inrexperienced managers. Difficult to make true impact when there are so many type A, motivated young individuals doing crazy awesome work. Although there are privisons for work from home and generally good at encouraging work/life balance, this is difficult with so many young and single people putting in intense amounts of hours.
advice_to_mgmt: Only advice would be to encoutage people to spend time otuside of FB environments to lear people management, processes etc. at exteernal companies/.organizations. Crucial as the company continues to grow.

headline: Exceptionally Run Company
pros:
Facebook engineering is almost unparalleled. For example, the continuous delivery system at Facebook automatically builds, tests, and releases software.
Managers will give you detailed, constructive, and honest feedback on how to be a better engineer.
Lots of opportunities to impact the product through hackathons.
cons:
Most engineers are pretty introverted.
Can be stressful.
advice_to_mgmt: Facebook is on-fire and is firing at all cylinders thanks to Mark's incredible leadership.

headline: Open, Diverse, and Life-Changing
pros: Facebook allowed myself to express who I am as an individual and work in a diverse and open environment. As an internship, Facebook provided work that developed transferable skills as well as a network of opportunities to meet many talented people.
cons: The shuttle rides are a double-edge sword. It's great benefit to have, but if you are planning on using the shuttles or even commute, good luck on the 2-hour ride back home.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work! I wouldn't change my experience as an intern to anything else.

headline: Engineering Manager
pros:
Great benefits. 
Fast paced work environment. 
Competitive salary and stock
cons:
Stressful - most people are expected to be available all of the time.
People are passionate but that comes with a down side of not wanted to listen to other people's opinion.
Profanity is part and parcel of working here.
advice_to_mgmt: Make the environment easier to deal with. Most of the stress comes from the top down.

headline: I love this place!

cons: To me, the one con is the time it takes to get down to Menlo Park from San Francisco.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Facebook offers an open, transparent, positive, and collaborative environment. I've been working for over 15 years and could only dream that such a work environment exists. To be surrounded by such a talented group of genuinely nice people is truly refreshing. I frequently get approached for job opportunities. While I would consider them in the past, I couldn't imagine ever leaving here - even for much higher pay.
cons: I'm gaining weight with all the free food:-)
response: Thanks so much for taking a moment to share your feedback. We are grateful for your commitment to and passion for Facebook. We’re 1% done on this journey! - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: Amazing!! Like no other company!!
pros: It's true!! Facebook is the best company in the world to work for! Mark Zuckerberg is an absolute credit to the globe announcing to donate 99% of his shares to charity! The business is genuinely interested in making the world more open and connected and it's wonderful to be part of an organisation that is changing the world positively!
cons: No cons!! To date I am blown away with the efficient manner and effective work force all with the one global goal!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work, keep to your goals in making Facebook the best place to work in the world to make positive change and make the world a better place!

headline: Great company
pros: Very fast moving. Brilliant CEO. Long term vision. Great compensation.
cons: Sales org is becoming corporate. More about visibility/perception than substance.

headline: Disneyland for Engineers
pros:
Wide variety of great things to work on. Your colleagues will be the best you ever worked with, and you'll learn a lot from them.
Very supportive of employee growth, great managers who really invest time in their employees.
Amazing parental leave benefits, great senior leadership.
Awesome open source program, leading the world in numerous areas for both software and hardware
cons:
Better for engineers and designers than fro most other disciplines. 
Stock had captured most huge growth, not a start up any more.
The 101 is basically a parking lot.
The interns eat all the best food :-)
advice_to_mgmt: Just keep it up, you're crushing it
response: Thank you! We work hard to hire people who are the best at what they do. We were really excited to announce the extension of the 4-month parental leave to male and female employees around the world. So we're glad that matters to you. We do want to work hard to maintain the benefits of a start-up culture while growing the Facebook business around the world. (Instagram, Oculus, Messenger, WhatsApp, Internet.org, etc.) Our advice on the interns eating the best food? Try the 11:45-Noon window for lunch. It's early, but sets you up for a break at the Sweet Stop later in the afternoon. - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: HR Business Partner
pros:
Dream Job: 
-Autonomy to work 100% independently, authority to make huge decisions that shape the business, and pretty near perfect manager and leadership support. 
-Quite literally the smartest, hardest working and most competent people I've worked with in every facet of the company (including start-ups, mature companies, and post-start up tech companies). 
- Low tolerance of BS, low tolerance of "everything is amazing, everyone is perfect" when things can be improved. 
- The org moves fast with people issues, low performance (when appropriate), and childish behavior (very very low tolerance for this). 
- Incredibly lean orgs, especially in HR, so you really have the ability to own a business from end to end. 
- Low tolerance for politics or front stage/back stage behavior. 
- Best HR team I've ever worked with including the best manager I've ever worked with. Full of high performing, no jerk, high wit peers at the top of their game.
cons:
- Incredibly lean - At least on the non-tech side of the house we could easily add 5 more HRBP's/HRG's and still be understaffed. The pro is way more opportunity for impact, the con is that you just cant get to every org, manager or employee that could be optimized with some extra attention. 
- Comfort in the gray - Being successful at Facebook means being comfortable without always having a process, policy, or system to fall back on. The bonus is it leaves more freedom for judgement, the down side is first ever decisions can feel like they're policy setting (even if no policy is created)
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in more headcount into HR Generalist's, they're the force multipliers for your HRBP's and the eventual pipeline of talent.

headline: CSM
pros: Good opportunity to growth yourself
cons: Strongly need self study attitude

headline: Love My Job!
pros: Culture, culture and more culture. The first thing you will notice as a new employee at Facebook is the multitude of social events both in office and offsite. There is always something fun to do that helps you engage with coworkers that you may not have come in contact with in your normal work day! I truly enjoy my coworkers and find myself hanging out with them even for non-facebook events, its great!
cons: It is a very fast pace environment and it takes time to really find that work life/personal life balance.

headline: Technical Project Manager
pros:
Worked with some of the smartest people I have ever had the privilege to work with. The company is amazing and the culture is one to be admired. There was always a new challenge when was opportunity for learning. 

Benefits were great and are perfect for anyone. 

Food is why I am 20lbs heavier then when I started. The Chefs deserve a standing ovation for some of the food they put out.
cons: Work/life balance was getting better as I left but definitely an area that could get better. In many cases the bad W/L balance is self inflicted due to this personal mission to be the best. At least that's my perspective. Note that this is a problem within Tech period.
response: We too are very grateful for our culinary crew. Thanks for the kind words. I know they will appreciate it. We wish you the best. - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: Good place to learn and earn
pros: Good microkichen, Good pay, smart people
cons: performance review is not perfect

headline: good culture is fading away
pros: The opportunity to work on interesting and challenging problems. Intellectually stimulating environment. Great perks and shuttle rides make life more efficient. Company is in a good spot in a large market. The CEO has great visions.
cons: The good, old "open and focusing on impact" culture is fading away. Senior level engineers more and more often have to fight against each other for projects or reinvent the wheels for the sake of fulfilling requirements vs. real technical/business needs. Managers brought in through nepotism have little to none people management experience and skills and brought in negative impact by playing politics. There is no clear mechanism in place to stop these viruses from spreading.
advice_to_mgmt: Add checks and balances to keep managers' performance in check. Employees at FB typically can easily land external opportunities (and better comps) and don't bother to stay when running into issues, although most of the time the issues have been disguised as performance challenges or issues on the employee side.
response: We appreciate your candid feedback. Keeping our culture open so we can move fast and make an impact is critical to our continued growth. We encourage you to share your feedback with your HRBP directly so we can all be a part of building the type of company we love. - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: Software engineer
pros: Great work place. I can learn a lot. Nice coworkers. Great benefits. Reasonable work hours. I would recommend working here.
cons: A lot of responsibility. Things move super fast. This is pretty much i. It is overall a great place to work

headline: Visionary leadership, maturing company, hard-working
pros: This company is innovating and moving fast in every sphere, changing the way things are done. Great benefits and forward-thinking philosophy on human resource management.
cons: The harder-driving people are moving towards smaller companies, start-ups, companies that haven't IPO'ed yet. This company is becoming more mature and therefore the upside may be smaller and there are conservative elements that need to protect all the territory the company has conquered thus far. At the same time, leadership is trying to stay on the cutting edge and there's still a lot of growth
advice_to_mgmt: Fix the "always-on" culture, keep on with strategic acquisitions but don't overspend, invest in maintaining entrepreneurial culture

headline: Amazing company! Learning a lot.

advice_to_mgmt: Keep key talent

headline: Excellent space to level up
pros:
- You are surrounded by the best of the best.
- Everything is handled for you, and you get the feeling the FB is here to help you be more productive in life in general.
- There's space to grow, and it's performance driven.
cons: It's still a big company, so there are ways you can end up going down the `feel good about yourself` train, and end up not being too great.

headline: Amazing
pros: The culture is amazing, You get to work with really smart and nice people and the learning curve is amazing on lower level up to middle management. Speed, innovation and focus is amazing
cons: work life balance could be better in offices outside HQ and US.
advice_to_mgmt: N/A.

headline: Cool products, great colleagues, management can be dissapointing
pros: Speed of innovation, extremely bright colleagues, who generously share knowledge, great benefits
cons: Mid management: they are not transparent, talk about valuing people, but don't act accordingly
advice_to_mgmt: If you want to retain talent, treat them with respect and empathy

headline: Luh dat
pros: Great experience in fast moving company with great perks
cons: If you care about city living, enjoy dumping thousands of hours of your life away in a bus annually
advice_to_mgmt: Get a south SF office

headline: Software Engineering Intern
pros:
Smart engineers
Great location
Access to resources
Lots of freedom
cons: There are no cons, it's basically the perfect place to work.
advice_to_mgmt: The olives at Harvest are a little too big.

headline: A lot of good a lot of bad
pros: smart people, interesting problems, good perks
cons: a lot of pretentious people, not very helpful in getting started in your career/learning

headline: Partner Engineer
pros: Dynamic , Fast , if SWE can move around easily
cons: Little work/life balance .. ..

headline: Data Scientist
pros: great amenities, free onsite gym, shops, and restaurants. Great culture that responds to employees with weekly talks with CEO. Free shuttles to SF
cons: Long commute from SF. Large company so sometimes there are duplicate tools for the same task.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work. Continue to have weekly meetings, keeping everyone informed and on the same page is really a great way to run the company.

headline: Accounting
pros: Small Firm; Very friendly company culture
cons: Limited Resources; Set team that rarely saw newcomers
advice_to_mgmt: Hire younger colleagues

headline: Ads Analyst
pros: There's a huge hype around being an FT (Full Timer) and a contractor. Never get into that zone. Focus on quality than quantity, and Facebook is a decent company and will recognize your talents surely. Work hard for it. Fun place to be. Amazing food, they only want to feed you, home pick-up and drop.
cons: Less salaries for contractors, when getting referred keep in mind ho is referring you. A contractor or an FT (Full Timer). Hard-work comes after, what comes before is the way you carry yourself and you look, trendy, urban and a very social personality is a 10 on 10.
advice_to_mgmt: All contractors contracts should be extended atleast once. Give them a far chance to showtheir talents.

headline: Great place to work, not great for certain roles (design/research)
pros:
Amazing perks, super transparent company, very little boundaries to communication. You can pretty much talk to anyone at a whim except Mark. It makes getting things down a breeze. 

Super laid-back, younger vibe. A lot of energy and excitement around the future. 

It's also nice that the company is so successful; it's motivating to know that they are moving in the right direction and have had wild success in the past
cons:
There's so much autonomy that direction from above isn't quite there. There's no product development process. The success of your product is very much up to how good your PM is or whatever process the team has lifted from other companies. PMs can be really clueless or junior sometimes, but other times, they're out of this world. 

Very metrics driven. It is frustrating to be so tied to metrics that better experiences don't ship or some really crappy product gets developed because of a metrics goal.
advice_to_mgmt: Standardize product development more. Have phases, even if they're fast. Product design as a process should be a focus (and not mocks). This would lead to better product hit rate.
response: Thank you for your feedback. We are glad you feel empowered with the autonomy needed to think creatively and solve problems quickly. We will be sure to share your feedback about product development. We encourage you to share this with your leadership, as well, so that your perspective is heard. - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: beware of kool-aid...
pros: lots of money and having a top 5 tech company on your resumé.
cons: it's a soul-sucking new age corporation with promises of making a difference in the world or finding the next "billion dollar idea". Projects aren't set up for designers or a creative process. Their engineering mantras of "hack" and "move fast" will always take precedence, which makes for failed designs and cheap ripoffs of existing products.
advice_to_mgmt: The design process and strategy should take precedence over engineering.

headline: Facebook
pros: Great place to work. Collaborative and encouraging management team. Rewarding for people who take risks and produce. Benefits and lifestyle are the best you'll ever see.
cons: Hard to say there are any negatives at a place like Facebook.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up!

headline: Analyst
pros: The work environment is stress free and work culture is healthy
cons: You would get so addicted to the smooth and tension free work environment
advice_to_mgmt: they know better

headline: Great Company!
pros: Amazing place to work at! Interns are pampered, and given lots of work! Great culture, great people. You get to learn a lot here!
cons: It can be overwhelming to be an intern, with work starting from the very first day. Also they get too many interns sometimes and managing them gets messy for mentors. Screws up your work life balance a bit.
advice_to_mgmt: Get fewer interns! Also, it'd be nice if 3 reviews were given through the internship instead of 2. Other than that, I've got no complaints!

headline: Analyst
pros:
friendly environment
amazing culture , food
cons: not a full time position

headline: Awesome Experience
pros: Lots of resources and opportunities to grow
cons: Management is not the best

headline: Product analyst
pros:
Smart people
Autonomy
Challenging problems
More words
Even more words
Finally some more words
cons: Company getting big, hard to connect with proper XFN partners to drive impact
advice_to_mgmt: Keep sourcing internal feedback

headline: Great people, culture, environment, and interesting projects
pros:
- Everyone is smart, but most are also extremely friendly and willing to help/give advice.
- Choose work that interests you, and managers do everything to make sure you are happy
- Flexible work hours (choose your own start and end time, doesn't matter how long you're in the office really) within reason
- great benefits etc.
cons:
- steep learning curve
- very hard to find good documentation when trying to learn about various aspects of infra
- a lot of custom systems/tools everywhere, can be overwhelming to new hires
- sometimes people move too fast and create projects without enough consideration for effort vs impact
- compensation is probably not as good as other similar sized companies for new grads (unless you are an extremely desired engineer with many competing offers)
advice_to_mgmt: Compensation for new grad in certain data roles and departments is lower compared to others (similar roles other departments) in the org. You should ensure compensation is more even across the board

headline: i give it five star rating
pros: Its a very good company
cons: i dont see any cons for the company

headline: Work Here
pros: Awesome; They treat interns well
cons: None I can think of

headline: great company
pros: Food is great, and the people are amazing as well. Great culture. I loved everything about it.
cons: lack of proper software engineering practices/hacky culture. Not much guidance given to employees.
advice_to_mgmt: great going, but codebase can be made much better. Some of the code base is buggy, but it is still working fine.

headline: Best job
pros: I learned a lot of things, from a lot of smart peoples. It is a job where your ideas matters, and that is the most important thing for people like me.
cons: I really have no cons here. Probably the only thing that bothers me sometime is the food given to us.
advice_to_mgmt: Let's see. Keep doing the good job that they are doing right now. Keep being the best employer in the world. Keep giving us good salaries.

headline: SWE
pros: the pay and the culture are so good
cons: people who are smelly sometimes there
advice_to_mgmt: nothing

headline: Good internship
pros: fair pay, small-ish company, real-world problems
cons: location, competitive atmosphere, stressful hours,
advice_to_mgmt: None

headline: Great
pros: Free thinkers, great perks, smart people
cons: None none none none none

headline: A happy place
pros:
• The quality of people was off the charts
• The work environment was fun
cons:
• Working in London made it tough to communicate with people at head office (Menlo Park, CA)
• Decision making was slow; often times, consensus was sought, which was slow

headline: Best place to work with many people.
pros: People here are very active and the company has the best employees.
cons: I don't think there are cons to this company.

headline: Excellent place to work at
pros: The company is aggressive in investing in new technologies. Employees have the freedom to explore different possibilities. The company is also very open and everyone is involved in important events and it feels like a member in a big family.
