cons: It's hard to find anything that's completely wrong as an employee.

headline: great place to work
pros: great engineers to work with, great projects to work on
cons: management tiers increasing as companies scale

headline: Disneyland
pros: 4 months paid leave with newborns, work from home Wednesdays, unlimited high quality food, can always walk in the park on the roof if I need some fresh air. Food is consistently great.
cons:
The only legitimate con I have about working here is meeting start times. Meetings go from 12:00-1:00 for example, with the following meeting starting at 1:00 promptly. This naturally leads to people starting meetings late.

Also I get withdrawals on the weekends when at home because the food here is so good. It causes me to eat out more on the weekends and thus I don't actually save on my food bill.
advice_to_mgmt: Would love to modify our policy on meetings to be more in line with what I understand Google's to be: Meetings can be scheduled for 25 or 55 minutes, must always have a 5 minute window so meetings can start on time and end with reasonable gap to get to the next place.

headline: This is an amazing company of kind people
pros:
Competitive pay and wonderful benefits (the food is gourmet- seriously!) FB 15 is real- we've all gained 15 pounds in the first year!
Very human in how they think of their employees- it's hard to find a company in the valley that treats their greatest assets with kindness and compassion.
People genuinely care about each other
cons:
-you have to open your personal FB page up to co-workers (hard!)- makes sense that you use the product your company makes, but it's such a co-mingling of personal and professional lives.
- there seems to be a group of the before and afters- who struggle to understand the company has grown and will not go back to the first 100 employees! This leads to a sense of entitlement and not playing as a team.
- commute. UGH
-Need to do better with giving back (as a company and as employees). I know our CEO has donated gazillions- but we need programs that allow employees to donate and have funds matched, and allow employees to volunteer their time.
-More focus now that it's a larger company with 10K employees, on career growth and development.
Opportunity to do on diversity hiring and older workers- the average age has to be under 25!
And a more diverse executive team...
advice_to_mgmt: Keep things transparent- build strong leadership so we can focus on more than one crisis at a time- bring in senior leaders w/lots of experience who've gone through the lifecycle of a company before.

headline: Perks Beyond Comprehension and an Opportunity to Change the World
pros:
If the reviews here sound like employees are really drinking the Kool-Aid...it's because many of them are. The people at this company genuinely believe they're changing the world by connecting it, and that mission and set of values permeate everything they do. 

-Unbelievable benefits and compensation. Seriously, some of their benefits are mind-blowing. Gym benefits, free (really good) food everywhere, amazing healthcare and family planning and daycare benefits (including a "baby bonus"), access to incredible company events and speakers, generous vacation time that they're constantly encouraging you to actually use, the latest phones and computers for work use, on-site doctor and dentist that are actually good...the list goes on and on. 
- Strong company culture and values. I've never been at a company that lives and breathes a mission so completely. Am constantly in meetings where coworkers are asking, "Is this the right decision for the people who use Facebook?". Even the way they treat their contingent workers (who receive better benefits than most of the tech sector's contingent employees do) makes this evident; there are internal communication groups where full-time employees are constantly asking what more we could be doing for contingent workers to show our appreciation for their work. Both internally and externally, the "#shiplove" mantra is strong here.
-Work/life balance. You'll see some mixed reviews on this point, but I've been here a year (non-engineering role) and I've never had the level of work/life balance I've had here. I work a very consistent 9-5, and it's rare when I have to fire up my laptop at home at night or over the weekends.
-Facilities. It's Facebook! The campus is gorgeous, and they allow visitors. Hosting out-of-town friends and family for lunch or dinner is a great perk.
-Efficient and fast. Fewer politics than many other companies of this size. A lot of the day-to-day communication and work gets done on the Facebook platform, which is hugely efficient and easy to use system.
-The future! These guys have their hands in a lot of cookie jars, and are working on some really amazing stuff. Whether you're working on things like bringing internet access to the third world, virtual reality products, artificial intelligence that will serve peoples' needs, or all of the innovative things that go on inside the regular ol' Facebook app that serves over a billion people a day, chances are you're working on something really cool.
-Women's leadership. I've also never been at a company that really understands women's needs as much as Facebook does (I think we owe this to the leadership of Sheryl Sandberg, Lori Goler and Maxine Williams). They encourage an ongoing dialogue about women's issues in the workplace, have mothers' rooms all around campus, encourage us all to take a "Managing Bias" course (which is really eye-opening, on many levels) and even host a yearly Women's Leadership Day, which is truly empowering. They bring in amazing speakers for this event and out of everything I've experienced in my first year here, this was probably the event that stayed with me the most.
cons:
-Entitlement. After you've worked here for a while, it's easy to get entitled. I'd say 95% of employees keep their feet on the ground and appreciative and gracious about the benefits they receive, but the entitlement plus the company's culture of open feedback ("feedback is a gift") occasionally breeds inane complaints in internal communication groups.
-That commute. If you live in SF, you'll have to hike down to Menlo Park, and depending upon where you're coming from and how bad traffic is that day, it could be as bad as 2 hours each day. The good news: that's rare, and company-provided transportation options (shuttles with WiFi) make this as easy as possible. You do get used to it, and your time on the shuttle is your own. Sure, you can do work, but you can also nap, watch Netflix, or read.
advice_to_mgmt: As you grow, you'll be tempted to cut back spending on benefits-- don't. That is one of Facebook's biggest differentiators and it seriously makes many of us question leaving.

headline: Not for everyone, hypocracy and blame I saw mostly
pros: Lovely campus, okay perks for contract workers.
cons:
The HR/training teams that I worked with were staffed by people that thougt they were experts. They indicated that no contractors could ever offer value; contractors were viewed as an extra pair of hands. However, my role was specifically to provide expertise and coaching in my domain area. The junior/mid-level staff never solicited feedback and assumed only their ideas were useful. Just because people say they are open to feedback does not make it so. I got unsolicited feedback constantly at FB: everyone has an opinion and thinks it's valuable. But, not once did anyone ever ask for my feedback. In that sense, and many others, it's a hypocritical environment. 

If you're junior or less than 15 years in your job, FB is probably a good place to grow. If you're more experienced, be sure you carefully evaluate the job. My experience is that I wasn't working with the best or brightest, more often they were the narrow-minded, arrogant and entitled.

Finally, in the area I worked, it was all about blame and pointing fingers when things went wrong. And because they hate processes, of course things would go wrong.
advice_to_mgmt: Puleeeze - do you really think management is listening? My experience is that someone junior will respond to comments (everything had to be answered by someone at FB because "feedback is so valued)." Uh, no - not in my experience.

headline: Great company
pros: Fun, challenging, collaborative. The campus is also amazing, and interns are treated very well.
cons: The company is getting big, and even though the company tries hard to not be affected by "corporate" culture, some of it is unavoidable it seems.

headline: An amazing company
pros: They have an amazing culture, everyone I met was very friendly and the work life balance is so much better than the Menlo Park office.
cons: The people working at the office were so friendly and nice that I hung out with coworkers a lot and didn't meet any Londoners.

headline: Good place to start a career in software engineering
pros:
1. A lot of smart people and interesting projects
2. The "Move fast" culture allows you to contribute a lot
3. Good pay, good perks
4. Looks good on your resume
cons: 1. Almost no work-life balance. Although not specifically required, you will be working after 5 or over weekends (mostly from home.)
advice_to_mgmt:
1. Should definitely keep the fast-moving, open, trusting environment as the corporation grows.
2. Try to improve work-life balance for employees.

headline: Great experience
pros: Everyone was very friendly, and the atmosphere was great. Benefits were great - free $25 per day to group with 4 other employees for any activity, free food, lots of intern events.
cons: Goals and projects were not laid out very well. Shouldn't be a problem for people with more experience, but for first-time interns this might be an issue because they offer little help with getting accustomed to the work environment.
advice_to_mgmt: There should be more help (ie. classes) for back-end development during the first week or two to get more accustomed to the code base.

headline: Young Adult Wonderland w/ Golden Children
pros:
- Incredibly transparent when it comes to company priorities and initiatives
- Great access to leaders in the company. Nobody is too big to talk to.
- Touches basically all of internet-connect humanity, which is nice.
- Playing on the largest-scale chess board in the world against the top 4-5 tech companies
cons:
- Lots of hiring from outside that layer long-term employees under several managers
- There are a few "Golden Children" inside the company who can essentially do no wrong and will always be given control of the most interesting/valuable projects. They are either buddies with Zuck/Sheryl or were actual startup veterans who were brought in from the outside. Either way, it's near impossible to become a significant player in the company without that "golden" anointment.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep kickin' butt!

headline: Incredible culture and benefits
pros: Working for a mission-driven company makes for an engaged and enthusiastic workforce. Focus on impact means that you have flexibility to get work done when and how you choose. Quality of people we hire is outstanding, coupled with low egos. Love the 'focus on strengths' mentality which means your role often shifts to make sure you are spending the most time doing what you love. Lots of support and training for managers at FB, although the individual contributor role is equally valued - becoming a manager is a lateral move (and a deliberate choice) at FB rather than a reward for being awesome in an IC role.
cons: Personally I love the concept of bringing my authentic self to work and being personal friends with coworkers, but I understand that it's not for everyone. I do feel that this will become more prevalent as the millennial generation becomes the majority of the workforce in the next decade.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the amazing internal comms, including weekly Q&A with Mark, quarterly strategy updates and accessibility of the management team.

headline: Facebook
pros: Facebook creates opportunities worldwide. Very innovative and forward thinking. Offers support for developers or businesses on all platforms.
cons: I presently do not have any cons.

headline: analyst
pros:
management is bad
poor opportunities for career development 
work life balance is not good
cons:
culture is very positive
people are amazing
international experiene

headline: Data Analyst
pros: Stable, large company with good leadership
cons: Too large to make an impact

headline: Best place to work
pros:
- Coworkers are all smart and passionate people
- Managers truly care about their employees
- Flat organization
- Amazing perks
- Great benefits
- Schedule is very flexible
- Transparency
cons:
- Longer days (but you like what you do)
- Handful of entitled people
advice_to_mgmt: I think management does really well from the top (Zuck) down to line managers. Incredibly transparent, honest and genuinely invested in employees

headline: One mission - and we're getting it done!
pros:
*We have a very straight forward mission - to connect the world. Everyone knows it well, work is aligned to it and everyone is passionate about making it happen
*the "amenities" really do make life easier so I can focus on getting things done
*I feel like I can innovate everyday because we have SO much room to grow still
*the campus has such a high energy that it makes the horrendous commute worth driving everyday
cons:
*we have a lot of folks reinventing the wheel with tools and processes
*our tools are behind where we should be for the age of our company
*for the amount of internal transparency we have, at times it still feels like we are still very disconnected
advice_to_mgmt: IT would be great if we could focus more on global streamlining across groups/organizations. The teams are growing so fast the teams are becoming siloed and everyone is reinventing the wheel.

headline: Poor work life ballance
pros: The perks are some of the best in the business. Salaries are very healthy. Organization moves quickly. Free meals and great services offered at all offices.
cons: Work life ballance is absolutely an issue. As a manager, this was the number one problem I faced.....keeping my team moving forward at the pace of the company's expectations, while also managing my team's frustration at being on and accessible 24/7.....not a philosophy I could subscribe to.

headline: Strong business
pros: Decent culture, incredibly strong business fundamentals, Sheryl is a star, lots of good people. If you're looking to build a career, this is the place to do it.
cons: Big and getting bigger. Genuinely not on the same scale as Google or Microsoft, but reaching the point where all start-up remnants are being washed away.
advice_to_mgmt: To be honest, management is doing a solid job, all things considered. It is, in most ways, as good as a large tech company can get. There could be more of an emphasis on diversity.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Moving fast, awesome culture, smart people, rooftop garden, manager training, sweet stop, and music around campus cafes.
cons: Can't really pinpoint anything to complain about. I mean after all, we have amazing benefits!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing!!

headline: Great company
pros: The company cares about you well being (as shown by the food, the social events, everything is basically provided for you). But then it's also a bit difficult to have work life balance because of it, because you're expected to be doing your best regularly.
cons: You can gain weight within your first few weeks there - the Facebook 15. But hopefully with that free gym, you'll be able to eat healthy and be healthy!

headline: Love this place!
pros:
-Things move very fast here and they are constantly changing. This might not be considered a pro for those who are resistant to it but I think it helps keep the job fresh. I've been here for almost 3 years now and never once have I felt that my work has gotten stale. I think this is very important for facilitating personal and professional growth.
-The people I work with every day are not only some of the smartest people I know, but they are my friends and people I chose to hang out with outside of work. Facebook encourages all employees to be their authentic selves which translates to a much more relaxed and social work environment. It's work hard play hard and it's awesome being able to work people you actually want to spend time with.
-The perks are unreal. Everything from free food and laundry to awesome healthcare plans. It's actually kind of ridiculous. Their focus is on convenience benefits to help with work life balance.
cons:
-Always attached to Facebook. Let's face it, I did this before I started working here anyway.
-Lots of information. Sometimes it can be tough to keep track of all of the things that are changing. We have internal groups for everything and it can get a little intense trying to follow it all.

headline: Find Your Own Destiny
pros: It's like a microcosm of the real world. The organization can be fast and chaotic. It's up to the individual to find information, resources, and make things happen. It's great that one person can find support and quickly get resources allocated to their cause if it's justified.
cons: One of the consequences of the flat, disparate teams and "move fast" philosophy is that multiple teams may be duplicating work and competing internally, or just faltering in a disorganized fashion.
advice_to_mgmt: Could use more company-wide training on manager / managee relationships. Could use better design thinking and process integrated into org, sometimes need to slow down and think properly to save re-building costs.

headline: Incredible place to work
pros: Some of the smartest people I've ever encountered. Extremely high expectations for everyone, but it's a good, supportive kind of pressure. Management is top-notch and really sets the tone and leads by example.
cons: The pace that everyone moves at is extremely fast, so be ready when you join. There are a lot of smart people so it's easy to feel overwhelmed at first.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work! Remember that a lot of people around here look up to you all. Focus on maintaining the culture and good things will continue to happen.

headline: Review
pros: Great atmosphere! I really like the people there.
cons: Not much. I would appreciate more frequent buses though.

headline: Facebook review
pros: Great company, open environment, friendly and smart co-workers, nice benefits
cons: Expanding too fast, many new people do not have much solid work to do.

headline: Facebook internship review
pros:
Facebook has great people, culture, and benefits for employees. Interns are given the chance to live in corporate housing, with excellent conditions. Also, 3 meals per day and transport to and from work is a really good thing. Working in open spaces is another good thing about FB, since you get to easier communicate and work with people in your team/different teams. 
Also, the sweet shop was my favorite place!
cons: Project allocation was probably not suitable for all of us, since there were more than 1000 interns this summer.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work! The recruiting and interviewing process in very good so far, in my opinion. Managers should keep on doing their best to give interns real tasks and responsabillties, and help them whenever they need to.

headline: Fantastic bootcamp
pros: During the bootcamp you can see all the stack of the technologie
cons: You can end up doing things that you have never done

headline: Unlike any other employer!
pros: I've been at Facebook for close to 1 year, and have absolutely loved my time so far. I can finally say that I've found a company that I value as much as they value me, and I plan to stay as long as they'll let me. We hire amazing people that are interested in what they do, which makes teams strong and interestingly, I work with many people that have been at the company for 5-8 years! The perks are unbelievable, from the gym to the spa to dry cleaning to absolutely delicious food that fits everyone's needs. I'm also pleased with the compensation structure and opportunity to earn a very large bonus for high performance.
cons: Location in Menlo Park can be difficult for some commuting from farther parts of the Bay Area, but shuttles from many locations help a lot.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up!

headline: Technical Sourcer
pros: Great company would highly recommend
cons: Slowly but surely turning into Google
advice_to_mgmt: stay small and stay fast - don't sacrifice quality for quantity

headline: Truly the best company to work for
pros:
- flexibility to make your role your own
- open culture (truly open doesn't just say it is)
- appreciates their employees- perks and benefits are amazing
- company feels like family
- work life balance is appreciated and respected
cons: - comp isnt as high as other companies

headline: Empowered to Do What I Love
pros: #1: The people. The flexibility. The challenges/growth potential. Life@ - Our benefits program.
cons: Depending where you live, the commute - but the commuter resources are really strong.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay flexible.

headline: Great place to grow
pros: Very open culture; super fast-moving; incredible resources at your disposal, including managerial support + autonomy (in my experience, it's rare to truly have both); and really great benefits
cons: The pace can be exhausting if you don't actively take time for yourself; however, managers are really good at encouraging employees to take vacation.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue encouraging employees to take vacation and time for themselves. Stop to recognize the incredible work that is coming out of the company at such a breakneck speed.

headline: Better than ever
pros: work on products that touch billions of people + have a chance to shape future tech like AI and VR
cons: very challenging work + demanding jobs

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros: Focused and dedicated management team. Colleagues who genuinely like being around each other. Huge opportunity to create impact even as the company has grown.
cons: Lots of teams want to weigh in on things, but this often produces better outcomes in the long run.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay focused and maintain confidence.

headline: Perks Galore but Prepare to Work
pros: The open-office model creates cross-functional collaboration; mostly everyone is smart; the perks are abundant; and the work is impactful.
cons: Teams can be a bit cliquish and the lack of diversity can be dehumanizing.
advice_to_mgmt: Be more approachable.

headline: Nirvana
pros: Facebook encourages openness in all spheres, professional and personal. Be yourself - don't lead a double life where you are dull & droid-like at work, then are someone different at home.
cons: It's too early for me to tell. I hear rumblings that justifying code cleanup can be difficult since there's no neat metric for it.

headline: Full of adventures
pros:
Amazing colleagues focusing on making impacts
Employee Benefits
Great community
If there is anything you want to make it work out, it is a perfect place to be!
cons: Work life integration. Your colleagues will become your closest friends. But then, when do you spend enough time (enough not to ask for their understanding) your family and best friends?
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the work!

headline: Facebook wasn't for me
pros: Great Frank Gehry designed office environment. Free food & snacks
cons: Not such a happy environment to work in. Lots of pressure placed on individuals. The organisation talks a good talk about 'community' and 'sharing', but i found it quite a lonely place to work with an unrealistic amount of pressure. There is a fear within the London office which I coined 'FOFU', which stands for 'fear of f*cking up'.
advice_to_mgmt: So much activity within the organisation goes 'unchecked' which leads to bad behaviour. There needs to be clearer lines of management and a transparent set of work objectives that should guide the teams in their daily roles. Their are some ruthlessly ambitious people whose behaviour needs to be reigned in.

headline: Sales & Account Management
pros: It is a fast-paced company, innovation, the company is very open in terms of projects
cons: Some business units do not have a good management; as everybody wants to work here, there can be a lot of backstabbing involved; "diversity" can be questionable, it is not always the case. HR sometimes does not listen to a lower-level employee, but an employee on a higher rank. You can earn a good salary, but spend most of your time at the company (lack of work-life balance).

headline: Advertising
pros: The privilege working in a highly dynamic and engaging environment while bring surrounded by some of the smartest co-workers in the business. A truly open company that cares about it workers and consumers.
cons: No cons are worth detailing in comparison to the massive positives at Facebook today. Facebook just needs to keep up the good work maintaining that culture as they continue to scale.

headline: Not a Diverse Company
pros: Great employment brand and perks
cons: Was attracted to FB because of its Diversity message but it was a sad illusion. I'm HIspanic and women and since I joined the company they put me this HIspanic tag. Don't feel included by my peers and even by my manager, who is a global leader. Internally the company believes they include the people but never dare to deeply talk about the non inclusive culture we have here (Maning Bias training and tribes are only the top of this iceberg). Some Latinos friend already left the company and I might be the next.
advice_to_mgmt: Be honest to yourselfs and face the true, we are not ready to bring diverse to the company.

headline: Consultant
pros: I was one of few! I was paid to observe and report while I'd rather get mentally involved! I love to get involved in the brain-power decision making , but I like being a staff consultant to a leader who makes the final decision. In other words, I like being the brains behind the power that makes the final decision! I merely provide the simple and dry facts.
cons: Well, it only paid an honorarium which didn't amount to much, but it was the prestige of having done the job that mattered.
advice_to_mgmt: Consulting

headline: Even better than Google.
pros: I came from Google, which was amazing. But I love the culture and atmosphere here even more.
cons: Some people drink the Kool-Aid too much and think we're perfect.

headline: Amazing Place
pros:
+ Amazing growth potential, at no other place could I have moved up so quickly so fast
+ Everyone focuses on Impact all the time, if it's not worth doing then we don't do it
+ Learn from some of the best in the world at what they do
+ Unbeatable pay, benefits, work environment, and culture
cons: + Some people find it hard to find a life/work balance, but following the guidance of the more experienced people it can be easy, just need to cut through the BS and focus on impact
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on Impact

headline: The analytics org is in trouble
pros: Smart people, amazing benefits, good salary, "anything you need" attitude
cons: No clear career path, Analytics org has seen multiple owners, lots of attrition, not a meritocratic culture
advice_to_mgmt: Give people a real career plan, something to look forward to

headline: It's ok
pros: Good food, cool office, stock does well
cons: Young culture, lots of fires, little WFH unless group / manager super supportive, average pay

headline: account executive
pros: good environment to be working with people, the company provides a really relaxed atmosphere
cons: There really isn't that many cons I can think of working here

headline: Love everything about Facebook
pros:
1. No other company can compete with the Bootcamp. It's like a Red Carpet experience minus the glamour. You literally "decide" what you want to work on after working on real projects.
2. Brilliant people to work with.
3. Awesome work culture.
4. Even though it's a large company, you still feel important.
5. You are encouraged to move fast, without taking pressure which is an awesome combination, especially for a Software Engineer.
6. Awesome management, HR and all the supporting teams. They really make the life easy.
cons:
1. Work can sometimes be overwhelming for some people. However, to me, it seems like it is a product of their own working style. No doubt, there is a lot of work going on at a rapid pace, but you are always free to complete it at your own pace and your team is always there, ready to help you.
2. Limited number of PTOs: Although they are more than most companies out there in the industry, but they are still low.
advice_to_mgmt:
1. Keep doing what you are doing. Employees are the key to the success of Facebook and making them feel important is what has kept the company going till now.
2. The DNA of Facebook consists of the best of the people out there. Maintain it that way and never lower the bar for hiring new employees.

headline: Amazing Culture in London's Office
pros:
Lots of smart people
Interesting projects
cons:
It could take some time until you hit your sweet spot in terms of satisfaction and impact.
London's office doesn't have that many teams but is growing a lot, maybe this improves over time.

headline: Great Product, People and Values
pros: Facebook is a great place to work. Its not often that you can say that you work on a product that you genuinely believe in in a company with great values and with the best caliber people. Facebook is such a place. Nobody at Facebook is there accidentally. The interview process is intentionally tough because Facebook would rather have more False Negatives than False Positives (ie they would rather be wrong they give someone a No Hire than be wrong when go ahead a hire someone). What this means is that you are working with some of the best people in the world. Also the values that the company believes in truly important. Its great to work for a place that is so open with its Employees. Since Facebook's product is all about Social, the company makes sure that employees feel free to express their opinions. Everyone is encouraged to weigh in on important decisions. The company structure is such that we dont get fancy titles and therefore we end up being more equal. Move fast is also important, and the company removes all obstacles from employees so that they can do their job well. Overall I love working at Facebook and would recommend it to everyone.
cons: Since the company is focused on impact, work life balance could be better. People often feel that putting in an extra hour or two a day will increase their impact. Usually this is correct, but will cause the employee to burn out faster which the company doesnt want.

headline: Amazing company, management, coworkers and product.
pros: Mark is an amazing visionary and CEO. He makes hard calls and has a very long-term perspective.
cons: None that I can think of.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up.

headline: Awesome
pros: Free food and free everything
cons: Not getting paid every second of our lives ... it kinnda sucks, but hey
advice_to_mgmt: Pay us every second of our lives

headline: OK, but...
pros: Perks are mind-blowing - awesome food, and thoughtful benefits like laundry service and onsite acupuncture/clinic.
cons: Frenetic pace, which isn't bad by itself. But PROCESS is a four letter word at Facebook, clearly moving fast and breaking things is considered the way to go. Sorry, but when a company hits 12,000 people you gotta add in at least a light layer of process and actually hold people accountable to follow it.
advice_to_mgmt: M-team leaders appear to be a really solid bunch of people. But there are some duds lurking at the next level that should go.

headline: Working at Facebook
pros:
Amazing, smart people who are actually kind and want to collaborate vs. avoid it.
Open and transparent culture
Ability to grow your career
cons: It can be difficult at times keeping up with everything we need to know as we grow. We're also spreading out more - both globally and in HQ at Menlo Park. We need to make sure that we do our best to stay connected and maintain what's special about Facebook even with this growth.
advice_to_mgmt:
Continue being open to new ideas.
Continue believing in a transparent culture.
Continue to keep our hiring bar high so that we bring in the best talent.

headline: Amazing company to work at
pros:
Great company with an amazing culture. You work hard, the pace is fast, expectations are high, and change is constant, but Facebook really looks after its employees and provides a diverse array of opportunities for self development, cross-functional training and career growth. The CEO meets with all employees once a week and answers anyone's questions.

Most people here are energetic and passionate about their work and seriously focused on making an impact. The work environment is physically (and culturally) very open: open spaces, no offices, casual dress, etc. Work/life balance is respected and encouraged and you have the flexibility to work in the way that best matches your individual style and needs. Face-to-face communication is highly valued but meetings are generally focused on not time-wasting activities. Anyone can suggest a new feature or improvement and be part of the team that makes it happen. There is a lot of opportunity for high performers to grow their careers. The compensation, benefits and perks are truly above par. 

One of the most important things for me is the open culture and the way Facebook encourages employees to find and be our authentic selves, and to listen to the voices of others who may be different from ourselves. The company works very hard to create a diverse and welcoming environment for all.
cons: It may be hard to adjust in the first few months if you're used to working in a traditional company. You can't sit in a corner and work alone - cross functional teamwork and building relationships are the norm. Facebook is always in the public spotlight, and this is one of the things you'll have to learn to deal with if you want to work here. And you'll have to get used to spending more time on Facebook. :-)
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing.

headline: Amazing place
pros: Compensation, Great talent, a lot of space to be creative and submit ideas, not a lot of hierarchy and politics yet, ability to switch teams easily.
cons: A lot of product ideas get killed and never ship, which is usual for a company this size as you can't just ship half-baked products.

headline: Software engineer
pros: open culture, move fast, cutting-edge tech, awesome benefit, the best company in the world
cons: really cannot find any Cons...

headline: Awesome place to work
pros:
#1: more impact/person than possibly any other organization on the planet

Also: brilliant and friendly coworkers, ridiculous perks, emphasis on career development and learning
cons: Most people don't have a great work-life balance, but it's always self-selected/self-imposed. (Culture is focused on impact rather than time spent working, so working longer hours is not measured or inherently valued.)

headline: Simply put, one of the best companies to work for.
pros:
That Facebook is still interesting after 3 years is pretty amazing.

- interesting product area
- smart people, incredible company (not tech) infrastructure 
- more transparency than I had anticipated.
-
cons:
- size, it is getting big
- too many things going on at the same time
- quantity over quality
advice_to_mgmt: - set clear directions for the teams and the company, and don't change them every 12 months

headline: Smart People, Great Culture
pros: The Perks are nice, but what is very valuable is the people I work with. Everyone is top notch and I'm learning a lot every day.
cons: There are a lot of people who touch each project making it hard to execute quickly.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep rewarding XFN collaboration.

headline: Software Engineering Intern
pros: Facebook lives the #movefast culture not only in their employees but also in their coding. I really enjoyed working there.
cons: Too many interns. Our class had 1200 interns and even though you meet many new people, it's difficult to reach out to more senior people since there are so many interns already.

headline: High Quality Employment
pros: FB tries to eliminate regular discomforts one can experience in less progressive corporate employment. Management is easy-going but in return one is expected to do quality work.
cons: FB is a large company and with that, it is sometimes hard to see the impact of the work given.

headline: Software Engineering Intern
pros:
- Felt like I made an impact even in 3 months
- Great benefits, even for interns (meals, microkitchens, health allowance, etc)
- Transparent path to full time offer
cons:
- Was placed on a team despite not having the skills that the team needed
- Bootcamp could be a little bit more comprehensive
advice_to_mgmt: The intern program is great, but make more efforts to make sure people are on teams that interest them.

headline: Impactful Intern Project
pros: Definitely the interns at Facebook are doing much more impactful projects than interns at Google, Microsoft etc
cons: There's no work life balance here.

headline: Longtimer
pros: passionate people, dynamic environment, flexible, constant change
cons: growing pains, middle management, unclear expectations
advice_to_mgmt: give your employees room to grow. trust them.

headline: Difficult, but lots of support
pros: There is always someone who can help you with any problem you have, if you just ask. There's also free food.
cons: Lots of pressure to get a lot done. Not for people who can't take the heat.

headline: facebook review
pros: lot of room for impact, lot of challenging technical problems.
cons: not a lot of mentorship.

headline: The best company to work ever
pros:
You met with a ton of smart and friendly co-worker and managers.
You can make a lot of impact and also grow yourself.
cons:
Too much food, way too easy to gain weight.
You need to make decision yourself most of the time, sometimes it's intimidating.
advice_to_mgmt: To be honest, nothing much to be criticized. I love my manager so much!

headline: Great Company Great People
pros: People, Projects, Benefits, Food, People again
cons: Too much great free food will get you fat quickly!

headline: Software Engineer Intern
pros:
1. Interesting and challenging project for intern, compare with other tech companies like Google or Amazon
2. Very open culture, easy to find help from senior developers
3. Diversity
cons: May not end up doing something you're good at if you want to do something very specific.

headline: Management was tough
pros: Ups your game considerably. Great perks!
cons: Management is tough, the emphasis on impact makes it dog eat dog
advice_to_mgmt: Value your people

headline: Fun Perks, High Energy, Impact, but Give Up Your Life
pros: Spent three years on the hiring team & found the hacky whacky culture fun for the most part. Key to success is forging the right relationships. Be sure to manage your own career because no one will do it for you.
cons: Politics abound, lack of management training, questionable review cycles, erratic tangible roadmap outside of high-level ideas
advice_to_mgmt: Get better training, nurture your employees, and truly play to their strengths

headline: FB getting too big and political
pros: Free food and some of the great colleagues. Great benefits and pay is quite high
cons: Getting too big and political although the company acts as if there isn't. If you don't please the right people, it can go wrong to downhill very fast. Not what is used to be couple of years ago.
advice_to_mgmt: None

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great compensation, benefits and people
cons: Large organization and can take longer to climb the ladder

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Everything Is Good, Most Great Is The Free Food & Maternity Paternity 4 Months Paid Leave, No Force To Join Work Back.
cons: I Found No Cons, A Great Company To Work With. Tough To Get A Job That's All About Facebook.
advice_to_mgmt: Everything Is Great, They Should Continue Till End, Online Application System Is Great, The Review Team Should Be Given More Expenditure.

headline: nice workplace
pros: a lot of perks, coworkers are nice. feeling sense of belonging there, and has a lot of events and learning classes available.
cons: work life balance could be a problem........

headline: Awesome perks, smart co-workers, great environment for engineers
pros:
- Really good perks
- Challenging yet fun work environment. Engineers have a lot of say in the product.
cons: The company is getting bigger day by day.

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Great place to work, high energy, and everyone is very helpful and friendly for the most part.
cons: Every now and then, you run into a bad egg who thinks they're more important than the company. But this happened much less frequently than at any other place I've worked.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the company feeling small, don't let growth ruin the values we all believe in

headline: Overachievers Wanted
pros: Free food, smart people, potential to work on impactful products
cons: Unclear expectations, burnout rate is high

headline: General Statement about the Tech Industry
pros: Pinnacle of Industry, work with the passionately intelligent people.
cons: Disneyland Capitalism, fun and games on the surface with a monolithic corporation underneath.

headline: Unreal Work Environment
pros:
The culture is the real selling point here. Facebook looks to leverage people's passions. The focus on strengths, openness and care is so refreshing.

Facebook takes care of its employees to a degree I never could have imagined, and there always innovating to do even more. Here's what I take advantage of in terms of perks:
Gym with a variety of fitness classes to suit anyone's interests
Free food, sourced sustainably, local whenever possible, with options for everyone 
To go along with above, the sweet shop full of fresh baked goodies and rotating ice cream flavors
Spa on site (you pay for the services but it's so convenient)
Free laundry service up to $40/month
Shuttles from all over the bay area with wifi so your day starts when your commute starts
Amazing benefits and leave policies
cons: No matter where you come from, it's trafficky to get to the offices in MPK.

headline: A good place to stay for a summer intern
pros: 1. great working environment; 2. world-leading platform and people to discuss; 3. Lots of funny activities and speakers every week. 4. A lot to learn and grow for college students.
cons: 1. it would be stressful for interns who would like to purse the return offer.

headline: Recruiter
pros: Amazing company where you are given lots of autonomy and trust. Great perks! Friendly and fun.
cons: Need to give more feedback and room for improvement.

headline: Facebook is a decent place to start out, but it's not what it used to be
pros: You can work with some smart people on challenging problems. You can learn from the existing infrastructure.
cons:
Not as much room for growth anymore. Bad work/life balance. Waining company culture being replaced by Microsoft suits.

RSU grants are at the whim HR, so you really have to fight for a good offer otherwise you'll regret it.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat your veterans better by higher raises and equity. It makes no sense to stick around Facebook for longer than 2 years. 3 years is really pushing the boundary of rationality.

headline: marketing manager
pros: great party time at the office after work
cons: Total waste of my life and potential for a evil corporate giant

headline: Becoming a "big company" and shedding some of the initial hacker culture
pros: Work on interesting problems with smart people. Some really incredible managers.
cons: Growing pains from becoming a larger company. Some managers are very political and more red tape involved in processes. Some really terrible managers.

headline: Researcher
pros: Great perks and benefits. Many great people. Good focus at the top and investment currently investing in research and design.
cons: Mostly growing pains due to the rapid growth of the research team and at times a lack of a clear direction caused churn. Perhaps it is simply too top down.

headline: Brilliant company!
pros: Great work environment and just a brilliant all-round company!
cons: Nothing I can think of!

headline: Connectivity Lab
pros:
-Flexibility. I could choose a project and a particular area that I wanted to contribute to.
-Great team. A bunch of smart people on the team, including former Google, Apple folks.
-Fast. By the end of my internship we had a product almost ready for shipping.
cons: Not much to say here!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work!
response: Thank you for spending your summer with us. We know you have lots of options, and appreciate your investment in getting to know Facebook. We are delighted that you had a meaningful internship with us this summer. As a move fast, strengths-based company, we pair our peoples' strengths with ample opportunities to make an impact. This is how we run engineering boot camp, too. —Your Friends at Facebook

headline: Great company to grow in
pros: Surrounded by smart people to learn from and work with. Emphasis on impact. Plenty of travel opportunities.
cons: N/A None at the moment.
advice_to_mgmt: Never lose sight of the importance of great managers and quality of people hired as the company grows.

headline: Sweet place to work
pros: Huge impact, Smart peers, Good food, and Hard technical challenges to list a few. I also really like the culture.
cons: Noise and distractions in an open work environment sometimes hurts productivity sometimes. Luckily, there are couches and quiet rooms for that.
response: Thanks for your review. We like all the things you like, too. As for the open work environment, many people balance the open, collaborative workspaces with quieter options like the Zen Garden, side lounges/rooms, and rooftop garden work pods. It sounds like you’re already doing that. There are also complimentary headphones, if you think you might want to try them. —Your Friends at Facebook

headline: Hardware Validation Engineer
pros: The people working there are very fun and kind.
cons: Sometimes there is poor work life balance
advice_to_mgmt: keep on killing it. Keep the organization flat

headline: Amazing learning opportunities
pros:
- Learning opportunities are really unparalleled. There are so many different 'camps', classes, and informal learning opportunities at the company. If you have an interest in a topic, most likely someone else is equally interested in teaching you about it.
- Many of the little things are taken care of for you: food, laundry, shuttle, gym, etc. It does add up, from both a money and time perspective.
- Managers care! I've had better and worse managers, but one unifying theme is that they all have good intentions, which I can't say for every manager I've had in my short career.
cons:
- Salary growth can be somewhat linear...and the y-axis (what you start off at), has more weight than it should for a young company. 
- Easy for performance to all clump together at the above expectations rating, which really makes it difficult to stand out.
advice_to_mgmt: Work more aggressively to reward hard work with proper reviews and compensation.

headline: Empires & Game of Thrones
pros: Reality, neither a pro or con: It's getting fierce as many teams grow on the business side. With growth comes empire building and people will fight for ownership of your team's work. You see team's shifting scope and grabbing land. You have to be fierce and aggressive to win. That has always been the case at Facebook - just look at what types of people get into leadership roles. If you like this type of environment, Facebook is your place.
cons: There will be winners and losers. Career growth to gain skills is hard. Internal transfers are harder than getting hired externally.
advice_to_mgmt: The review process feels like a game.

headline: Developer's heaven
pros:
Amazing people
Freedom to do what you want, move between projects
Cheerful and optimistic work-environment
Find something you want to hack/change, go do it
Good food
Lots of perks
cons:
Sugar-shop is hard to resist 
HQ Office in the middle of nowhere
Commute on 101 is a pain
Sometimes work environment gets pretty noisy with all the discussions going on around you

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Smart people. great engineering challenges. freedom to work on projects
cons:
Not that many interesting projects 
Too much maintenance burden at times

headline: Great freedom
pros:
- great learning opportunities
- high degree of freedom
- strong sense of ownership
cons:
- some managers aren't really manager material, but just did a lateral switch for the wrong reasons
- despite having some truly exceptional people, there are a number of new hires that are sub-par
- work life balance varies immensely across teams, from very relaxed (10-6, mon-fri), to very ridiculous (12h+, 6+days a week)...
advice_to_mgmt: Continue passing down the ideals strongly across the hierarchy!

headline: SMB Account Manager
pros: Great company, lots of opportunity and insights from leadership
cons: You need to be comfortable with significant change at very short notice.

headline: Thumbs up for Facebook
pros: Engineers have a lot of responsibility and opportunity for impact. People say, there isn't just low handing fruit, but you will be stepping on fruit on the ground. The culture is accepting and respectful.
cons: It is and intense and demanding work environment. Many engineers work late into the night and there is an expectation that people will respond quickly, sometimes within minutes. If you don't pace yourself, you can burn out quickly.
advice_to_mgmt: Try to maintain the culture and incredible opportunities for engineers as the company grows. Already over the past few years, some aspects of the company have started to feel bureaucratic.
response: We appreciate your feedback. We hope that the focus on results creates flexibility in the way that you and others work. Some do use that flexibility to work outside of traditional office hours. While there are some situations that require a quick reply, we agree that it is a marathon, and work toward making it an environment where people can thrive for a long time. Your manager should be able to help in this regard. Or, if you have thoughts on how we can do better across Facebook, please let us know. We welcome your feedback on this. —Your Friends at Facebook.

headline: Overall great company
pros: Open culture, flexible work hours, great perks, ability to shift roles within the company
cons: Long commute from San Francisco, starting to become a bigger corporate entity, upward mobility isn't as clear or easy as it used to be

headline: Sales Client Partner
pros: Wonderful company and great benefits. Fantastic culture, a true leader in our industry and an example for other companies to follow. Great supporter of equal pay and opportunities for all.
cons: Pace is incredibly hard and demanding. Growing too fast at times. Need to slow down and put more alignment in place. Almost too transparent with our employees with information and data. They really do share a lot, there are positives and negatives to that, such as when new products get leaked to the press.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing, putting people first at the core of our product and services. And treating your employees with great care and kindness.

headline: Top of the Field
pros: Great pay, great benefits, interesting work. You get to work with some of the best engineers in the world, and the business is doing incredibly well.
cons: Work-life balance, while better than most top tech companies and certainly startups, is always a struggle. Unstructured work environment is a challenge to some.
advice_to_mgmt: Make you employees feel like it's OK to unplug and recharge. Make employee calibrations more transparent.

headline: Intern
pros: Big Name. Big Name. Big Name. Big Name. Big Name.
cons: Not good employees, rude managers, just so so cultures.

headline: Nice working place
pros: The greatest place to be if you are looking for challenges
cons: Too many processes and reportings simply kill creativity
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in more training for hr employees

headline: Contractor
role: Culinary Recruiter and Human Resources Assistant
pros: free food, gym, culture, people, work flexibility
cons: noisy, contractors treated differently, lots of changes

headline: Data Scientist
pros: I get to work every day on interesting problems together with incredibly smart and committed coworkers. The internal tools we have in place to perform analysis are world class.
cons: It's very hard to advance your career if you want to have work-life balance. The fast pace and the high demands foster burnout in a lot of employees.
advice_to_mgmt:
I can only speak for Management in Analytics: The load of work in Analytics is poorly distributed. Some Data Scientists have to support several products while others get away with simply keeping track of a metric.

I would advice management to keep a check on the workload distribution, as a lot of the most talented data scientists see their careers stall as a result of this imbalance.

headline: Finance
pros:
+ Overall mission to connect the world 
+ Interesting challenges to work on
+ Great culture - honest, open, direct
+ Never seen finance team move fast on key strategic decisions
+ Equitable and rewarding career - You get what you put in
cons:
- The pains of a growing company are beginning to show but everyone recognizes this and there are active discussions to preserve the culture
- Work life balance can be tricky but FB takes care of you
advice_to_mgmt:
1. Address diversity across the company and on management team
2. Stay focused and keep shipping!

headline: Great place to work
pros: Fantastic culture, benefits, and working with some of the most intelligent people in the industry
cons: Work life balance was not a huge priority, lots of office politics
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up

headline: Good company
pros: Very good leadership. Company culture is very good. You feel valuable to the company and can work on really tough problems
cons: Work life balance issues. Everything else is great
advice_to_mgmt: Keep focusing on user growth and product experience. Increase the perks for employees

headline: Can't imagine a better workplace
pros:
* Open culture - no secret projects
* Opportunity for growth 
* Access to management via weekly Q&As
* Lots of learning and development courses
* Encouragement to work on what you are passionate about
* Perks and benefits can change according to what employees want most
cons: The company is scaling rapidly, so while there is still a start-up culture, it's impossible to have the type of familiarity with all your coworkers and knowledge of all active projects you'd have at a smaller place.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing!

headline: Project/Program Manager
pros: Facebook offers competitive pay, fantastic benefits, a comfortable dress code, etc. but you all already know that. Those reasons alone make it an attractive place to work (though that luster does wear off). You have great IT services and productivity tools that make the day-to-day of getting work done easy.
cons:
- Management at the manager level is full of many inexperienced managers who are looking to try their hand at management. I don't think it's working that well. They don't back up their direct reports and are afraid to make any sort of decision. 

- Decision making by groups...while in theory is nice and probably worked a few thousand employees ago makes things slow down now. Empower your people and embrace accountability and responsibility. 

- Politics are king, if you can navigate them well, you'll do well on certain teams as it is rampant. Favorites are played and it's more about what you say you're doing then what you actually are doing. 

- Plan but don't execute - executing is for low level people, senior folks plan strategically with a holistic view and full context....yeah all that garbage talk is for real though. Seriously, depends on the team and role, but getting "stuff" done could be seen in a bad light.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Managers and IC's need to be empowered to make decisions and to know they have leadership's support. 
- Maybe take a look at hiring experienced managers from other companies instead of promoting the volunteer. 
- Remember that executing is more important then a roadmap.

headline: Best place to work at
pros:
1) Co-workers are all crazy talented and top of the industry
2) Working on some really technically interesting and challenging problems
3) Anything you do affect up to a billion people!
cons: The location of the office is the biggest drawback, it's in the middle of nowhere with no good housing nearby
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing, it's awesome working at Facebook!

headline: Move Fast and Be Open
pros: Two of the missions of the company, Move Fast & Be Open. These are attributes that are upheld throughout the company. I've had the opportunity to be a part of different teams, and in every switch this has been the case. Transparency is important to hold people accountable, help people grow, and connect people on different levels.
cons: The facebook adventure can be a whirlwind at times, and moving fast comes at the expense that you lose sight of little things at times and get burned out, but for the sake of growth, we move on, an continue forward.

headline: Facebook Main Campus
pros: campus perks; food, gym, etc. hardware resources.
cons: bi annual self & colleague reviews

headline: Facebook Experience
pros: Facebooks teams are driven to connect the world.
cons: The Facebook IT team needs to be less hierarchical and open to new ideas from their workers.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat their interns like actual workers and give them more responsibilities.

headline: Nice salary but tough management
pros: Nice salary, beautiful offices, challenging field, fast paced environment, nice people around. I had a great experience working there actually
cons: Some of the managers are real control freak and won't be really open minded sometimes but otherwise everything is great there
advice_to_mgmt: They might choose better some managers that are not giving the confidence to their employees needed to improve their skills

headline: Ops teams- Great place to learn but limited opportunities as you progress
pros:
Great M team
Transparency at the company level
Openness
cons:
Limited opportunities in Hyderabad as you progress
Lower salary when compared to other biggies
Benefits not as good as HQ
advice_to_mgmt: Performance reviews twice a year are killing people and aren't helping their careers at all. Think hard about how you want to give your ops teams better opportunities
response: Thanks for your feedback. The Hyderabad office is a model for operations in so many ways. We appreciate hearing your thoughts on the career progression. Thanks for sharing it. On the benefits, our goal is to be market leading in every office where we operate rather than having the same benefits in every location. We do think we have achieved that in Hyderabad, but please let the People team in Hyderabad or Singapore know if you think there are specific things we have missed. —Your Friends at Facebook

headline: You get out what you put in. And so much more.
pros: An incredible amount of time and effort is put into pushing employees to be the best version of themselves they can be, both professionally and personally. Development and career opportunities abound everywhere you look, and the quality of people that you are surrounded with is eons beyond anything I've seen at any other company, and I've worked for quite a few in different parts of the world. Culture plays an important role, and is also what makes the special place it is. The workload is high, but a heavy emphasis is put on having the right work-life balance/integration - which helps keep things humane. Even with a high workload, the impact of what we do is seen and felt on a very regular basis, pushing me to continue in my quest to be the best version of myself I can be, so I can deliver results that support our ultimate mission of making the world more open and connected. The hype is very real. It really is this good here.
cons: Being surrounded by the creme de la creme day in and day out makes imposter syndrome a very real and regular challenge. Keeping these thoughts in check can be challenging, but if you can manage it, and focus on being the best version of yourself, everything works out in the end. Incredibly fast moving changes can be tough to keep up with, but its also a big part of the joy of being here. There isn't much to complain about, which is why I'm having difficulty finding something of real substance to put here. Oh yeah - the free food, drinks, and snacks absolutely must be offset by regular workouts, or else the natural process of weight gain will rear it's ugly head. File that under #TheFoodIsTooGood.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep focusing on culture, its what makes this place unlike anything else in the world. We're all scared that as we continue to grow, culture will fall to the wayside. Keep fighting the fight - the message is getting through, albeit not to every single one of us, but regardless of that fact, keep it up, you're doing great. #ShipLove

headline: Incredible opportunity to innovate and learn
pros:
1. Culture. Facebook thrives on a collaborative, open culture where anyone can make an impact. You get to work with brilliant people who are very data driven and are open to constructive feedback on projects. It doesn't matter if you are an intern or a VP, your voice matters. 

2. Career Satisfaction and Growth. It's truly satisfying to work on projects that impact the nearly 1.5 billion people on Facebook's platform. I've interacted with people from every major department and there are so many interesting projects. Also, I love participating in the hackathons. You get to take a break from your current work and just be creative. It's amazing! 

3. The Food. So the food is ridiculous at Facebook. That's all I need to say. 

4. Facebook's Leadership. I'm very impressed with Facebook's senior leadership. They do an amazing job of communicating with FB employees and keeping everyone motivated. Specifically, they are extremely focused on Facebook's mission of making the world more open and connected.
cons: Work-Life Balance. There are very high expectations at Facebook and people work long hours.
advice_to_mgmt: As Facebook continues to rapidly grow, stay focused on maintaining rigorous hiring standards.

headline: Facebook
pros: Strong vision and passion for the company
cons: Turning political and into a PM heavy company

headline: Getting Corporate
pros:
- Food
- Health care benefits
- Fringe benefits
- Nice campus
- Corporate shuttles
- State of the art tech stack
- Extremely smart coworkers
- Visionary and bold top management
cons:
Work/life balance can get hurt as a lot of folks at the office are single and do not understand the needs of having a family.

The company is getting bigger. This means more room for backroom politics and aligning people without ruffling people's feathers.

Very talented individual contributors (and/or good at politics) are being promoted. As a result, instead of having well rounded managers, you end up having either extremely career driven or super awkward managers. Some of those middle managers are very green, making it even more painful.

Some women feel like they have to be extra tough at work because of the Leanin coolaid, making them very hard to work with.
advice_to_mgmt:
Continue the great job at investing for the future of the company.

Try to be a little more sound at the way promotions to middle management roles works.

headline: Engineer
pros:
Great corporate perks,
Fast-paced company knows clearly where we are heading,
Challenging but rewarding job responsibility that can really impact people
cons: To my knowledge, all cons I observe are present in any other similar high tech companies

headline: Review
pros: Really good company .Great place to work!
cons: No cons ! I dont have cons.
advice_to_mgmt: Work on competing with google !

headline: Disneyland.
pros: I mean, it's the happiest place on Earth. It's like Disneyland except... you get paid a lot instead of the other way around. I legitimately and genuinely enjoy the people I work with and coming into work is something I look forward to after a vacation (of which we get 21 days / year). I'm not a father, but I hear if I choose to be, I get 4 months paternal leave. Comp is great, food is great, ... I never talk about where I work and what I do because I just feel so lucky to be here. It's not really fair.
cons: We're getting huge. The last thing I want is for the company to turn into a Google/Microsoft/Amazon, but it might be inevitable. Luckily, the company takes preventative action to prevent the big corporate feeling... but it isn't working super well.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on keepin' on. Some of the best in the biz.
response: Awesome, happy to hear you are enjoying Facebook. As we continue to grow, we are working to evolve in a way that is uniquely Facebook – focused on our mission while continuing to move fast and be bold. We’d love to hear your thoughts on how to continue doing so. Please feel free to share them with your HRBP or in one of our constructive feedback groups so that we can benefit from your observations and input in this area. Thanks for your feedback. --Your friends at Facebook

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Facebook is an employee-focused company. Working here I feel valued and appreciated. I feel lucky to be part of this organization.
cons: This is not a real con, actually, but rather a reflection on the fact that in order to be successful at Facebook you have to be comfortable with change.
advice_to_mgmt: I'm inspired by my management from a professional as well as from a personal point of view.

headline: Review
pros: Facebook is a great place to work
cons: The office is pretty loud

headline: A Spectacular Ride
pros:
- change the world, nudging a billion people at a time
- working with the best minds around. I graduated at the top of my class, both high school and college...and so did everyone else
- they take great care of their employees needs
- a pace of change, despite the company's size, that will blow you away
- an unlimited set of interesting and challenging technical problems
cons:
- they talk about "work-life blending" instead of balance, but what this means in reality is that work generally dominates your life (along with your newsfeed)
- a growing focus on financial compensation instead of intrinsic motivators
- at the pace and scale of the company, an individual's perceived impact is shrinking
- using user engagement metrics as a poor substitution for user sentiment / satisfaction
- especially in the last few years, converging with the model of most other major companies
advice_to_mgmt:
Focus on the Impact
Move Fast, Be Bold
What would you do if you weren't afraid?

headline: Positive Feedback
pros:
Best company for an intern! Everything is free and there is a good hotel to live!
Worked on an independent project. (This is really good compare to some interns in Canada..)
cons:
Really good company and no big cons..
Ok.. food is not good as heard..
advice_to_mgmt: My manager offers me minimum help as usual.

headline: Smart and Exciting open market
pros: This place has the greatest collection of brilliant people in one place that I've ever experienced. Every day I learn more and get the opportunity to add value to what we do. People are collaborative and totally motivated by fulfilling the mission of connecting the world for the better. All that matters is that you have a great idea and the data to back it up. Once you have those, you can run with a creative approach to solving a problem and colleagues at all levels will offer support and partnership. Its great!
cons: Because hierarchy is insignificant and bureaucracy is at a minimum, it can sometimes be hard to figure out who else is working on something in which you have an interest. Feels decentralized.

headline: Very open and transparent
pros: The company is very open and transparent. Leadership is incredibly open about what direction the company takes and honestly answers all questions about why certain decisions were made. Everyone says "we" and never "I" or "you" about everything. Team atmosphere and sense of mission and belonging is infectious.
cons: Moving fast is fun and exhilarating, but it does break a lot of things. Lots of times work is derailed due to shaky infrastructure that can get frustrating.

headline: Best place for data science
pros:
- World class technology and infrastructure
- Brilliant colleagues who care a lot about their work
- Challenging problems and impactful 
- Decisions focus on the data and facts behind an idea vs who's suggesting it
cons:
- Not a con for me, but Facebook is an intense place, driven by smart and passionate people. If you are looking for a place to coast, this aint it.
- Commute, if you're living in SF
advice_to_mgmt: Work to maintain Facebook's mission-driven culture and weed out people who aren't aligned. Maintain a high bar for hiring, and put more emphasis on retention.
response: Creating an environment where our people can do their very best work is critical to our success. We take our work seriously but have lots of fun, too. We appreciate your feedback on the hiring bar. We strive to keep it high, and will continue to focus on the experience our people are having, as well. Thanks for your feedback! --Your friends at Facebook

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
- A lot of smart people to work with.
- Planet-scale projects.
- Less meetings/planning than in other big companies.
- Great benefits and perks. Free food. Laundry/dry cleaning.
- Great pay.
cons:
- Commuting by car to the new Seattle office from Eastside would require going through Mercer street.
- Open space floor plan.
- May gain weight due to free food.
advice_to_mgmt: Seek options to diversify business.
response: Thanks for your thoughts and feedback. We put special care in creating a unique and rewarding experience to support our people. Facebook is excited about the work that is underway in areas like AI (Artificial Intelligence), as well as Internet.org, virtual reality with Oculus, and scaling Instagram and WhatsApp. We mean it when we say our journey is only 1% done. -- Your friends at Facebook

headline: Great place to work
pros:
great opportunities
lots of learning
good pay
insane perks
cons: none, they are doing everything right
advice_to_mgmt: stop re org

headline: Great Place
pros: Awesome workplace with lots of energetic people! It's a fast-paced culture where the only way to move forward is to constantly have an impact. It's a great place to push for fresh ideas and provide input and work on projects that you are passionate about.
cons: Since teams are distributed around other offices, it sometimes takes longer for decisions to be made.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great amount of autonomy given to employees at all levels. Leadership is very transparent. All employees are encouraged to never hesitate to question their leaders. Overall environment is one of cohesiveness and cogeniality
cons: Targets & Goals set can be very aggressive. Hiring still tends to be slow which results in tough workloads on current employees.
response: You help make the culture what it is, so thank you for contributing to the cohesiveness. It's great to hear you've got the autonomy you need and that you're getting clear communication from leadership. We do see targets and goals being set aggressively across the company as we're solving big problems at scale, but we also want to get better at getting you the resources you need, when you need them. Thanks so much for your feedback and for working hard to achieve your targets. - Your Friends at Facebook

headline: It is the best company to work at for new grads.
pros:
- tons of responsibility
- respect for employees
- learn from the best
- flexible work hours
- flexibility in switching teams
- great perks
cons: - no office in the city (so commute from SF is something one should be up for)
advice_to_mgmt: Build an office in the city to tap into the pool available there.

headline: Business Development
pros:
It's like the best group project you never worked on in college. Everyone is extremely smart, driven, capable, high octane, and wants to work hard to see the team succeed...and for the most part, everyone is genuinely kind and friendly. Office politics don't exist like they do at other companies. 

The quality of the benefits / perks cannot be overstated.
cons: There isn't much opportunity to be based outside of Menlo Park. There are a handful of offices outside of Silicon Valley (New York, LA, Seattle, abroad) but not many. That said, it's better to have the company stay small and focused than get too big and have offices scattered about.
advice_to_mgmt: For jobs that allow it, consider unconventional work schedules (i.e. work from home ~25% of time) to allow greater time spent with family/significant others that live outside Silicon Valley.

headline: Loving My Job
pros: Every single day I am learning something new on the job-- I love being constantly encouraged and stretched in my role! Plus, I have the opportunity to work with people who are absolutely best in their fields.
cons: Facebook moves extremely fast -- it can be tough to stay on top of all the product/strategy changes. Innovation is extremely important to us, so we have to make sure that all of our operational teams can keep up.

headline: Great benefits, changing culture
pros:
Facebook is working on some inspiring things & it's cool to be a part of it. 

Many of the people they hire are extremely bright. 

Benefits are awesome.
cons:
Work/Life Balance is non-existent. As is career development opportunities & mobility on the non-technical side.

Management is really poor & gets increasingly detached and political the higher up you get.

They tend to reward/promote people who can make themselves look good, rather than people who actually get stuff done. This wasn't the case when I joined; but, the culture has shifted dramatically in that direction.
advice_to_mgmt: The culture is shifting pretty dramatically, and the ability to actually affect change is decreasing. The company is starting to suffer from a lot of "big company" problems that will affect it's ability to succeed in the long run.

headline: Terrific place to work!!!
pros: Great people! Fun innovative company! Great ideas! Much better than google! I worked there for almost 10 years. Great free food
cons: I really can't think of any it is the best placed I have ever worked. It is just incredible they really listen to you
advice_to_mgmt: Work on competing with google!

headline: Software Engineer
pros: No Pros for the people join in after ipo.
cons: No work life balance, culture is so bad. It almost squeezed you all your time and give you a great pressure.
advice_to_mgmt: Need to change the culture to be more friendly to the engineer.

headline: Awesome
pros: Facebook treats people really well.
cons: Very competitive environment, if you're not the right kind of person for this it can be challenging.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue doing what you're doing.

pros: It much better working environment than most of the companies.
cons: no such cons for company like facebook

headline: Account Executive
pros: Very good work experience for future jobs.
cons: Low Salaries and not valued as an employee

headline: Wonderful company but they outsource to a call center
pros: Working for Facebook! It is an amazing opportunity to learn all about this great platform. The employees that would visit the Phoenix office always treated everyone with respect and professionalism even though we were the outsourced employees. It was great to have your ideas and opinions taken into consideration by people creating something for a billion people!
cons: Revana/ Teletech is the company that hires people to work on the Facebook account. They hire entry-level people, people with criminal records, on up to people that have an education and work ethic. (Most of us that worked at real jobs prior to this were laid off from a variety of professions.) You have to start as an entry level telemarketer pitching the help of "Facebook marketing experts". You can move up in the company, but you will only ever make $13.50 an hour +commission based on a bucket system. You cannot pay your bills on the sketchy way the sales are calculated. Some people run scams and do shady things to get ahead and get top commission. Bottom line is that it is a call center and you will never be treated like a real Facebook employee. Cheryl Sandberg recently spoke about all FB employees making MUCH more than the Revana employees. I guess Facebook's call center doesn't need to Lean In. We would have people from HQ (with the same job title but making in the $70k range) sit with us to learn how we do our jobs. There was NO chance of advancement other than becoming a supervisor to telemarketers and moving up in the Revana call center system. I am giving the Career Opportunities section 3 stars because you can get good job offers to leave the Revana office by going to advertising agencies or other marketing jobs.
advice_to_mgmt: Facebook should ire from within. The employees at Revana are allowed to say that we worked for Facebook on LinkedIn (in case clients would check) but not on our resumes? What? Also the clients in the different programs are told that they were working with a "Facebook employee". If someone asks, you are told to tell them "YES, I am with Facebook not a 3rd party". All of the hard working employees need to either leave or deal with the horrible pay. I loved the job but I had to leave because I couldn't afford to stay when I could make more working at Starbucks.

headline: My experience
pros: -Very good company with time balance.
cons: -No cons at all. A like it a lot.

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: Moves fast on projects, efficient processes for workflow, excellent tools in place to get work done, great people, amazing benefits, wonderful work/life balance
cons: Far from SF and commute time is really long

headline: facebook software developer
pros: I think the employees there are prominent, the salary is good and I learnt much. I like its product and creativity.
cons: but the hr is not so good. The food there is so-so. The environment is not charming. So I decide to other companies.
advice_to_mgmt: hr should be good to us. manage should not be too hashed. The managers are not honesty enough, sometime they can't do sometime they promise to.

headline: Software engineer
pros:
1. Bootcamp is a really great program to choose teams. You get to talk to different managers and have the freedom to choose teams.
2. After working in a team for a year, you can change to a new team. There is a program called hack-a-month. You can go to another team to work for a month, and then decide whether you want to stay or com back. It is really flexible.
